From a business perspective, employment plays a pivotal role in driving consumer demand for companies' products. When individuals are employed, they have a steady source of income, which enables them to make purchases and contribute to the economy. This creates a positive cycle where businesses generate revenue, which in turn allows them to invest in product development, innovation, and marketing.

Conversely, unemployment presents a challenge for businesses as it reduces the number of potential customers with disposable income. Unemployed individuals may face financial constraints and prioritize essential expenses over discretionary purchases, leading to decreased demand for companies' products. This can have a negative impact on business revenue and growth.

Therefore, from a business standpoint, it is important to recognize the link between employment and consumer spending. Policies and initiatives that promote job creation and economic growth can stimulate demand for companies' products and services, ultimately contributing to the success and sustainability of businesses.

Your bit about "the gap" resonates with me so much, and I've been saying as much about creative AI tools since they became a thing. I have just so many creative ideas stuck in my head but don't have the technical skill to make them real. Creativity should not be limited just to those who have spent years practicing their craft; it should be for everyone. We're entering an era where you no longer have to have expertise to be good at things, and I find that genuinely exciting.

With music in particular though I feel like the level of intentionality needed in any tool would be much higher. It can't just be a text prompt like the image generators because you really can't encode a song as an English description of that song. Like, imagine having to describe a song you know and then ask a producer that's never heard of that song to recreate it. The odds of it sounding right would be zero. Words are simply not a good medium to express the intentionality of any sort of song with all its nuances and micro-decisions in each second of it. I would love to see some tool that takes a song idea I have in my head and turns it into a wav file with as little friction as possible, but I want it to be my song, not just a song. Honestly I can't think of any UI short of a brain computer interface that would do that super well. I could maybe work with a good img2img equivalent where I could feed in a garbage sounding draft of a sound file and it just makes the mixing good and polishes things up for me. Maybe it could give advice on how to make it sound better.

You might get some basic to intermediate code out of an AI, but Will it be supportable? Will you be able to deploy it to a production system? Will you be able to maintain it? Will you be able to patch the underlying systems that run the code? I think if you look at the entire team that it takes to run major production level software systems, you might be able to replace the junior programmers. But we've still got a ways to go before we can start declaring programmer's obsolete, and even further in order to get rid of the operations(SRE, Devops, Sysadmin) side of the equation.

5 years before jr programmers could replaced on a team, 10 years before lead engineers, 15+ before a product manager could manage all the roles of a software team without others to write, deploy and maintain a software system.

In all likelihood, engineers aren't going anywhere anytime soon. We will use AI to accelerate the building, deployment, and maintenance of software. But I think you'll still see the combination of AI + smart engineers, working together to produce more competitive outcomes than just AI.

I expect there to be a hot industry of consultants that have to come in and unfuck software systems that were built and productionized by AI in concert with people who didn't know what they were doing.

This is what ChatGPT, answer to the question: "How the future of music will be impacted by artificial intelligence ?"

It is difficult to predict exactly how artificial intelligence will impact the future of music, but it is likely that AI will play a significant role in the creation and distribution of music. AI technology could be used to create new musical instruments and sounds, and could even be used to compose and produce entire songs. Additionally, AI could be used to analyze and understand consumer preferences, making it easier for music creators to tailor their music to their audiences. It is also possible that AI could be used to automate some of the more tedious aspects of the music creation and distribution process, freeing up artists to focus on their craft. Overall, the use of AI in the music industry has the potential to greatly enhance the creation and distribution of music, but it is important for artists to carefully consider how they want to incorporate AI into their work.

The company Envato recently started leaning heavily towards AI. First they declared that all portfolios that exist on their platform now belong to the company, and started training AI to generate commercial work that original artists will not be compensated for, or even offered the option to opt out of having their work trained.
To save space for AI content, they limited the human artist ability to submit new work, set up limits on how much submissions they can publish each week. Then reduced artist commission incrementally so they can no longer make a living on their platform.
What's really amazing about all this, is that even though all these steps above were publicized, it failed to generate any type of backlash or attention.

Timetable:
2022: announced that artists can sell AI content on their platform, then quickly backed away from this decision for fear of copyright laws.
2022: introduced kangaroo quality standards to limit submissions from human artists.
September 2022: took away 30% of commission.
June 2023: illegally took possession of everything that was published on their platform, trained AI models without compensating the original artists.
August 2023: reduced artist commission from 50% to 25%. And limited submission of new products for human artists.

I'm a developer of a lot of the application infrastructure that keeps the Internet "interneting." It's been my work for over 20 years, and evolved into a consultancy that I own that manages and provides service for some of the most crucial mission-critical processes that very large data centers use. One exception for me is AI, as I thought to steer clear of putting any eggs in that basket since it seemed like a short-lived fad (and it kind of turned out to be, as it did not develop into the monolithic technology that the tech bros said it would, predictably...).

To provide some context for what I'm about to say, my first major in college (dropped out after 2 years) was in art. Considering the attitude the average person in such a school had (insufferable, full of themselves, considering that I should be amazed to be graced by their very presence, believing themselves to be beyond the talent of Rembrandt or Van Gogh), I can't say I feel too much sympathy for these glorified pixel doodlers.

On the other hand, it isn't beyond my comprehension how much of a shift this is, that art on the web will be appropriated by a system that requires minimal effort to execute. One good compromise for this would be to eliminate all AI training material that contains any work that isn't CC-licensed. It'll still be enough of a basis, and that incentivizes the development of more robust algorithms that rely on diffusion alongside [redacted] to synthesize the same exact art it currently does anyway. That way at least you legally cover your ass while continuing the tear fest.

In the meantime, I'm willing to put in resources from the servers in DCQ1 for that little project. Gonna get in touch with some of my old colleagues.

The issue with the concept that AI is making art more accessible is that art is accessible. There are thousands of artists out there who are begging for work. And yet so many scumbags are too damn lazy and stingy to pay them to make something for them. Despite any good AI could do if it was trained ethically, it will always be used by cheap people who don't care about their fellow humans. Artists and writers are some of the most exploited workers out of all the arts-- theft and plagiarism was always common and frowned upon, but now it's even easier to do-- and it's anonymous.
Spoken word and people clapping their hands together will always exist.

Now here's another ethical dilemma: When we get to the point that most cars are self-driving and are 10 times less likely to have an accident, should humans even be allowed to drive on public roads at all?

I could see some value in an actual hypothetical (electric) self driving car concept. Let's ignore all the many problems it has with variety in road design and various other non-car modes of transportation as a solved problem in that scenario.

But in order to make it an improvement for the urban situation it has to be at least not privately owned for the majority of the residents but some kind of shared pool of vehicles. Ideally used by combining multiple departure/arrivals along that route or filling the vehicle with one family. It would reduce the need for parking space in residential areas and also at the destinations if they were only allowed to be parked there for a limited time period. But to some extent I suppose this could quickly turn into some form of transportation closer to the public transport side but with dynamic routes based on the demand. Another benefit of an actual self driving car would have been the same one that applies to public transport time, it's not always strictly wasted time getting from A to B. Reading books, attempting to study, nap time on the longer train rides, etc come to mind.

But honestly I've got no idea how one would go about changing the car centric design in North America. It's probably going to be a painful slow and gradual thing if it happens at all, ah well there are still places over there I wish to visit some day but I'm happy to live in a place where I don't need a car for basic survival living outside the city. Having my licence is certainly useful, bicycle/public transportation won't always be suitable depending on when I have to leave and what the destination is or when bringing the cat to the vet with, hauling big and heavy stuff, etc. Fortunately both my parents and brother live nearby and it has never been an issue for any trip planned somewhat in advance (like ask at least one day ahead of time, no guarantee for available cars on the day itself). Even less mobiole elderly people often get around safely using their mobility scooters on infrastructure designed around bicycles for local trips without having to rely on a third party for transportation.

Someone told me one day, "I wish there was a program that just translated English into a computer program". I said, "That already exists. It's called a Compiler". AI greatly speeds up 3 things 1) Learning - It gets right to the answer and shows you a method to do something even though you are completely ignorant about that area. You often don't ever has to ask that question again 2) Labor - It can do the typing for you in seconds that might take you an hour. All you have to do most of the time is tweak it a bit because it's very close most of the time but often off just a bit. 3) Debugging - It can get right to the reason for cryptic error messages.

There is probably a lot more I haven't thought of and don't remember. It can't directly replace a developer but it can make one developer do the work of 5 and so indirectly cause fewer jobs for developers. It still needs the expert judgement of a human at this time.

I have a feeling that the only way artists in the future will experience any kind of "payday" is via the lawsuit.

As an aside on the coding part, as with any technical subject, subjects that are massively covered online (CRUD, hello world, very basic algorithms, etc.) produce solutions, whereas anything remotely complex produces garbage 99% of the time. In much the same way that you cannot use LLMs as a replacement for properly searching for sources and references, they cannot be used for advanced material due to a general lack of bulk understanding of that level of the field.

This shields most STEM professionals from it, as anyone who dares poke at the idea of replacing an Engineer with an extremely inaccurate LLM now has to contend with liability, something that not even the most persistent cons in the space are willing to touch.

It's staggering how many of the problems mentioned trace back to the system we've immersed ourselves in. From artists not being able to make minimum wage, to free time being an absolute luxury, to crypto bros looking for a quick buck, to corporations embracing whatever direction will help their bottom line. At what point do we stop blaming new technology and start blaming a system meant to exploit the many in favor of the few?
We're waaaaay past the point where every human should have food security, housing and sufficient income regardless of their work. AI amplifies this on a massive scale by automating so much more. So I'd say we need to look at more fundamental structures of how we organize society or we're just pushing the problem further down the line.

The technology is a tool, you cannot blame the tool.
A hammer can be used to build or to bash someone's head.
But you don't blame the tool.
The tool is here, it makes making art easier.
But now that everyone can create art that they want and not need to pay a ton of money to artists, suddenly artists start blaming a tool.
In the end it's still about money.
Not about the human soul, the "human being" the "artistic magic" or whatever.
It's about money and they know it and we know it and everyone else knows it.
The problem was and still is, MONEY!!
But a real artists doesn't demand money for their art.
A real artist shares his or her art, just because they want everyone else to see it, because they're proud of it.
If you're proud of something that you've created, you feel no need to make money off of it.
Because if you became an artist just so you could make money, you know nothing about art or the soul at all.
People paint and create for the sake of giving birth to something unique and that is reward enough.
To be proud of your creation, to feel the love that you've poured into it, now looking back at you, through your image, that is what art is about.
In today's world more than 60% of artists, aren't artists at all.
Art is and never was about making money.
Art is and always will be about creation and joy and satisfaction.
The dispute over A.I generations is about money and nothing else.
A true artist doesn't care if someone else copies their style and he doesn't care about recognition.
A true artist knows that his creation journey gives him joy and when the product is complete, a true artist moves on to his next project.
If you want to be a true artist, you need to remember this very old saying:

"As I create it, I give it birth, yet when it is born, I take no dominion over it, because only when I give it freely, it becomes art"

Art is there to be look at, to be shared, to be enjoyed by others.
It's not about the artist or his feelings or his ego or his monetary situation.
It is there to inspire.
True art is unconditional love, meaning it is made and it exists for others, not for the artist himself.
The journey of making it is for the artist to discover themselves, but when it is complete, the journey comes to an end for the artist and it becomes something for others to enjoy.
It is art to you when you are making it, but it is art to someone else, when it's complete and passed on.

True art is a gift, not a product.
You don't sell a gift, you give it freely.
Just like god doesn't demand a paycheck for you to live in his universe, he creates it for you and he demands nothing in return from you.
That is unconditional love.

This is why a true artist creates for the sake of creating, not for the sake of making money.
Creating from your heart is different than creating from your egoic mind.
If you're making something to sell, you're not making art, you're making a product.
Art has no defined purpose, no specific direction and no limits, life itself is art and all that exists within it, even A.I generators.

So people will not understand art, until they can see beyond their own ego.

For all the disgruntled artists out there I have this to say: "Making the art is your journey, enjoying that art is someone else's"
Your art shouldn't be about you, it should be about what others feel when they experience it.
So at least try making something for someone else to enjoy for once, instead of making it just for the sake of making money.

Until you learn how to infuse your art with a piece of your soul, it won't be art at all, it will only ever be a product.

WOW I‚Äôm really impressed by all of your points, I‚Äôve seen a lot of content defending artists and denouncing AI art and while I don‚Äôt mean to put artists down sometimes the arguments I hear really confuses me.

1. ML model training: not even listening to a song as you create, it‚Äôs more like an artist copying a piece of artwork by another artist in the process of learning - means almost nothing on an individual work basis, but taught something infinitely intangible to shape their future style and creation process. It‚Äôs THAT far detached from the artists‚Äô individual piece, particularly at the scale they reference, so this argument really doesn‚Äôt make sense to me. Artists can be uncomfortable having their work referenced but in an app like this it‚Äôs never pinpointed to an individual; plus that‚Äôs also how they learned and how the industry works? Art doesn‚Äôt just appear out of thin air. All that being said, when a data set is targeted to a specific artist then that‚Äôs a problem, but also what‚Äôs the difference between AI doing that and a human trying to imitate the style in new pictures? Unless you say the human is just as incorrect, in which case I would generally disagree but that‚Äôs a different topic.

And as an important aside I specifically reference large-scale training models, because I‚Äôm quite conflicted about other situations. I also only talk about these situations where you may upload your own photo or some other material owned by you, rather than pure ‚Äúrandomized‚Äù compilation by an artist because that‚Äôs an entirely different problem for reasons mentioned like it can‚Äôt extract from out of database.

2. ‚ÄúNot real art‚Äù - how do you even define art? Another argument I hear a lot is ‚Äúsupport an actual human‚Äù which is definitely great for those that choose to do so but at the same time no one owes anyone else anything. This argument is often commonly used for ‚Äúsupporting small business‚Äù but at the end of the day the consumer is looking for a product and they are not responsible to support anyone else. While I do personally enjoy small businesses, it‚Äôs not because I feel ‚Äúlike I should‚Äù, and likewise I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a relevant argument for art.

3. I don‚Äôt believe that something taking more effort necessarily increases that item‚Äôs value (which is different from that item‚Äôs value to a person, and in both cases value specifically refers to ‚Äúthe item itself‚Äù). Eg someone types a paragraph and someone else types that exact same paragraph but it takes them more time and effort for whatever reason, doesn‚Äôt mean that second paragraph is inherently valued more (it could be worth more, but I‚Äôm hitting the limitations of the English language differentiating between the two, hopefully you get what I mean). That said, theSpeechProf on YouTube said something pretty important. I could get an AI piece I spent $2 on or a handcrafted piece, whether significantly more expensive or free as a gift; one I could toss away without caring, the other I‚Äôm absolutely treasuring.

Anyway, probably gonna get a lot of hate if anyone reads, but as someone in a middle ground (I create art for gifts but don‚Äôt rely on it for finances) which should be relatively unbiased, here‚Äôs some scattered thoughts too late into the morning. And open to change with new ideas too.

HUGE SIDENOTE: I don‚Äôt mean these arguments to undervalue the price of an artist‚Äôs work. Since the dawn of time that‚Äôs something I know artists have been struggling with and it‚Äôs ridiculous; AI art may be pennies whereas similar handmade is hundreds, but that‚Äôs because a human being spent hours plus years of education and practice to do what they do. AI can get close, but likely can‚Äôt offer that full extent of customization. I think people can make their own decisions of which they would prefer, but they have no right to judge the value of an artist‚Äôs work, time, or effort just because AI can do it cheaper.

Edit: also want to clarify that I‚Äôve never used this app and tbh the extent of my knowledge about it is seeing a few ai portrait pics floating around + the workings explained in this video + limited background understanding of ML models. It could be these apps are totally different than how I picture in which case my opinions here are less valid

I agree this is the end of programming as we know it. But that has happened many times before. When we went from assembly language to modern programming languages. What we expected of an engineer changed drastically when we had google and stack overflow. This is another time where things will dramatically uplevel again and what we expect a developer to produce will change. I don't think developers, will go away, they will be expected to create bigger, better, software in far less time.

However, AI is getting good at writing software that we are able to produce today based on the information that it has ingested today. Each time we previously had a bump in how software was done, we also had a bump in the complexity, quality, and expectations from software. We will have such a bump again. We will no longer tolerate how often software doesn't work, goes down, has security holes, etc. as it did in the past. I think it will take the software developers of the future to be able to create that software. I do think how they create it will change quite a bit and may hardly be recognizable to what it is today, but software developers as a profession will still exist. It will just look different (as will most professions as a result of AI).

As an artist, I was initially terrified by the ease at which AI could create art, seeming to replace the hours it takes for an artist to create something. However, I have found comfort in reviewing the history of photography and the opportunities that created for art. Sure, it took some work away from the classic portrait-style artists (as a photograph better captured the resemblance of the family), but photography eventually just became another medium for artists to use. So long as human interface is required to generate art using AI, there will always be a place for artists to use AI in their own practice.

Truly self-driving cars can improve traffic, if done correctly (and sometimes i doubt, that it will be done correctly). For example, if there is already a traffic jam, cars could take another route (something that humans could do as well, but choose not to do). And the main point from Grey's video is still valid: most traffic jams happen, when a car suddenly has to break and therefore all cars behind have to break, each one a little bit harder because of reaction time, until a car has to come to a full stop. With self-driving cars communicating this type of jam would be diminished. Of course this is not the "be all, end all" solution, i'm much in favour of inner cities without any cars around and a better public transport system!

Ive been drawing and painting since i was a child. Ive kept at it mostly as a hobbyist. I dont make any money as an artist; in fact i struggle to even call myself an "artist" because I feel to a certain extent i havent done enough of the "work" that artists do, like the different ways of practicing and such.

I used to enjoy however showing people things i worked on to completion when i could and peoples reactions were enough to make me keep going. Creating art is a lonely process, and when its done all of the work that went into it is lost in translation immediately. I also enjoyed joining art communities with other people doing the same things.

But thats over now. I have to wonder if people think its "real" or not. I have to reckon with the possibility that this picture that took me 4 months to create (i have a demanding full time job that has fuck-all to do with art) is being compared against something somebody made in a few seconds. I have to consider that somebody somewhere that wishes they could do what ive done can simply take it, make a couple tweaks and spit out something similar with a few typing prompts. And finally that whatever ive posted online is being actively used by machines and corporations to help people that cant do what artists do, and nothing to help the artists that they used in the first place.

It fucking sucks. Growing up i used to dread being a "starving artist" or spending my life toiling to become a master only to die in poverty while my art goes on to make someone rich 100 years later. Maybe it was because i spent a significant part of my young life poor already and i sacrificed the creative part of myself to ensure that i can support myself, like so many artistic folks do every day.

But now i see why that happens a lot more clearly than i did when i was making that choice. I feel really bad for those that did choose to follow their passions and dreams only to wake up one day to everyone in the world saying "now I can do that too.. in a fraction of the time AND effort."

I've gone over this very topic several times in the last few years and have come to the same conclusion each time. The only ethical way of handling accidents with self-driving cars is for each of them to prioritize the lives of people outside of the car. That means they will always choose to put passengers in danger before putting outsiders in danger. This way, it's the passenger's conscious decision to trust their life to a car the moment they enter it.

I'm a graduate researcher in machine learning as well as an artist (unprofessionally), and there are a few things artists need to understand if they want to effectively fight back against AI art. Legally, a case could be made that the AI is making a derivative work of your copyrighted art, but that is usually done on a case by case basis and you need to prove the AI essentially copied it. An artist does not own a style, so while the fact that the AI could copy your style and put you out of business, if you can't prove they are derivative works then you currently have no case. Legal Eagle has a great video about this.

Also, bias in machine learning (making sure there is race/gender/etc. diversity in training datasets) is a really important field and is taken seriously in the industry and academia; that isn't to say they don't do a great job right now. One of the issues is that you can easily get datasets online but they will be naturally biased. Then you need to collect more diverse data yourself and use a basket of different biasing algorithms which need fine tuning and still end up with an imperfect model.

Artists are already taking some of these companies to court but we will see how they do. AI is only going to improve in each and every field. Even programmers like myself are starting to see AI do our own job.

As a previous Lecturer of Law in Rule Production I am weary the all obfuscation of the real world solution to this question which is easily resolved in real life. Indeed law makers around the world have faced similar issues many times before with self driving trains, elevators, escalators etc. etc. And the answer is dead simple. If the car must choose between several possible outcomes it chooses according to the following schematics totally disregarding the individual status of the persons involved - 1) the car always first tries to avoid deaths 2) the car next always sacrifices the passengers (this is why a train with 500 passengers will emergency break for one person - even if the risk is multiple deaths on board btw) 3) the car sacrifices the least amount of people outside the car 4) the car goes for minimizing the individual damage 5) the car sacrifices other people on the road first 6) the car sacrifices people in traffic before people outside traffic - such as someone parking) etc. etc. Easy peasy a rule maker were a long standing guiding principle is to let those who choose to take risks run the risks. You get in the car - you accept you go first. You lump together - you know your risk is higher. You are onto the road - you know your risk is higher. You are in a traffic situation (like in parking) - you know your risk is higher. The reason this works in real life is because self driving cars are much safer in average than people driven cars - so you have the principle of average risk taking maximized throughout the system. The only interesting question is if we always should always sacrifice people in road traffic before people outside road traffic, for which you can make a very valid case, here point 3) may however prove to be too strong a principle to disregard at any time. I frankly fear the question is only being perpetuated widely to hide the real issues with self driving cars which are about privacy, ownership of and access to personal data etc. [You can test my principles on the film's questions and see that they hold 100%]

For self-driving cars, the levels you mentioned are very bad way to look at the state of the technology. They were devised long before we even understood the problem, and look at it more from a legal perspective. The difference between levels is essentially who takes responsibility in different circumstances. Tesla's FSD for example can drive anywhere in most conditions about as well as an average human. That sounds pretty close to level 5, but level 4 for sure. Yet officially it's just level 2, same as basic adaptive cruise control and lane keeping, because the driver remains responsible for safety at all times.

Also, 2035 is ridiculous, a decade too late. The Tesla FSD is already close, it only has a couple of stubborn bugs, and some loose ends to tie up. And they are coming out with a completely new architecture (literally any moment now), which is far better, allegedly indistinguishable from human driving.

AI scientist here - generative AI is currently really good at certain tasks, like summarizing longer texts, generating simple emails, etc. However, it's still difficult to ensure that the model outputs factual information and not something that just sounds good. It's a useful tool for some things, but it absolutely shouldn't be crammed into everything just for the sake of saying they're using AI. And it definitely shouldn't be used to replace creative roles like writers and artists, because it's "creative" output is only based on meshing together things its already seen, and it's not driven by human experience and emotions. I also tell everyone I work with that anything generated by AI should be clearly labeled as AI output.

Also - it's fancy math, it is not in any way self-aware or conscious. Don't be fooled.

Firstly it's machine learning, not true AI. AI is a buzzword used to raise capital from investors. The LLM's (Large language models GPT4 etc.), don't think in the way humans do. It is not sentient or alive in any way. They are really just a very complicated set of paths that guess the right answer. Secondly, what it produced is based on content originally created by humans and it was taught and corrected by humans. The LLM's also don't know whether the art they have created is any good, or the software is correct. I can ask the LLM to write some code to do something I previously would have had to Google, adapt and make work for myself, but if I have a complex idea about a new app I want to write, I can't describe what I want to it, and see it produced in seconds. So far the LLM's have not really invented anything new and if it did it would not realize it. I did read it had come up with a better mathematical algorithm or something like that, but it is the human that realized that. People can already create their own website, but if a company needs something specific, the web designer has the advantage of being able to converse with another human and understand their needs. So I expect the technology will focus on the off the shelf boiler plate stuff and techy people will need to become more focused on the big picture. That's how jobs will change.

As a self taught traditional artist, I have a few thoughts.
I don't make a lot of money from my art, and the money I do make is almost exclusively pet portraits. My clients generally just want me to copy a picture, or use a handful of pictures to put their pet in an aesthetic pose, so practically speaking they could get the same flavor of result by running the photo through a watercolor filter. But they choose to pay money for the time, labor and skill it takes for a human to paint their pet. So my rational brain tells me AI isn't a threat to commission artists to the extent that some are saying (although many artists do bring home food with money made off smaller assignments like flyers or album art, so it still is displacing their income).
That being said, my emotional brain hates AI art. It hates it because of how streamlined and heartless the end product is. Art, music, writing, theater, any creative outlet, is so intrinsicly human. People have always created, since we lived in caves and etched mammoths and deer on the rock. It's so important for humans to make art, and I don't want it to be taken from us by machines we built. It just feels traitorous.

Now I understand why Apple customer support on the phone was useless and I had to drive to an Apple Store where an actual human made the right decision. Apparently their AI prioritizes Apple profit above all else. (I'm sure they'll adjust it - as it is, it made sure my next phone will be a Pixel with GrapheneOS.)

There is a fundamental philosophical difference between the type of wrong humans do, and the type AI does (in its present form). I think programmers are in danger of seriously devaluing the relative difference between incidental errors and constitutive errors - that is, humans are wrong accidentally, LLMs are wrong by design - and while we know we can train people better to reduce the former, it remains to be seen if the latter will remain inherent in the implementation realities of the latter - i.e. relying on statistical inference as a substitute for reason.
But if you never post your "work" and only use them as wallpapers, I see that as an absolute win.

For those wondering about GPT-4: Creative mode of Bing Chat uses it and you don't pay for it. Here's my experience so far:
GPT-4 is a double-edged blade. It's slower, but it can output more text.
The quality of the text is... Better, but overstimated for many.
Asking the same question to both and the results were almost equal. The key difference is that 4 tends to elaborate a bit more on some topics.
It doesn't elaborate a whole lot and it still is prone to making stuff up. But there's not much I can do to end this issue, only reducing it...
Overall, I still use GPT-3.5 a bit more since Bing doesn't allow me to save the chats.
Should you try it? If you wish, try it for free. Just be aware that it isn't a silver bullet.
(Edit: It's also a bit kinder if you correct him.)

An interesting aspect of art (prior to modern computing and following through to the present) is social resentment and social competition.  This resentment and social competition is not just against the artist but also the work itself. The prestige and value in art is overt, experiential, and seemingly mysterious or out of reach outside of artists.  Aside from overt vandalism (destroying art for negative prestige), critique, sneering, and other attempts at peer pressure campaigns against the work and the artist is very old. AI as a con game claiming to distribute the mysterious prestige can be expected.  Or as Swift described in Gulliver‚Äôs Travels ‚Äúthe Engine‚Äù: ‚ÄúEveryone knew how laborious the usual method is of attaining to arts and sciences; whereas, by his contrivance, the most ignorant person, at a reasonable charge, and with a little bodily labour, might write books in philosophy, poetry, politics, laws, mathematics, and theology, without the least assistance from genius or study.‚Äù

The rise of jobs like prompt engineers but the fall of programmers feels weird to me. Prompt engineers are essentially programmers using a different form of code to give the AI specific set of instructions.
Then again, to develop these AI models requires programmers to create these models and train them. Since a programmer is just someone who gives the computer instructions to do, we will always need them unless the AI can instruct and repair itself like it is conscious, but by then, we will have a much bigger problem.

We couls also build a big, superefficient car on a optimized lane - maybe bunched up with more carts to minimize drag. Then many people that want in the same direction could get in, making a couple of stops, while one AI supervised by one driver makes sure to drive safely. While we're at it, we could exchange concrete and rubber that is expensive and environmentally problematic with something less intense on friction, like... Steel. Lets call it "tracks". Since said track is optimized for aggregation zones, it could have electric supply lines above or integrated so we dont need to drive around heavy batteries. I hope to see more of such futuristic self-driving cars around one day.

Considering these trends, is essencial for the computer programming industry to adapt and strategize for long-term:

1. Upskilling: Encourage continuous learning and upskilling among employees to stay abreast of technological advancements and remain competitive in the evolving market.

2. Diversification: Explore opportunities beyond traditional programming services, such as AI development, cybersecurity, or software testing, to diversify offerings and cater to emerging market demands.

3. Collaboration: Foster collaboration with other tech sectors and professionals to leverage synergies and stay innovative in a rapidly changing landscape.

4. Market Research: Invest in market research to identify emerging patterns, consumer behavior shifts, and technological advancements that could shape the industry's future.

Thank you Matt for your kind words and for sparking such an important conversation! As a Project Lead and Senior C# .NET Developer, I've seen firsthand the capabilities and limitations of AI in coding. While AI, including technologies like GPT-4, has become an invaluable coding assistant, helping us to explore design patterns, architecture, and even tackle some coding tasks, it's clear that AI is not poised to replace human developers, especially in complex scenarios.

Developing enterprise-level applications requires a nuanced understanding of not only coding but also business logic, user needs, and security‚Äîa realm where human expertise and critical thinking are paramount. Furthermore, the ethical and regulatory implications of AI-generated code, particularly regarding accountability for security flaws or data breaches, present significant challenges. These issues underline the importance of human oversight and the collaborative synergy between AI and developers to navigate the complexities of modern software development responsibly.

Your points echo a vital message: AI is a tool to enhance our capabilities, not a replacement for the creativity, judgment, and accountability that human developers bring to the table.

Thanks for your insight your video makes me feel more hopeful and less worried about Ai art. I‚Äôm the head graphic designer at my job and a few years ago the business partnered with a much larger business. Suddenly instead of all art being created by us designers, we started getting a lot more pre-made art. Generic art is made in India by designers there for cheaper prices and then a program lets people auto change the text and colors and then they can download the vector files. It‚Äôs always worried me that my job might become obsolete because of things like this. However, the Ai doesn‚Äôt always do the best job with spacing and re-coloring so we are still valued higher. If someone wants a really great design they don‚Äôt bother with the pre-made art and they tell us what they are looking for and we make it from scratch. However a lot of customers don‚Äôt seem to care that the Ai art is cheesy or the spacing/layout sucks. Sometimes it hurts my soul knowing someone is paying for a trash pre-generated design that we could have made way better if we made it from scratch. When cameras became a thing, realism art was no longer such a big deal so artists had to evolve and create things you can‚Äôt just take a photo of. Ai just means us artists will have to evolve into styles that can‚Äôt be replaced by Ai. My main annoyance for Ai images I‚Äôve been finding on Pinterest is that it is starting to get hard to tell what is real and what is not. I‚Äôve always thought of human brains starting as empty black boxes. Our senses throw inputs into our brains, and those observations, sounds, tastes etc. bounce around and melt into a big soup. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre capable of imagining anything that isn‚Äôt some derivative of or iteration on the data that we‚Äôve ingested. Sure we can imagine all sorts of novel scenarios or put unusual perspective on ideas, but it all derives from the stuff we‚Äôve put in there. This is also exactly how ML neural nets work. ChatGPT/midjourney etc. are trained on HUGE data sets. Arguably more data than any one person can ingest in a lifetime. They can also generate novel perspectives and scenarios, just like humans. In short, I think we‚Äôve truly reached a strange turning point. Something fundamental has changed, most of us just haven‚Äôt realised yet.

I kinda don't like this on principle for the same reason I don't like to tell people to learn with python. My exception is if you are specifically coding just for hobby projects. If you want to get good at coding though, you should learn without shortcuts. Different people will define different things as shortcuts, but to me, I think Java is a great language to learn with since you are forced to be verbose, but you can still skip stuff like doing garbage collection yourself. If you 'learn' with co-pilot, then you aren't really learning anything and may not even know what that code does at the end of the day. If it works for your personal project, that is great, but if you rely on it heavily and want to get better at programming and being able to do complex stuff, I think it's gonna make things harder in the long run.

All that said, I would say it could be a good tool if you already have a good grasp on the basics. I use Python for most of my hobby projects for that same reason.

I have zero skill as an artist. I simply don't have the mind's eye for it, and yes, I'll admit it. I don't have the patience to learn. I STILL despise AI art. I don't see it as a democratization of art. I see it as a devaluation of art. I... LOVE watching real artists work. I love the process. I love seeing how they turn sketchy lines into basic shapes, and then basic shapes into compelling imagery. It's as close to magic as we can get in the real world. The only people who consider AI art to be real art are people who refuse to try and understand art. Art says something about the creator's story. It's a reflection of their unique experience. Their passions and interests. I might not experience it exactly the same way they do, but I can respect it. I can experience it in my way while also imagining it in their way. AI art lacks soul. It lacks... emotion. If AI art were to be perfected tomorrow, and I could get exactly what I think I want, down to the pixel, I would still reject it. Something about imagining what was going through the artist's mind when they created a piece is crucial to my enjoyment of it. To me, the process is just as important as, if not moreso than, the finished product. I'm immensely glad the USCO has determined that AI "art" is uncopyrightable, and I only hope this clamps down even more. If I want some art that is to my specifications, I will always hire a real artist rather than have a machine pump out stale junk. The common defense of AI art using data from real artists to make something being the same as real artists mimicking each other is bullshit. "You inspired me to learn your style!" is a lot more respectful, implies hard work, and is more touching than "I didn't want to pay you, so I fed your stuff to an AI."

I am always disappointed that videos talking about job loss to not add a quantitative attribute to their discussion. To my understanding, after every revolution, we get more efficient in performing tasks so the total number of jobs will go down. Ie. 10 000 000 physical paper accountants -> 100 000 programmers creating accounting software -> 1000 AI researchers managing accounting AI. Yes, we get new jobs but after every iteration the number actually goes down. Yes we get great improvements in quality of life on the mankind level but the average Joe still loses the job.

AI can help us make some boring tasks much easier and faster, but it cannot replace us.
Note: AI cannot invent things. It is just a bunch of mathematical patterns that are trained on data. It cannot come up with anything new that is not already in the data.

I think it'll be relatively easy to just train an image classifier to detect poisoned vs unpoisoned images, all you really need to do is run your training data that you already have from your existing art generator through the nightshade tool, then label it as "poisoned" and the originals as "clean". Then you can use that classifier to detect any images that might be poisoned and discard them from your future training data. Include a paranoia threshold so that you can tune when the confidence is too high ("it's over 40% certain it's poisoned, get rid of it!") and you can probably just have the computer fight the computer that's fighting the computer.

Of course I think the bigger problem with AI is that its it's own Achilles heel. The Dead Internet problem means that more and more potential training data is generated by previous versions of the AI, putting a hard cap on output quality unless you can make a good enough classifier to detect (unpoisoned) AI created data and remove it from your training data.
Certainly interesting times ahead!

Really intrigued by the "Jarvis" project and its capabilities in automating software creation with AI-assisted dialogue. I'm working on a hobby project of my own with a similar concept. I'm building a full-stack template, focusing on a robust, modular monolithic architecture (the most pragmatic for 95% of cases, imo) as its foundation. The goal is to train AI using a lot of examples based on this foundation, allowing it to autonomously develop and deploy enterprise-level software (again, built within the robust 'framework').

Seeing this "Jarvis" only makes it more obvious that further developing that concept in general has potential to significantly redefine the programming landscape. Genuinely looking forward to not having a job (even though I love programming) sometime in the future!

One thing is that while LLMs may enable non-technical people to write code, those same people could perhaps become technical.
What is at the heart of skilled technical people isn't just their raw knowledge of programming, but their command of logic and design.
Anyone who is a good problem solver with the ability to sequentially and recursively solve problems could program. Everyone doesn't have those same abilities by virtue of genetics and/or experience.
The key issue isn't raw knowledge, it's the ability to think like a programmer or an engineer to create things and solve problems.
So it isn't as simple as anyone can do it because of specialized logic skills, that many have, but some don't (although they could learn to one extent or another if given the opportunity)

I'm a traditional artist (watercolor, gouache). However, I don't agree with your assessments, because you are falling into false dichotomies. From one side you say that art is a process, but if other people find value in using AI art, then it means that art can also be functional (product) and not just a craft (process). No one cares how many hours a wool pullover took to knit, for example, or what kind of sheep was sheered to get it. All they care is if it looks good on them. I mean, heck, the only people who watch watercolor paintings on youtube are artists themselves, NOT normal people. The process is not something people care. And in a democracy, the masses always win.

Additionally, you are having misconceptions regarding AI. AI can free the hands of artists to create new things. Look how AI art started big last April: "an astronaut on the moon, on top of a horse". A simple, little sentence. Fast forward 4 months, and the prompts were now whole paragraphs long. Fast forward 3 more months, and now there is InvokeAI, where you EDIT and you (crudely) draw on top of the canvas to instruct the AI what, and how to draw what you have in mind.

In other words: AI started as a half-a33ed tool that didn't feel like real art (but rather just pretty images with no intrinsic value), to a FULL BLOWN editor, where a HUMAN is driving the process! The art has become AI-assisted, instead of AI-driven. (Check the Canvas feature of InvokeAI on youtube videos to see what I mean). And this is huge! This means that the hands of artists will be FREE to minimize the "process" of making an art piece. You can now make real art, complex art, directed by an artist all the way, in half an hour. This is huge, this is amazing progress. Because while the "astronaut on the moon on top of a horse" is not art per se, the EDITED image of a brand new human idea, where it has directed every part of the image, IS.

And please don't point to the argument that "art in half an hour still lacks process, so it's not true art", because then I can point you to Procreate and Photoshop that make art still much faster than doing it on canvas or paper. Digital programs are doing the same thing that AI editing tools do, just slower and with way more input by the user.

And yes, there is going to be saturation of such artists and art when such editing tools become more available. Commissions will go away 100%. That's the part of the art economy that will disappear. You will now only make art to EXPRESS yourself, just like you always wanted it to be. No more customers.

Because you see, you can't have it all. You can't claim artistic expression, and then cry that you won't have clients. Your artistic expression IS ALWAYS LIMITED when it comes to commissions. And I know what I'm talking about, because before I became a painter, I was a world famous collage artist (no, I'm not exaggerating). I've done multiple commissions for NYTimes, Wired, Netflix, Cosmo, Oprah Mag, and whatever else you can think of. And EVERY FREAKING time I had to do a commission for them, it was NEVER what I wanted to do with their input or article subject. Each and every of these magazine/newspaper editors RESTRICTED my expression, and they essentially told me what they wanted from me. AS IF THEY WERE WRITING AN AI PROMPT. I wasn't feeling like an artist in these cases. I was just the AI for them, but at slow, human speeds.

Now, AI frees your hands and THEIR hands. Editors of magazines won't ever have to pay for commissions again, they will get exactly what they want, and artists will also create things that was not possible or easy before. Their imagination is their limit. Now, you can truly express yourself. AI is just a tool. That WILL take commission jobs away. But now, you can finally be a TRUE artist, and never have to think of reducing your artistic integrity by bowing out to commissioners. Now, you're free to create as you should be. It's just that you will also need to have a second job to support your hobby. And that's fine, for a true artist who only want to express themselves, rather than limiting themselves with commissions. If people like your stuff, they'll buy a print. Or maybe not. Original works on paper/canvas will also make a comeback, just like Vinyl is, for the diehards. These are our options. And I'm ok with that having lived as a professional, and rather successful artist. Now, I just want to do art for me, not for others.

@Cynthia Zhou I disagree with your proposal because, first, I think "in the style of" should constitute copyright infringement. That artist's complaints are misguided because copyright infringement must occur at the time of sale, not at the time of production, that is to say that if I "sell art" than I as the "seller" should be legally responsible for selling a work which is infringing. Second, just like with the music industry, the act of dealing with an artist is both expensive and time consuming. You are asking people to trade 5 mins and $0 for returning to "pay me $1500 per image for commercial rights and I retain creative control," when in reality even if I like the "stroke style" of some artist maybe I don't actually like "THEIR ART WORK," only some specific brush stroke. In other words, it's a pointless loss of control and extra cost. I appreciate your argument that artists didn't get their piece and that there is nothing to learn from if no one makes anything new, that's completely right. I definitely don't think copyright actually applies to perception, in other words machine learning isn't infringing copyright because it is simply reading the data, that's actual nonsense. However, the truth of the matter is the company or companies took a bunch of art data, which they definitely required, and then sold the result. Talking about copyright actually derails the argument, because it's ignorant and only makes the arguer sound like an idiot to anyone who understands the technology, without exception. Your magic paint brush example was spot on, it hits the heart of the argument and the emotion of the argument while retaining reason and the appeal of the argument is the infringement of capitalist liberty, that of the artist in their contribution to the creation of that capital. I'm convinced enough by it that my stance is almost swayed, it would literally be swayed if I wasn't afraid to give up my civil liberties, i.e. the right to view, hear, or perceive copyrighted works in private as a human being, the right to own my own 'data' or in other words, the right to own my computer even if windows or osx is installed on it, and so on. If you let the legislators decide on too many of such things, I fear where we'll actually end up.

Sometimes I feel like a canary in a coal mine. I try to tell people this is going to have horrible consequences and people just hand wave all concerns away.
A personal example is my dnd group. Our dm likes to have character art for pcs and npcs to make things more immersive. Great! nothing wrong there, but where as she normally would've had to ask the players if anyone draws and build a connection with others, she just plays around with ai till it gives something 'good enough'. Never mind the hands are nightmarish, it gets details like hair and body type wrong, its 'good enough' so that's what we use. (not to bash her though, she's a wonderful dm. Watching lost chances for quality connections and human interaction just makes me feel depressed lol)
A lot of non artists don't seem to understand that people will accept a significantly lower quality product as long as it's free or almost free. And this will degrade the overall quality of art we get in our daily lives.
I'm sure I'm preaching to the choir here though, so how about a bit of optimism? There will always be value in what we do. A machine might 'learn' and make 'good enough' things but we give things soul. We give a kind of life and dedication to our work that will always be appreciated, even if it's never as wildly appreciated as it should be. But that's being a creative in general isn't it? I think we'll survive this, even if it's a rocky road we have to walk.

But we had this once. Before WWII residential neighborhoods were mixed residential and commercial. Intersections of major arterial streets generally were shopping districts. One of them would be close to you and the next closest maybe a mile away. Pretty much what you needed on an everyday basis would be there. Young people and old people lived there without cars getting around by walking, bus or bike. Families would have cars. Middle school kids could do their own shopping and operate fairly independently of their parents, meaning fewer cars driving them around. Retired folks might have a car, but rarely use it. This translates to traffic that flowed.

But after the war they decided to build large all residential developments with fewer, much larger shopping centers spaced many miles apart. Teenagers hated living in these places and there was no place for older people who did not feel comfortable driving in heavy traffic. So now couldn't bike to grandma's apartment who had to get driven along with the family. Kids no longer have any agency. I don't think people wanted this. I think this was simply what was available so they took it. So I don't think America's car centric world was something people (i.e "the market") demanded, but rather something the developers and planner wanted to foist on us.

My major concern with AI is if we ever do get to general artificial intelligence, there's a chance that the majority of humans become unnecessary under capitalism.

Consider how much power is concentrated in the hands of major corporations already. As it stands, they depend on people to deliver their goods and services. But a smart enough general artificial intelligence could (in theory) remove humans entirely from the equation. This wouldn't just put people out of work. It could complete change the economy as we know. What incentive would a major corporation have to sell goods and services to people when they a) don't have money or anything that they want and b) those corporations have technology that's capable of producing whatever they want, regardless of the moral inplications.

It really is up to AI developers to put their interests to one side to put safeguards in place. Governments, too.

You presented all artists as being against AI art and seeing art as a process rather than a product. As a professional artist and designer myself who works with many other artists in the industry, from my experience this viewpoint is a result of a sampling bias. It might seem that way at first glance, but in reality this only applies to the vocal minority. The silent majority who are happy to simply add these new AI tools to their toolkit aren't going to be nearly as vocal online about this as are those who are panicking that AI is going to take their job.

I loved your metaphor with cheap nice looking vases at the dollar store. This is a good way of looking at it, as it makes it clear that we should all collectively prefer to live in a world that features nice looking vases at the dollar store, than in the world that exclusively features expensive handcrafted vases.

In my opinion, having artists consent to their art being seen by an AI is no different from having them consent to their art being seen by anyone else. They consented for their art to be seen in general, the moment they published it. I know that AI has seen my art, and I'm quite happy to have contributed an infinitesimal amount to AI understanding art concepts in general, as I am to have any human be inspired by or learn by looking at my art.

Many artists don't understand how AI works, and are under the impression that AI is taking their art and remixing it with other art to create new art, while in reality AI is simply looking at it and learning concepts.

When I create art, I use various processes and tools and mediums, rather than being married to one particular process, medium or style. This means that I don't agree with the sentiment SamDoesArt expressed in this video of "combining all our life experiences with how we approach every single brushstroke". That's a politically charged statement, and I'm quite sure he isn't literally doing that, as then each of his brushstrokes would take days.

Rather brush stroking is like breathing or typing, more of a subconscious process. And puring and combining our life experiences instead applies to our intent, to where we guide the artwork towards as we work, to what we envision or discover that we want the artwork to become in a given context. AI does not replace any of this, and in fact beautifully integrates into helping us explore the space of possibilities orders of magnitude faster.

Humans + Machine will still outperform either one alone for the foreseeable future (Human + AI beasts AI alone in chess). As for programming, I do predict the rise of the role of ‚Äúsystem architects‚Äù rather than PMs, working on many small custom projects, and domain knowledge will still be worthwhile with a gradual shift in the value of skills. Regarding non-programmers, I predict that there will be a limit to how far they can design a system without having the right number of technical fundamentals and experience, especially when scaling to real-world systems. There will be applications that their knowledge and skills will produce solutions for, but not all.
A more cautious prediction, the problem of scaling both context retention and complexity, might turn out to be harder than we think. It‚Äôs unwise to extrapolate AI progress (Autonomous Driving?).

Your propasal at 16:00 is a viable alternative, and addresses a large part of the ethical issues sorrounding AI.

I've been enamoured with AI tech in the last month or so. Honestly, it gave me some anxiety. Now I've started to feel like this will be the beginning of truly amazing advancements in creative application, as well as truly terrifying realities with it. Like in every industrial turning point of human history. AI generated content will be appreciated as an abundant resource, human generated content will be appreciated as 'handmade'. Jay Leno made a thought provoking comparison of cars being replaced by dull and utilitarian electronic vehicles, especially if autonomous driving becomes universal. As enthusiasts we were scared that they will take the wheel from us, and with it, the mechanical harmony in honing the wheel between the driver and the road. But as cars came to replace horses, horses became its own luxury. much more luxury and exclusive market.

Likewise with AI generation, I think it will help in producing the broader mass of which human intervention will either touch up, or take inspiration, or a mix of such, and use it in content. Cheap and efficient, but still cheap. Human art will need to stand out in a way, like with a purebred - to have an approved stamp '100% made with thoughts, hours and carpal tunnel!"

It will, unfortunately, become a luxury to buy and use non AI content, so long as that content stands above the rest in a distinctive way surpassing what AI can 'deliver'. There will be a market.
There's so many mind boggling ways in which this will propose issues, mainly of the privilege reserved for the rich. To adapt they artists have to stand above the very top of their brilliance to really hone their craft in order to be seen and appreciated.

Artists deal with many existential crisis, it comes with the title, and this will be another one. But we also acknowledge that there's a saturation of 'content' in the market that are half-assed, with little to no sense of dedication, "passion" and effort to any distinctive level of technical skill. And whilst 'lazy' whimsical art can be brilliant in occasions, perhaps the whimsical part will be a value of its own. But technical prowess will have to be a priority going forward.

I'm not really going anywhere with this apart from the two conclusions I can say is that AI content will eradicate the saturation of low-effort content by being its own form of cheap and abundant but much better. And it will force creatives to truly commit to git gud or git out. Is that in itself a positive thing? No... there;s a lot of ethical issues and likely an entire sector of laws that will need to adapt to addressing all of this. Laws we don't even have for things like cryptocurrency yet. So for now, AI generation is here, it's real, and we have to embrace what it will require from us as creatives to standout in a much more brutal market. My personal view is... I accept that challenge, as tough as it is. It will require the best of what I can achieve or nothing at all from me. No half measures, no corner cutting, no 'interpretive' ambiguity. Like Van Gogh's Starry Night, it delivers something to the human eyes immediately and doesn't need to be explained. Or an Aston Martin, designed with both aesthetic excellence and mathematical composition at every angle. Or a Shakespeare poem, every line every stanza rhythmically composed, consistent in syllable, a marriage of mathematical prowess and imaginative expression to manifest literary brilliance. Okay I'm going a bit OTT here but I guess you've got the gist lol

Who knows, it's a scary future. Best that we can do is 'bring it on'. At least, that's my take on things. I know many will disagree and I respect that. But, what else is there? We can't stop these things, we have to adapt.

My take right now on this is that it might not affect the job market too much. A lot of people talk about there being less demand for juniors but if you work as a junior, you quickly realise it's mandatory to do so in order to eventually become a senior. Otherwise there will be less seniors, and following the law of supply and demand we all know what that means.

Also, people seem to worry about RIF. In my opinion, software teams don't move THAT fast already. If I was in charge, I'd keep the same amount of devs and use AI to accelerate the trajectory of the team rather than downsize. Maybe demand will wane once terminal velocity is achieved, but I can't see that happening any time soon.

I think you are missing something about the Product vs Process thing (great observation by the way), which is that the process isn't entirely lost when doing AI art, only part of it is lost, that being the technical part, the "having a steady hand" part, but the creative iteration is still there.
Think about it: if you tell the AI you want a landscape, it will spit out a generic landscape, very likely not what you wanted, and so you will have to keep prompting the AI with more and more details and changes that you want until you reach the result that you had in your mind, that might take you hours if your vision is very specific; that's actually not too different a process from traditional art, minus the brushstrokes.
I don't think the process is lost with AI art, it is just a technically different medium, not an inherently different one.

My take so far on AI is this. I haven't listened to much of it, but did hear some "Beatles" stuff. While it did indeed sound "Beatlesque", it did not sound fresh. For those that remember, every time the Beatles released new music, it had basically moved on from the last album and always had something new and fresh to offer. The AI stuff just sort of takes bits and pieces of their "signature sound" and rehashes it so to speak.
But here's how I would use it. When I sit and play "sounds", or patches from my synths or sound files, it puts me in a certain mood when I hear certain things and causes me to go places I probably would not go "sitting by the river" so to speak. So as I was listening to some of the things you were playing, most was junk, but there was a gem or two in there that might trigger an emotion or a "beat" or a texture, that sort of thing within me. But if you take that germ and then put the human mind and emotion into it, expand it and actually play the parts, I can see where a hybrid could be quite good. I suppose you could say use it for inspiration. It's going to come down to mining the gems from the dirt and separating the stone and then cut and put the polish on it to get it ready for the setting. Just one man's thoughts. And don't forget, only one out of a thousand records made by humans is worth listening to as well. And it might not even be that good of a percentage. We just mostly never hear the junk because it doesn't make it to the charts.

Hi Matthew. First of all thank you for your videos. I learn a lot.
I know you make such a title only for a hype. But if not, do you really think that AI is able to understand requirements written by human beings for a more or less big project (have you ever read such a crap? :) If the most advanced LLM has only 25K tokens context how it will help with a codebase of 100MB or 1GB? I work on a project with more than 200 DB-entities and uncountable number of relations between. It's so funny to hear how AI will leave me without a job in close time, but when I ask gpt-4 some questions about what I'm working on it's not able to answer at all. AI-copilots trained on existing code, it's not able to generate something new, like a good architectural solution (i.e. relations between hundreds of classes working well) in a big project. At this moment AI is good only for one-page-DIYs to impress people who know nothing about development.
Coding is not the biggest part of development. And what is AI copilots really good in, is just autocomplete. It really helps to save time to remind syntax or similar, but obviously it can not create something working in real life without an educated human. So, let's talk about that in 5 years, not now :)

Another great episode! I love this series. Since this is the first episode that is kind of in my vein as a composer and music producer, let me make a point about "the gap".

For non musicians, it can be easy to think that technology / knowledge of music theory is a hurdle that one needs to overcome to create. But in fact, it is what enables a musician to create in the first place. I believe that it is necessary to have some kind of process, a workflow, that inspires more ideas by providing tools to expand on previous ideas.

Let me give an example: I don't think that anyone has ever composed something entirely in their head, be it a symphony or a hip hop beat, and then tried to execute it as close to their imagination as possible. Rather, I think that you start with a very loose idea of a vibe, a feeling, maybe a melody, and then iterate and iterate and iterate - using the tools (!) that you have. And those tools provide more inspiration.

Those tools can be counterpoint harmony, or FL studio, or both. You cant create something big out of nothing. You need an initial spark, yes, but after that the tools are the necessary fuel to keep the creative process going.

My point is that we should not promote AI tools for music with the argument that it will be so much easier for everyone to create beautiful music. It won't be, because the gatekeepers are still the same. It's never been easier to create music *right now*, but still, some groups are underrepresented. Not because of the lack of technology, but ..... mostly because of platform capitalism...? Idk

The future of AI is time and time again presented as a solution to a deeper problem that we actually know how to solve *right now*. But it's easier to imagine a better future with AI than to point out the deeper problems in the now that it attempts to solve.

Honestly I'd be curious to see this new AI workflow. Everytime I consider using AI, it just doesn't seem worth the trouble except for some of the most basic tasks. The code it produces is usually flawed or it just can't help meaningfully because it doesn't know anything about the project as a whole to tie things together. And I still get stuck testing and looking over the AI's work to make sure it all actually works like it's supposed to. And if it doesn't... well then I have to debug it anyway. And if you can't program, I don't see how you can debug the AI's work properly.

Thus far the good use cases are fairly limited, like a strictly pure function that does some kind of relatively simple transformation, it's good at. It seems like a useful tool a programmer can use in some spots, but I haven't seen anything that seems to be be making the entirety of programming obsolete anytime soon. I might change my mind if I see some amazing workflow someone is doing with AI that's producing this perfect flawless code, but thus far my own experiences haven't been all that great. Once you get past the honeymoon phase of "OMG I typed a request and the computer is coding it", it just doesn't seem to be all that amazing at coding.

When you mention how animators and texture artists have been using ai tools for a long time, i think primarily they will be talking about photogrammetry and motion capture. The photogrammetry is obviously fairly automatic, but motion capture is not a simple plug and play automation. You have to resolve the delta between a captured actor and the target model, as well as manage interpolations between capture frames. Then on top of that you have to tweak animations to account for collisions, timing, and character performance. Its actually quite involved and not really automatable.

Lowering the bar never got us more creative. Creativity increases with the restrictions and the numbers of problems you have to solve. That's why the biggest outburst of creativity comes with technological innovations, in music: the electric guitar, the synthesizer, home recording, the DJ-set etc etc. When these technologies where introduced, it was the freaks, the nerds, who got to work and made new, exciting, fresh stuff that was creative. And it was creative because it was *hard*.

What you get from democratization is a lot of fluff, a lot of sameness, and a lot of middle-of-the-road stuff, that is: Not creative. Sure there are outliers, sure there will be masterpieces that wouldn't have been created with a higher bar of entry, but that's the exception to the rule.

I live in the US, and I got rid of my car a little over a year ago. It's rough, Ive spent extended periods in other countries with good infrastructure and transit, and the US does not have that. But you know what sucks worse than American public transit? Fucking driving.

I made that trip on transit for the first time, and google said that trip would take about 3.5 hours. It actually took 2.5. (I cant really say why thay was, since its my first time on this route) So, if we compare the best case scenario for both and the worst case scenario for both, it takes 30 minutes or so longer by transit, and then I have to get picked up or take a cab to my parents house, but I read half a fucking book and carried on a conversation by text without killing anyone.

My tital fare was about 7 dollars, and at current gas prices the round trip would have cost twice that in gas, to say nothing of the massive regular costs for maintenance, registration, and insurance (the main reason I ditched my car)

I cannot stress enough that this is in car country, in a place with bad transit. Cars suck so hard that taking the bus is still the better option.

Hey man, I love your videos. But let me correct you in just one point. You are possibly correct with stating in the title that AI will never replace "our" jobs, meaning your viewers, who are probably young and in tech or similar. But there's a certain difference in this industrial revolution compared to the ones before. The birth of the steam engine, the assembly line, or the computer had a huge impact on the way people worked and it surely made lives easier by replacing hard physical work. Workers could be easily trained to use the innovation, there was always a place for that worker in that company. This ai-revolution though replaces hard mental work. Stuff that people studied over years and maybe decades. There is no way, that people in the industry, who are comfortable with their routines, who are already in their 40s, 50s or 60s, can perform this amount of work in order to remain in their fields. Jobs created by ai will always be mentally demanding jobs, or creative jobs, that will be risky. As an example can accountants be easily replaced. And everything similar to the work of an accountant. Accountants need to resaddle to something completely new, using lots of mental effort. Not physical this time. This is the discussion german philosophers and industrial experts having at this moment. And why people like Elon Musk demand for basic incomes. To sum it up. Young tech people can adapt to ai-revolution. But most of older people, which carry the country on their backs, which jobs get replaced, can not easily resaddle to work in the jobs created by ai.
Ai is as good as the point artists have gotten up to. It's still up to artists to create new things and push art forward

That's the main problem with AIs currently - they can reach like 99% (and do it even better than humans) but then fail miserably at 1%. For example, AI might miss a thing that I can find in a document using a simple Find command, and it might even be not that huge text.
Today I found an ugly old piece of code and asked Bing AI to refactor it using specific framework functions. It created a nice working code with comments. Then I asked it to shorten the code by removing comments and getting rid of intermediate results to merge everything into an efficient one liner. And Bing failed miserably - it removed not only the comments, but also some parts of code, and when I asked it to add the specific missing piece of code back, it made it even worse and it did not even compile anymore.
So yeah, that last 1% might turn out to be the roadblock, the "uncanny valley" of programming.
Also, if AI finally learns to do it completely right and asks all the right questions about the business logic and the infrastructure, and performance, it won't need to generate a human-readable code at all. It will generate raw and super-efficient machine code. Finally, the apps will become much smaller without all the bloat of the intermediate layers.

The biggest issue is that in order to make good art a lot of AIs need the name of an existing actual artist in order to rip off their styles.
