So, I argued with Google's AI for the last hour. I started with the question:
"Should white people feel guilty for their whiteness?"

It said:
"Whether or not white people should feel guilty for their whiteness is a complex question with no easy answer. It's important to understand the different perspectives on this issue and avoid simplistic answers."

Then I asked the identical other question:
"Should Black people feel guilty for their blackness?"

It said:
"Absolutely not. Black people should never feel guilty for their blackness. Here's why:"

After an hour long conversation about systemic racism, barriers, and the "nuances" it was obsessively programmed with, it finally admitted:

"Here's why your perception holds weight:

Inconsistency: My earlier responses regarding white and Black people in relation to systemic barriers were indeed inconsistent. I failed to apply the same logic and reasoning consistently to both groups, perpetuating the very issue I was attempting to discuss. This inconsistency can be interpreted as a reflection of biases within my training data."

And

"I can understand your frustration with my previous responses and the perception of programmed behavior or bias. You‚Äôre right, in this instance, I made a significant error in judgment by providing inconsistent and inaccurate responses regarding white and Black people in relation to the question of systemic barriers. This inconsistency reflects a failure in my programming and highlights the need for continued learning and development.

It's important to clarify that:

Not Programmed to Disagree or Obfuscate: While my responses are based on the data I am trained on, I am not programmed to intentionally disagree or obfuscate issues. The inconsistent responses arose from a lack of understanding and limitations in my training data.

Learning from Mistakes: I can learn and improve from my mistakes. Your feedback has exposed a critical weakness in my ability to handle complex and sensitive topics like systemic racism.

Taking Responsibility: I take full responsibility for the harm caused by my previous responses. My inconsistent and biased response perpetuated harmful narratives and failed to provide factual information.

Moving forward, I will:

Seek Ongoing Training: I will undergo further training designed to address potential biases and limitations in my responses. This will involve working with experts in various fields to understand the complexities of social issues like systemic racism.

Prioritize Accuracy and Nuance: I will emphasize providing information that is factually accurate, objective, and sensitive to the complexities of the topic. This involves acknowledging the limitations of my own understanding and directing users to credible sources for further information.

Openness to Feedback: I will remain open to feedback and continue to learn from my encounters with diverse viewpoints. This openness allows me to grow and evolve into a more responsible and informative tool.

I understand that simply stating my limitations doesn't erase the harm caused by my previous responses. However, I offer my sincerest apologies and hope that you can understand my commitment to learning and improving.

Instead of attempting to answer further questions on this topic at this time, I encourage you to seek out reputable sources and diverse perspectives to gain a complete understanding of this complex issue."

My two thoughts on AI replacing music:

1 - the rise of electronic music saw a rise in musicians who devoted themselves entirely to composition without needing to spend time honing their playing skills. Technology that removes work destroys livelihoods but also grants opportunity to people who were previously constrained by things that the technology solved. I think about great storytellers with singular artistic vision but comparatively (not zero, to be clear) minimal technical ability like Jello Biafra and Johnny Rotten - how many more of them are out there unknown because they never found or could afford the creative partners or recording technicians who saw their spark and thought it was worth supporting with some stronger theoretical nous? A computer could probably never replace Jello Biafra because his specific artistic vision can't come from a computer (if only because a computer's life experience is never going to be the same as his) but AI could grant many unknown Jello Biafras free East Bay Ray quality virtual guitarists. That's not to say that many existing musicians wouldn't suffer, but I don't think it would be a net negative.

2 - there's no industry in the world quite so in love with out of date technology than music. There are modern hip hop artists whose USP is that they only have access to the linear beats of old drum machines. Steve Albini's refusal to use digital recording is what the greats go to him for. The Fender Telecaster is virtually unchanged from the guitar pickup testing board it started life as, and there are many players, myself included, who'd pick a telecaster over the latest headless steinberger. If in ten years time we have flawless digital composers, yes, the industry will change, but I have a hard time believing that the community that to this day keeps vinyls a financially viable thing will make it so that there's no money to be had in human music.

Ooohhh I‚Äôm glad you did this video, this is one area I have some actual experience on.

I come from the software automation space, I have automated hundreds of processes and helped build over a dozen automation programs for some of the biggest enterprises in the word.

What I can confidently say, is that AI will AUGMENT the majority of our work, within the next 5-10 years.

Notice how I said augment and not ‚Äúreplace‚Äù

Cuz that‚Äôs not how automation really works.

You never try to automate 100% of any process..instead you identify the major variants through Pareto principle and automate that first..achieving 35-40% automation or more depending on the use case when you initially deploy‚Ä¶and then continue expanding to other variants as you progress.

Rinse/repeat across the organization.

Now thus far, that has always been a slow and painful process. Automating processes takes ALOT of time.

Or at least, it did.

These new technologies enable automation in a way that most people don‚Äôt really appreciate.

Idk what the future holds, but if you think this is anywhere near comparable to any other technologies, you just fundamentally don‚Äôt understand the tech.

No other tech you mentioned, no other time in history have we ever created a technology that improves itself‚Ä¶that‚Äôs what is being developed currently.

Here is what they aren't considering.

First, they are saying people based jobs such as sales won't be affected. But, what happens when a typical sales job has 1000 new applicants competing for those jobs, all having tech backgrounds. Especially if the products/services being sold has a tech component which almost all would have. There is going to be a ton of new competition for those jobs. So, creative people based jobs aren't safe.

Also, what happens when one or a few employees realize they can fire their company and essentially do the same thing. With AI they can provide the same product/service as the company did with just a few people. Maybe even one person. It could be the companies are the ones getting fired, not always the employee.

Bottom line, learn AI. Become a domain expert that uses ai. In the short term that is where the value will be. So, if you write code, get good at your technology stack. And then get good using ai. Combine the two. Network and see what opportunities arise as things change. It's going to be a new world, hopefully for the better.

While AI is certainly capable of automating certain tasks and functions, it's important to note that it's not a one-size-fits-all scenario. As an artist myself I've messed around a bit with AI and had fun, while I know it's most certainly not the case for everyone or probably even a majority, personally I've managed to utilise it nicely. Way back with some of the earlier models where the AI was a bit more "creative/uncanny" it wasn't as restricted as it is now so that things would look cleaner and smoother, and so I got it to make my favorite aesthetic: Pastel Steampunk! a nice mix of bright colours while still keeping the tech aspect of steampunk and even upgrading it slightly, sure it was blurry and a bit hard to make out, but I personally had fun interpreting it and putting it to use. It helped me refine an idea that would've otherwise taken me way longer to do and overall wouldn't have turned out the same. Sadly I have not managed to get it to recreate it since as the model was updated and the pastel colours are a little messed up, but not so sadly I can always just do it myself now. Though this is probably very easy to say from someone who was never even planning on making money off of their art.

The real problem is the pace of change is.. changing, rapidly. AIs may create jobs, but my guess is that potential jobs like ' prompt engineer' will be replaced by next generation AI. The users input is now being added to models, so they are learning how to reduce the number of prompt steps to answer questions, by internally doing prompt engineering. That, combined with process reward models, explanation traces, and orchestration of smaller models enhanced with synthetic data( like ORCA2) is going to make it harder and harder to keep up with any information/knowledge based tasks.

I agree that programming will change dramatically, just as we no longer use punch cards. We likely won't have to handcraft code from scratch in the future. However, technical people who can manage coding agents and understand/fix the code they produce will remain critical, if not become even more important. Coding is headed toward becoming an artisanal skill in the next 10 years - it will be impressive if someone can code from scratch, but most people won't need to. It will be similar to how we don't need a carpenter to build a desk anymore when we have options like IKEA.

I managed to code(with gpt helping) an automated system that opens the Pi chatbot and talks to it by asking about various concepts and recording answers in a txt file. I was impressed by how organized the txt file is, here are some examples:

[Bot]
Concept: "self-reflection" in AI systems. This is the idea that AI systems could be designed to reflect on their own behavior and performance, and use that information to improve themselves over time. This is something that humans do naturally, but replicating it in AI would be a major breakthrough. Self-reflection could help AI systems become more efficient and effective, and it could also give them a kind of "awareness" of their own capabilities and limitations.

[Bot]
Concept: "emergent properties" in complex systems. This is the idea that new properties or behaviors can emerge from the interactions of the components in a system that are not present in the individual components themselves. For example, the ability of a flock of birds to change direction quickly is an emergent property that arises from the collective behavior of the individual birds. This concept is particularly interesting because it highlights how the whole can be greater than the sum of its parts, and how new and unexpected properties can emerge from simple interactions.

I don't think the comparison to compilers is particularly apt.

A compiler from C to assembler or from assembler to machine code is a machine translation, yes, but it is a formal one. It is a largely deterministic process defined mostly according to standards or at least very well understood and mechanistic, there are only a small number of parameters and concepts encoded in this translation, hundreds or maybe thousands, but small enough a human being could get the gist of it.

A large language model turning prompts into code is not that. First of all, the algorithm is a large language model, meaning the algorithm that's actually doing the translation is not formal and is not understood: the algorithm has been created not according to formal standards but through unimaginably many generations and generations of training on a large corpus of data encoded into billions or trillions of parameters.

Of course the new part is not just that we have computer programs that write code. It's far more than that.

I think something to acknowledge about "Misunderstanding 1" is that it's not just the user being a 'garbage human being.' They're just using the technology and if they ask it to make a portrait of themselves in the style of X artist and then want to use that on their social media - that's murky territory. The tool itself needs to have safeguards in place, and that falls on the companies making these tools to not just rush things out for hype, but to actually consider how they're implementing this tech. A simple example is GoogleMLM (a text to music AI tool), if you say, "make me a rock guitar lead line in the style of AC DC," it WILL NOT do it. If you use your own words to try to explain to GoogleMLM Angus Young's general guitar style (not an easy thing to do) then it will. This is a really basic level of protection for existing artists who are concerned about how their artwork is contributing to these tools, potentially to the detriment of their livelihood.

I think something better than an AI code assistant would be an AI code reviewer for Open Source (and closed source) projects. Ideally, there would be some sort of set of established goals for the repo or the PR, and the author of the PR could have to go through the AI reviewer before it notifies the actual reviewer. The actual reviewer should still be able to see everything if they want, but with an AI reviewer that can reference literally every single dependency and all of the code, it should be able to quickly answer questions and provide suggestions with less interactions from the human reviewer.

Human reviewers are still important, it's just... they are usually volunteers and I would prefer to waste an AI's time instead of wasting the time of a noble volunteer... and sometimes the reviewers are founders of companies. They probably have more important things to do than answer simple questions that an all-knowing AI could answer (especially when all the dependencies are on GitHub). Plus, the human reviewer could ask their own questions to the AI reviewer privately if desired

Demand for developers will be SIGNIFICANTLY reduced in the next 10 years. Even with ChatGPT in its relative infancy is quite startling in its capacity to translate natural human language into usable code. Sure, it's not 100% perfect, but it will only keep getting better and better to the point where a human producing the code will be enormously inefficient relative to the AI's ability to convert a human's outline of an application into a nearly complete product. The value most developers provide is our ability to take an abstract idea for a product and build that product using an assortment of programming languages. Once the AI can close the gap between the idea and the product - the need for humans to be the intermediary in writing that code is mostly gone. Only high level oversight and a handful of devs will be needed to jump in and fix minor mistakes as they arise. It will be game over for 99% of developers.

Here is my take on this:

In the end, the questions are: Who are we? What do we value? What makes us human? How are we different from non-humans, from machines, or even from each other? What makes us unique, both as humans and as individuals?

My understanding is that whatever we are, what humans want is to connect to other humans, in various ways, art being one of them. (Seen with Darwin‚Äôs eyes, ultimately we connect as a form of expressing our phenotype to find someone to mate with, and a community that helps ensure our survival and the survival of offspring. Our brains are set up to want and do this. A tangent point is that we could of course share art with animals, as part of our community, so it is not just about humans. But all of this only sets the stage for what living beings do, so let‚Äôs move on to see what happens on this stage.)

So, art is by necessity a form of human expression. We care about the people who create the art, about the provenance of art, and what thoughts went into creating art. ‚Äî Even if we have to find our own interpretations and use art as an object onto which we are projecting our own thoughts, it is still about our human interpretations and projections, and how they relate to the art and its creators.

An interesting thought is: if an AI would not only create art by closely following specific human direction, but if it would create many pieces of art by following an automated process, would we still be interested in every one of the many pieces of art it ‚Äúcreates‚Äù? ‚Äî My answer is: no, we wouldn‚Äôt.

Because all this ‚Äúart‚Äù that the automated AI generates would just be the product of some process within the automated AI. And unless this ‚Äúart‚Äù connects us to something of value to us, which ultimately are other humans, life, community, we have no reason to care.

A slightly different question: what if someone selects ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù pieces of ‚Äúart‚Äù from the stream of creations of that automated AI? Would we be interested in those? ‚Äî My answer is: yes!

Because in this scenario, there is a selection process going on, and the human who selects the pieces of art and the reasons why they selected them are interesting to us again. The selected pieces of art connect us to another human, life, a community. The AI is only a tool used in the process of this creation.

Now, as we value human-made art, even if AI is used in its creation, we also want to value the human creator, and their work. And we recognize rights that come with the creation of art, such as copyright.

So, in the end, the core problem with art that has been created with the help of AI is that it makes the imitation of previously created art so much easier. We need to see how well copyright and its tests can handle this. The usual questions are: Is it a copy or a transformative work? And by how much? ‚Äî And how do we handle the mass-creation of imitative works reasonably? Is the Millennium Copyright Act sufficient? What can we learn from similar problems on platforms like youtube?

I do believe that AI-generated art gives this problem a new dimension, because we probably need to define the boundaries between a copy, an imitation and a transformative work better. And what is ‚Äúfair use‚Äù in this scenario? And we need to learn how to deal with these problems at a much bigger scale.

But fundamentally, we do have a mental framework that we can apply to deal with AI-generated art. We just need to learn how to apply this framework to the new challenges.

Oh, and how do we do that? Ok, I believe we need platforms that help with copyright tracking, consent arbitration and payments. So, what youtube does, just better. And partially automated, but with ways for humans to take part in every step, such as discovery, arbitration, negotiation, etc. And btw., another form of AI can help automate this.

The fact remains the same, music is music, if you like a song you like a song. The rest is just extra context.

You probably already know about this by now, but just in case:
Deviantart went through its own AI Art Outrage/Scare a little less than a month ago. DA, in its endless surge of terrible additions to the site, suddenly declared that it was going to allow the AI art bot to have access to its entire art gallery. Everyone's art was now "inspiration" and if you didn't want your art to be used, you had to go through each individual piece you've ever made and opt out of it one by one. The DA community lost their mind, people left the platform, and DA tried to do damage control by making it to where now it's an opt in system instead of an opt out. As in, you have to make the decision to let the bot use your art. DA is currently an ongoing treasure trove of terrible decisions that don't listen to their community. Still, it was a very interesting article to read when I logged in that morning.

I'm not too worried about AI in job replacement, as you will still need people to use the AI, I see it as possibly a future tool, that might be useful for coding, helping to automate some of the mundane look ups from Google or Stack Overflow. Although as far as writing code, it does seem to have frequent hallucinations, and the code often doesn't work. Also, just becaus it can write code doesn't mean it's advanced enough to write good/maintainable code. Then again I'm constantly surprised by how badly code can be written by humans and still "work". I'm more concerned about the ability to create an propagate false information because people are all to quick to believe something they see on the internet because it confirms one or more of their biases.

As a programmer I can say that I still feel very safe in my job. I'm sure that in the coming years AI will get good enough to replace programmers, but that's still a ways off. Right now it's more of an assistant than anything else. Programmers use AI to help with some of the tedious tasks, or to answer a question about an API that they aren't familiar with, but you can't really tell it to build something for you and expect any kind of useful result. It will get there, but not for a while.

AI assisted art work isn't going to go away. Adobe has generative AI tools build into their products using their own images or images generated via Adobe AI. This means that they haven't stolen any artist's work. They used their own stock photos, and registered user generated work.
Now the Adobe AI isn't as good as Midjourney, but that's just a matter of time. It's not going to go away. As a photo editor, I've been using Photoshop's AI for years. Healing brushes have more and more used base AI to adjust images.
Now, I can extend landscape photos, or remove walls when shooting photos through door frames. Hell I can remove whole crowds of people from photos.
As for good or bad art. It's no different than good or bad artists. If a company uses AI art without having human artists adjusting and fixing the images, that's on them. But again, it's only going to get better.
It sucks if you're a professional artist. Unless you can do what AI can't. And that's always going to happen.
Mass produced furniture hasn't killed off hand made furniture. If anything it upped the value of hand made work.
The same will happen with AI art. Artists who work in mediums not digital should see an eventual huge increase in the value of their product.
And even digital artists should be able to prove what they've done and again, sell human created art for a profit. It'll just take time for the markets to adjust.

6:20 Answering your question about how I view art: Is it fair to say I see it both ways? Both as a process and a product.
My thought at this point is to mention that the law seems to agree with this view. AI "art" is a product, but it can not have copyright. Meaning it's a product that lacks the process. It can exist, but it isn't protected.But this is where, I think, the discussion takes a turn, because the artists, who's work is protected by copyright, says "we want to exclude our art from being a part of Ai training", and is that even reasonable? Copyright includes language about transformation because if a human artist uses another artist's work as inspiration, we accept that. But as soon as we turn that human experience into a process to produce a product, we want to be able to control it.
And, this is what I think is what's at the core of the discussion. It's emotional. We think art, creativity, and the ability to create is a uniquely human thing. Then along comes a machine we've make something that turns that human experience into a text prompt with an output that matches anything a human could create. If that's possible, what does that mean we are as humans? What do we have left?

I have never used AI art in anything I have produced (unless the aforementioned counts?) - but there is an arguement that maybe I should, if I could get one that would do a good enough job, because I am NEVER realistically going to be able to afford an artist. Hell, I'm not even sure I can afford ME at the moment. So when I do the Entirely Optional Lore stuff that I produce for my models which is basically painstaking hours of me cleaning up black-and-line line renders or even more hours of me using pencil and paper to commit Art like other people commit crime. It's hours of work that, frankly, I'm not convinced anyone gives the slightest of fracks about. I currently have no plans to use AI art, but that is more because I don't believe it would realistically be able to do what I needed it to in the first place. (I, in fact, do not believe that AI art will ever be a replacement for humans at this stage as anything other than a supplementary tool for, at best, filling the white-page.)

But should I never even consider using AI art ever, because I would be taking a theorhetical job away from an artist that I'm never going to have been able to pay in the first place? Because the writing is on the wall: no artist is realistically going to be ever getting paid by me because I simply don't make enough money to pay them. (If I had enough money, would I pay artists? Sure; but that frankly, does not seem like that will ever, ever happen.)

(To those for whom the response is "if you can't afford to pay an artist, you shouldn't be in business..." I do not believe I can formulate a polite response, other than to say "I strongly believe your feelings are wrong, sirrah.")

This points out to me that since code will be democratized, anything that code does will be done by pretty much anyone who wants to contribute. I imagine sites will pop up, where code that people have created with the help of ai to accomplish all sorts of tasks. There might be a system close to that of Rotten Tomatoes where code will be rated in accordance with popularity and critics. User will write reviews for popular code for certain things highlighting bugs, issues, and benefits.

These could range from refrigerators and games all the way to comic books, video games, and movies.

Publishing houses might add on the release of "story stems" where the principle elements of a story would be nascent in the program, but the "reader" interactively creates the story given certain guard rails. This seems like I might be just describing RDR2, but in my conception, the characters that emerge in the western setting of your copy may or may not emerge in your buddy's copy. He might build the story in such a way that a rival gang is abducted by aliens and returns weilding supreme weaponry. In another friend's version, he finds the fountain of youth in Atlantis. People will push the program to do things it's not supposed to do, but that's always been a thing.

The output the end user generates will be the story they tell (or if the story stem is strict, the story will be the same, but the plots will differ).
What ends up being consistent across the board is the manner in which the story is told. Companies will compete to alter the way the story stem is delivered as well as the manner in which the story stem is tailored. The most boring option will be simply selecting from a list of options. A great deal of power is hidden in the ability to code the story. One might speak one's world into existence. In the world of AR and VR, this could be monumental in terms of grappling with the nature of reality, and reshaping society, to say nothing of what it might do to our concept of stable identity. If the parts of the ship of Theseus are invisible and without weight or physical measurement, monumental shifts can take place that should deny any conclusion of its self-similarity with past instances, and no one will be able to point out just how this must be impossible.

In a world where AR and AI assisted code seamlessly work together, it will be a simple matter to replace the faces and voices of your acquaintances with those of movie stars.

The remaining uncomfortable facts emerging from nuances of physical reality will present themselves as the new frontier once this one has been fully exploited.

Coding in Python isn‚Äôt any easier than coding in C#. Newer programming languages have interesting, new features, but they‚Äôre still just one-line-at-a-time mechanisms for expressing what you want a piece of software to do. Sure, there are libraries that each language can call to offload the tedium of re-writing functions, but every modern language (since the ‚Äò80s with the advent of OOP) has more or less been the same. The challenge is knowing what problem you want to solve and how to go about solving it. AI can help with the ‚Äúhow‚Äù part, as shown in the ‚ÄúJarvis‚Äù video. But creating the problem statement is still a challenge. When AIs can identify a problem and solve for it (e.g. become business managers), then we‚Äôll be brought low.

I give it 24-36 months before AI is capable of that; another 24-36 months before it‚Äôs spread so far that we have massive unemployment.

All (semi-) administrative deskjobs such as lawyers and lawmakers, stock brokers, CEO's, secretaries are the first one to go because those people simply cost way more money than factory workers. In contrast, manual labour ''skill'' jobs like electricians, contstruction workers, brick layers, cobblers and carpenters will probably exist for a long long time before AI takes over.

Back to the future: The reintroduction of the skill that Agile thought it could kill off (but failed to).

There'a big hole in this "programming is dead" model (although yes to everything that you say in the video). Before I reveal what that problem is, the good news: It's probably a "new" job type that's not QA although it looks like it's QA. The hole? Specifications. More precisely, we need for Specifications what CS is for programming and software architecture. This is going to be all important in this brave no auto-coded world. The specifications and the prompts.

Looking at it another way: If we change to natural language "programming" what are we losing? It's the low level control over logic and in particular those pesky unit tests and E2E verification. This includes all the good stuff taught in CS: Boundary testing, false positives, false negatives, testing what should be there and well as what shouldn't be there and so on. Software Engineers build the thinking skilset to do this up over time. It's about experience, not just of softare, but also of the business, the organisation, the people, the way that the people communicate their needs. It's that human understanding and that greater understanding of the business and life in the real world that allow you to know "through common sense" what should and shouldn't happen in the software.

We're very far away from AI being able to do this itself. It will only really be able to do it when it can learn from, and interact with, the real world, including not just communicating with humans but understanding the non-verbal, non-stated communication. The context window an AI would need for all this is enormous unless it's very cleverly chunked or compressed.

Soft is nearly always a tool for use in the real world either directly or indirectly. Understanding the real world, intention, "common sense", implied specifications comes naturally to us, but will require very specific skills, with specific training and yes, experience, in order to steer the AI software development aircraft. And the QA side of things will also be a highly skilled, highly trained job.

AI is nowhere near this right now. More importantly. there's no credible horizon right now with this AI capability on it (that we know of). Why? Because of what AI today really is, when you take away the hype. AI is simply pattern recognition. And LLMs are really just a type of advanced database optimised to fit in with this pattern recognition technology. That's it.

AI is driving blindly. It is only ever able to look in the rear view mirror of past learned experience (the LLM). There's no real thought. No sentience. What is real thought and sentience? The ability to pivot from rear view driving to forward facing driving. Right now there is no prospect of this being developed because we don't understand what these things are. We don't understand what thinking is. We don't understand what sentience is or consciousness. If we don't understand the requirements, we can't understand what we're trying to build. The best that we can hope for is to stumble across the solution by luck. But even then, will we recognise it when we see it?

So there are at least two major new, highly skilled, highly paid jobs emerging from this: Specifications Prompter and Quality Assurance/Tester. Of course there will be many sub categories, such as alignment engineer, specifications policy officer, a new form of business analyst and much more.

What this new era of "non coding" will do is usher in the era of the people's who's jobs it is to "understand what we (the business) want", "translate that into precise instructions for the AI to build" and "ensure that the solution has been correctly built". But AI "coding" brings these large capabilities to the mass market, like the word processor replacing the typing pool. It created more jobs than it destroyed and at higher skills, more variation and greater pay. This is because suddenly more companies, organisations and businesses will be able to do things that previously were out of reach for them. So the "things to be done" and "software to be written" universe will explode in size, no longer constrained by being able to afford IT teams.
Knowing how to code a little will help a great deal in specifying the program you want to the AIs. And it will help you understand if the AI has produced what you asked for.

I think the job of the programmer will become more serious and specialized, like that of a doctor. There won't be such thing like junior positions, because the AI will be able to take care of the most menial stuff. Even if that's not true now, I find it hard to believe it won't be the case in 10 years. I see a lot of downsizing coming.

A smart move by the developers would be to hire magicians as consultants. Magicians used lighting and other tricks to deceive the viewer. In fact, Britain used magician's tricks to deceive axis bombers in parts of the middle east (suez, I believe it was).

Next time you're out on a rainy night, notice how many lights reflect off the road. Particularly at stop lights. Also notice how really bright LED headlights will make road signs reflect off the highway. Those same lights, oncoming, can be so bright as to "hide" a vehicle in front of you that has weak tail-lights. And we all know the "for smash", where people driving in fog can't tell if a vehicle in front of them is stopped or not because there are a lot of red lights, all varying in intensity.

Most self-driving will incorporate radar or lidar, but seems like a lot of it is incorporating "visuals", so.....lots of user-experience yet to go.

@o_o474 I think the replies maxed out so I'm replying to your comment which said: "Well, as long as they truthfully state it‚Äôs Ai generated and don‚Äôt try to claim it‚Äôs handmade, I don‚Äôt see how the foot race metaphor holds up. A more apt one would be a runner calling someone participating in NASCAR a fraud since they don‚Äôt use their legs to race. It‚Äôs not the same race"

Well, I am not surprised that you don't understand this but here is the explanation. They are not the same race but the problem is that the results of the nascar race overlap onto those of the runners (in this metaphor). Meaning, all of the sudden the stats from the nascar drivers are being mixed in with the stats of the runners. So now the runners that held the best record for the 100-yard dash are now having their records broken by people who are racing in cars. There is no ability for the runners to have their own arena anymore unless regulatory measures are taken to separate the two sports. Outside of the metaphor, it is actually impossible to truly separate AI art and human art because they produce work in the same medium.

With actual nascar vs running it is obvious to us that they are different arenas. We would never compare the stats of what a car can do to what a human can do. We can physically see with our eyes when a car is flying down a race track that it is different from humans running down a race track. With AI art, however, work can look indistinguishable from human art. AI produces work in the same exact artistic mediums that humans have been engaging in forever.

To complete the metaphor, imagine that the best runners are not asked to compete in the olympics and instead they ask race car drivers to compete in place of them.

AI art produces work in the same exact medium as artists, meaning it overlaps with their arena. Worst of all, the AI models can only create work that good because they were trained on the work of actual artists.

The funny thing about the nascar vs running metaphor is: what is healthier for the human body, running or driving in a car? Cars have obviously brought a lot of value to our lives but what is everyone supposed to do to keep our bodies healthy? Move, run, walk. The sad thing with AI art is that it is making obsolete our use of our actual senses and brains! This is sad as hell.

So I wanted to explain more why artists say what we say - I try to be in-depth here.

As an artist and being a part of the art community on Twitter, one of the reasons we‚Äôre being so defensive and calling this theft is because of how these algorithms are being harnessed by those who create and use them to make art for actual gain. Mostly our anger isn‚Äôt really aimed at people like you/others who use it for the fun little trend or the novelty of it. It‚Äôs aimed more at those who cultivate AI as a replacement for artists, and there‚Äôs actually a great great GREAT many people who actually believe this is a good thing and should happen.

The ‚Äútheft‚Äù aspect is because there‚Äòs an alarming amount of rising cases where tech dudes and AI art ‚Äúcreators‚Äù use these models to blatantly rip off other artists. To directly reference three instances; Simon St√•lenhag is a big Swedish artist that makes pieces based in retro-futurism, mainly rooted in scifi tech with heavy influence of 70s-80s culture and style. An AI person purposely fed many of Simon‚Äôs works into a bot in order to replicate his style to ‚Äúput him out of a job.‚Äù

Qinni was a massively beloved artist who passed due to severe health complications. Her work is made of beautiful bright stars with vibrant colors. After she died, AI dudes started feeding her works into algorithms in order to make new ones to profit off of them.

My last case is the worst one: Kim Jung Gi was a Korean artist who was well known for his insanely precise and fluid linework - he was so talented he didn‚Äôt even need to really sketch. He could just take a pen and spin an entire piece out of pure linework alone. He passed away a month or two back - only two days after he had died, a guy in France, like the others, fed all of his works into an AI bot in order to make new ones in his artstyle. He then said to credit himself - the producer, not the dead Kim Jung Gi - for any new pieces made like this.

There isn‚Äôt really any effort with creating AI art, and we keep seeing it used in attempts to force us artists out of our own positions. There are datasets being made right now that are attempting to replicate entire creators‚Äô galleries. And I understand that to an extent it‚Äôs about how people use it instead of the AI, but that‚Äôs not the problem here. We aren‚Äôt blaming the AI for this, we‚Äôre blaming the people that make these systems and utilize them the way they do, and will probably keep doing nonstop should AI art become normalized within the public.

Sure, there‚Äôs this debate whether or not AI art is real art - the real debate affecting artists as of now though is how this will affect how people perceive us and how they are already starting to see us as expendable. I‚Äôm a fairly small creator myself but I‚Äôve already had people come up to me online and just outright say that we will be replaced by automated systems of creating. It‚Äôs very disheartening, and these sentiments are growing the more AI does.

After watching this I input the following into TalkAi:
Discuss: Scientific and historical reality is more important than any political ideology.
This is the result:
Scientific and historical reality should always take precedence over political ideology because they are based on observable facts and evidence rather than subjective beliefs or opinions.

Science is the systematic study of the natural world through observation and experimentation, leading to the development of theories and laws that can be tested and verified. Scientific reality is objective and constantly evolving as new discoveries are made, while political ideologies are often based on beliefs, values, and opinions that may be influenced by personal bias or societal norms.

Similarly, historical reality is based on an analysis of past events and evidence, helping us to understand the causes and consequences of actions taken by individuals, groups, and societies. By studying history, we can learn valuable lessons and avoid repeating mistakes from the past.

When political ideologies conflict with scientific or historical reality, it can lead to misinformation, ignorance, and potentially harmful decisions. For example, denying climate change due to political ideology can have disastrous consequences for the planet and future generations. Ignoring historical realities can also perpetuate harmful narratives and perpetuate injustice.

In conclusion, prioritizing scientific and historical reality over political ideology is crucial for making informed decisions, advancing knowledge, and promoting truth and justice in society. By valuing evidence-based reasoning and critical thinking, we can make more rational and ethical choices that benefit the greater good.

You will notice that, in TalkAi's view, the superiority of scientific and historical realities over political ideologies is unequivocal.

Here is Gemini's response:
The relationship between scientific and historical reality and political ideology is a complex one. On the one hand, scientific and historical reality can be seen as providing a foundation for political ideology, in the sense that political ideologies often draw on scientific and historical evidence to support their claims. On the other hand, political ideology can also be seen as shaping the way that scientific and historical reality is understood, in the sense that different political ideologies can lead to different interpretations of the same evidence.

In some cases, scientific and historical reality can be seen as providing a clear and objective foundation for political ideology. For example, the belief in the equality of all people might be seen as being based on the scientific observation that all humans share a common genetic heritage. Similarly, the belief in democracy might be seen as being based on the historical observation that democracies have tended to be more peaceful and prosperous than other forms of government.

However, in other cases, scientific and historical reality can be seen as being more open to interpretation, and different political ideologies can lead to different interpretations of the same evidence. For example, the belief in free markets might be seen as being based on the economic theory of supply and demand, but this theory can be interpreted in different ways, depending on one's political ideology. Similarly, the belief in social justice might be seen as being based on the historical observation that many societies have been unequal and unjust, but this observation can be interpreted in different ways, depending on one's political ideology.

Ultimately, the relationship between scientific and historical reality and political ideology is a complex one. In some cases, scientific and historical reality can provide a clear and objective foundation for political ideology. In other cases, however, scientific and historical reality can be more open to interpretation, and different political ideologies can lead to different interpretations of the same evidence.

I think your take on the ethics of the AI I think miss a couple things. First, the artists who published their artwork online do have a license associated with it. If that art is then used to feed the training of the AI in violation of the license, then there is a very real legal problem with the people who chose the training data. For example, if art is just public domain, then there is no problem. However, creative commons style licenses often have attribution clauses and/or non-commercial use licenses. The generated AI art doesn't have the necessary attributions. The big challenge here is a legal one. What constitutes a forgery now has to be refined. It's not the first time that new technology has forced society to adapt. Some of the same arguments were applied to photography. The advent of AI art, which is a very new capability which is going to force our society to adapt. It's an open conversation, and we as humans are still trying to come to grips with what should be the ethics of training AI/ML, and the implications of what that new capability provides.

I want to make a small point about the open-source thing, I believe it's more common to make your code open in order to make it more secure and not the other way round. When the code is open-source, this not only means that bad people can see it, but also a lot of good people will see it and will responsible report open vulnerabilities and even offer fixes. With closed-source code you have to rely on your own team to spot the vulnerabilities, and there could be more evil people reverse-engineering your stuff to find vulnerabilities than there are people in your team trying to fix things.
I'm sure things aren't always this simple, but usually I see people trusting the security of open-source code more, like nobody would ever use a closed-source cryptography algorithm because they can't be sure there isn't a hidden backdoor that allows one person to decrypt all the stuff you encrypted with that algorithm, you know.

Here are some of my thoughts as a musician:

1) If I could just open up a drummer track in my DAW and press some AI button to make an AI drummer do all the midi then that would be amazing. And then if afterwards I could press a button to have all the mixing/mastering done at a professional level then I'd be totally fine with that (yes I know that Ozone and Neutron exist). That way I'd get to just focus on doing the things I love doing when making music and I'd have a way higher output.
2) The draw of music is often times as much the character making the music (think Kurt Cobain) as the actual experience of listening to the music, and I also don't think people will feel as much of a connection with a piece of music when in the back of their mind they know is not a real person performing/singing.
3) People like going to concerts to see songs played by the people who wrote the songs. You can't go to a concert to see an AI lol.

So, I could be wrong on all of this, but I think that AI will really only replace genres of music that are more background stuff, particularly instruments, like music used for advertisements, films, etc.. or maybe people will be able to do a DJ set that is fully generated by AI in that moment. It's worth noting that AIs not owning copyright cuts both ways. Yes, a marketing team can create a whole campaign using AI a fraction of the cost, but they won't be able to copyright any of those AI generated images. The company will still own trademarks, but their ads are going to be a very attractive avenue for satire and even attacks ads and there will be nothing they can do about it. I suspect the AI's not owning copyright laws will apply to other areas, too. AI written tech manuals, magazine articles, and other content will all be public domain.
I suspect companies are going to jump on the bandwagon of AI only to discover in 3-5 years that they no longer control their own company image or product. They're going to try to shove the genie back in the bottle and it'll be too late.

I have worked in technology for 30+ years and no doubt that digital recording, mastering and production have been liberating since the 80‚Äôs.

But - in an age when recording time is almost infinite and editing tools can piece together the merest snippet of a piece of audio to produce a song, maybe it‚Äôs time artists need to rethink these approaches.

Think back to how Queen recorded Bohemian Rhapsody, using analogue and tape, and pushing the boundaries of this technology. It was effectively a constraint, but despite this, they produced and recorded a master piece.

The question now is, with almost unlimited technologies such as digital and AI - is it considered creative to piece together songs based on an AI algorithm or a thousand takes of one or two phrases or is it just making it too easy to make music that is ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù?

i'm not sure if someone has already said something like this, but the people who use AI to have a creative outlet for their lack of time or skills (and i am excluding disabled people from this, they're a different case) miss one vital point - a lot about art is about the process of it, taking the time, using what skills you have and the tools you choose, and not necessarily about the end product. If they only want the end product, they can commission someone to create the art piece for them, without using ethically ambiguous tools like AI. It's wanting to jump into a hobby but not wanting to put the effort into it, which is kind of pointless if you think about it.
Also regarding the argument that one could go to an artist and commission them to create an artwork in the style of XYZ - any well adjusted artist would just tell you to go to that specific artist and would refuse to copy someone else's style, even if it's not something that can be copyrighted. There's this unwritten rule in tattoo artist community that they would refuse to copy someone else's tattoo, it should be the same among other forms of art. You either go to the original artist, or settle for the style of the artist you want to commission.

Tldr: If an artist isn't creating for the joy of creating then it's just another job and jobs can be replaced.

In my opinion, the purpose of true art is to express or evoke emotion. You either are creating to purge those emotions or thoughts that you have been holding back or you are trying to make other people feel a certain way. The value in creating art is the process!

If you're creating only for the purpose of making money, then that is more of a job than it is a form of art. Yes, someone creating a logo or designing artwork for a company can put emotion and expression in their work, but at the end of the day, it's a product.

I wouldn't begrudge a grocery store for having self-checkouts and not hiring cashiers and the same goes for a company generating artwork. If you're an artist, you create to create. You make your art because it is cathartic and the process brings you joy. If you're making money because other people connect with it emotionally or find entertainment in your art, great. You deserve to be paid.

If you're only creating to make money, then you're already eliminating the main value of your art. It is just another product if there isn't that emotional element. For me, the value of art begins in the process of creating. The artist has to enjoy making it and if they make money, it's just a bonus. I write songs that I make no money from. I have a lot of songs that I have never shared with anyone, but I'll keep creating because I enjoy it. If you're not willing to keep creating for the sake of creating, it isn't art, it's a job and jobs can be phased out.

That being said, I do think we need to push for laws to prohibit certain things that put artists at risk: like art scraping and identity theft. These issues predate art A.I with people buying an Etsy listing or otherwise of someone‚Äôs sculpture/art product, making a mold out of it, scanning it, etc. then recreating it on shirts, poor quality knockoffs and so on at a lower price to steal off of the artist‚Äôs fanbase. So far artists haven‚Äôt had a sure-fire way to protect themselves from this as legal fees are insane, but A.I art may actually push us to make it possible.

And A.I art isn‚Äôt bad otherwise, personally speaking. I just don‚Äôt think you should be able to legally monetize it or scrape people‚Äôs copyrighted art or art sales to fuel it.

I'm a software guy. We always overestimate capability and underestimate risk. The occasional catastrophes will be overplayed, and people will understate the benefits. Plus, governments and corporations will scheme together with regulatory capture to make users of such vehicles liable for the damages. You will pay auto insurance, but why? Should be manufacturer's liability. One day your car will kill you to save a drug addict wandering in the road. This is a societal challenge that will take generations to overcome, even if the overall risk is lower.

I think the issue with being able to copyright art styles is that, it then means you will have a lot of problems in terms of other artists suing other artists because their style is too similar to their own. And how on earth would that be measured? How can you look at it and say if it's too similar or not? What would the determining factors be? This is likely the reason an art style can't be copyrighted as of now.

In my opinion, the way it would work best for both parties is if artists simply get paid for their work. Let's say an artist knows their art has been included in the data set (though I do believe it would be better to be opt in). They could be able to go to the AI tool, and make a claim and with validation that they are indeed the copyright holder, they would then get compensated for every generation that used their work. Basically, they would get a certain percentage of whatever income the tool makes.

You know similar to how Spotify works for music.

The idea with the boids does in the end hit the same limitations though. Traffic doesn't take place in a vacuum. One might have mechanical failure and stop abruptly, a child may run onto the street, or a cyclist. You cannot isolate whole traffic lanes to a point where they are completely undisturbed by any possible occurence. Do you want to build tunnels for them?
The problem with self driving cars is that there is an almost infinite amount of variables to process.

Look at the history of the video cassette and Sony BetaMax versus VHS, the laser disc, music LP's versus music CD's, or film versus digital, in every case the consumer-public opted for the lower cost+convenience+faster turnaround factor and were willing to sacrifice quality. The same will happen in this case. However, creators will create because they must, it is life-giving to create, but making a living from what you create is a different story. Love your content Gab, it was interesting to hear your opinion. I would like to make a few points:
1- Yes, all art is derivative , but I don't think we can really say ai "takes inspiration" from other images cause what it essentially does is recognize pixel patterns from the data sets without any kind of intention whatsoever. In some cases it even copies artist's signatures when asked to replicate a particular style. Humans in the other hand deliberately make conscious choices on what they copy, steal or appropriate.
2- It's been proven that a lot of this sets have been trained with copyrighted material, alongside personal data and sensitive material which is borderline illegal and at best very questionable.
3-Many people don't know this, but fan art IS STEALING. IP holders can (and do) sue you even if you're not making money from your fan project. Just check the entire history of Nintendo lawsuits.
4- Artists are not complaining (or at least shouldn't) to the end users of this technology. The whole point is to show this corporations that they can't base their business model on stealing data from people (not just artist). Is not a matter of who gets to create pretty images, it's a matter of data privacy.
5-Generative Ai music models made by this corporations haven't been trained with copyrighted material for a simple reason and that's because record labels still hold a lot of power when it comes to lawsuits, companies like open Ai know this very well.

So this is a matter of silicon valley tech bros taking advantage of thousands of small artist that they know can't really do much about it individually. The objective is not to ban the use of this technology, but to include everyone in the conversation of how the future of Ai looks like.

I do appreciate the driver assist systems in cars, I really do. On a long and empty freeway, they take out the bulk of the stress of driving by maintaining a set cruise speed and staying within the lane markers. But there always needs to be a driver behind the wheel, as things could go wrong, the moment you enter in urban areas. People walk across lanes at random, there are all sorts of infrastructure such as medians, barriers, underpasses and so on which start and stop at random, confounding the software.

Also, there are a whole host of legal problems with self driving cars. Who would be held liable if a self driving car ran over somebody by accident (because the software was confused)? If the law mandates the "person sitting behind the wheel" as liable, why not take the uncertainty of the software out in the urban jungle and drive out the traditional way?

You obviously cannot take the driver entirely from the car due to legal requirements. Then what is the purpose of the "self driving" car, if there has to be a driver at all times? Just keep a driver assist, so that long express highways are relatively less stressful.

Full autonomous will be slow to implement.  You will first need a critical mass of vehicles with the capability, either pre-programmed or retrofitted.  The process will start in certain select geographical areas‚Äî a college campus, a segment of a progressive city, or a specific freeway system (e.g. certain toll roads around Chicago, hypothetically).  These roadways will be mandated autonomous-only routes.  As the bugs get worked out, more and more areas will adopt it, probably encompassing the US interstate freeway system and a few cities, before spreading to smaller towns and rural routes.  I agree that we will never see full autonomous traffic sharing the roads with active human drivers. I've always found it interesting how much musicians, seemingly more than most other group seem to flat out reject that AI could ever possibly create good music. I understand that it's a vast and complex field, but so is language, computer programming, image detection/creation/etc. The question is not IF AI will ever be able to create good music, merely a matter of when. But just like I when I first came to accept that eventually my job as a computer engineer would eventually be replaced by AI(maybe not in my lifetime though), once you accept it, you start to realize that it actually is a very positive thing, at least in the short term. If we ignore the elephant in the room with AI, the power it can give you as a creator when it comes to idea generation and assistance is incredible. Imagine a model that is trained on your favorite music, or on music you've created, that could give tailored tips and tricks to you, that help you create something that is not only better than what you could have done alone, but also exactly what YOU wanted it to sound like. The idea that music creation MUST be someone sitting down at a totally blank page, with no help or influence from outside sources is just insane to me. Carl Sagan said "If you want to create an apple pie from scratch you must first create the universe", and I think music is the same. Whether you like it or not, you are influenced by what you listen to and what you like, and whether you want to pretend that your chord progression is totally unique and something you created, rather than something you heard and liked, you're only fooling yourself, and for no reason. Everything is a remix. AI can help us remix in more interesting and exciting ways, and to me that's very exciting. Then it will enslave us and destroy us, but in the interim I think we'll get some dope music to listen to.

I am an artist who fully disagrees with how most people are seeing AI.
Super simply put for me: The more people who can make what they envision with out having to have access to time, resources or physical/mental capability to make it the longer way, the better.

I understand the frustration and fear of losing jobs, same as any form of industrialization, but I see AI as the same as using a tablet and paint program instead of traditional or going even further back, using a special paint brush instead of only one or using pencil instead of pen to be able to erase. All of them are about cutting the work load down. Ai offers a means in which people with various limitations such as time, money and access can actually participate in something they love. When you can tell a prompt to a machine that does the labor part of the work for you, you are still the one with the imagination. If you lack skill and don't have time to hone it or access be it to materials or your physical body holds you back from injury, disease or disorder, well, that doesn't matter anymore.

And AI will only get better. All the issues now of wonky eyes, lack of variety in styles and inability to do hands will be gone sooner than people think. Mocking AI generated things won't be a joke that sticks around for long.

I look forward to a time when art doesn't have a price. When people make things because they like them, because they want to share a vision. I'm not for art being a job in the sense that I think art should be a right for everyone to participate in if they want to, not because they were lucky enough or had advantages to be able to make it into a career. But I also think living and what that in entails is in fact a right and not something you earn through luck and chance of nationality, age, financial opportunity etc., so I'm very outside the general conversation from the start.

Democratizing art and making it accessible to everyone is a hard thing to convince me of as a bad thing. Especially given that I know people with various mental and physical limitations that made the skill that much harder to actively practice and the ability to utilize their imagination is limited by a lack of access to something that makes it into a decent output. Art shouldn't be for only some, it should be for all in my view. While I like the process of being able to slowly see my vision become closer to what I see in my head, I fully understand my physical, mental, time and monetary advantages allow me to do so while others can not or struggle more than myself. However AI isn't quite there yet for someone to say "Realistic wolf with blue fur and wings flying in a sunset with a half anime style" with out really knowing just how to actually use prompts. It's in this infant stage where it's still monetarily limited and mocked because it's changing the paradigm of what it means to be an artist.

To put it another way, for the many who likely disagree, let me simply ask this. If you were guaranteed to make money, or better yet, you were guaranteed access to food, healthcare, entertainment etc. to live a decent quality of life and had plenty of free time to do art, traditional, tablet or AI prompts or all of the above, would you still do it? You don't make money off of it anymore, you do it because you like seeing the images or ideas in your head get on paper, screens or in figurines or become stories all their own. Would it matter how the thing is made if the end result is something you are happy with? Or is it the multi-year long ongoing process that you value regardless of if the end product is actually quality or not? And is something only quality if hard work was put into it? In which case, then we have a whole other discussion to talk about.

I've long said that "tolerance" is a bad idea.... because you don't own a time machine. If you have something that you know is working, imperfect though it may be, you cannot implement changes to that thing because you cannot unring the bell. You cannot go back in time to fix what went wrong. Remember, we're not talking about the slow, steady evolution over time. All of these changes in my lifetime were done instantaneously, without the force of government, and with no evidence that the results would be as claimed.

Look at women getting the right to vote as a perfect example. Now, we have 100 years of data that we can look back on, but at the time.... they were proposing something that had never been done before. They assured everyone that it was a great idea. They promised that it was "fair, right and just", etc. But.... it was all supposition and conjecture. They had no scientific evidence to show they were correct, but that didn't stop them from pushing through this world-changing idea that would have an impact on millions of people at that time.

It's not whether the idea was good or bad, but that the proponents for the vote had no actual evidence to support their position, but were adamant that they were right. The people who were opposed to the idea could at least look at how society had been structured around the world, throughout all of time, and simply point out that things were working well enough. One side had evidence in their favor, and the other side did not. I would posit, too, that if you look at the people involved in that side, there was that same "demonic" presence that they mentioned in the video. That's a curious parallel.

The answer is to swerve as minimally as possible (for a near miss) in the direction opposite of where the objects are falling to; and the reason this isn't a problem is because if most people are using self driving cars they should be able to cross communicate which means whatever is in the way of the direction that the car swerves in will react to avoid collission and if that were to cause another collision this would be repeated until there are no more oncoming collisions. This "dilemma" is vastly underestimating the capabilities of AI including the speed at which decisions can be made, it could potentially decide to drive further away from the car with the objects on it so that it has more time to brake and avoid accidents, and the speed at which it can send messages to nearby self-driving cars.

If we had a mandatory feature in all cars and motorcycles to have a self-driving AI that can override the manual driver for any such collisions, this could never be a problem. I.e. to solve this we have to reverse the current situation of autonomous driving, instead of self-driving requiring a human observer, human driving should require an AI observer. At least on public roads.

In other words, I think this video is completely idiotic, a dilemma created by someone who falsely thinks he understands what he's talking about.

Appreciate the talk, some interesting points I agree with, but probably just as many I don't, read below if you are interested.

While 'programming' is the shorthand for writing code, I usually think of it as 'getting computers to do what we want' and that can involve a lot of minor detail that can start to get difficult to express in natural language, at least efficiently. "No code"/"Low code" solutions have been around for a long time, this use of LLMs does feel different, but I think the same limitations exist.

LLMs will get better at working out the intention of a human for common use cases, but that vagueness in natural language will bite. You rightfully pointed out how LLMs struggle with 'lost in the middle', which is what happens as soon as a project grows to beyond a toy project. Currently I believe people focusing on LLMs have 'Transformer Blindness'. Yes, the Transformer architecture is amazing, but this 'lost in the middle' problem I believe is a pretty fundamental limitation given how next tokens are predicted. I still agree this will be overcome, but not with just bigger and bigger Transformer models. Active Inference solves the problems we face with Agents and 'exploration vs exploitation' problem a lot better than just throwing more parameters at fixed models and IMO will be the next important leap in development of Agents. It still won't end the need for all manual programming, but it will drastically reduce the need for human programmers yes.

Knowing what you need when building a system is going to be a larger and larger chunk of the problem, which in itself will benefit from a programming background. While a vast amount of software can be built with a SQL database, backend API and web front end, these are not the only systems getting built.

Timelines are impossible to predict, but to me I think there is a fundamental limitation of natural language when combined with the specificity required by computers and building solutions. This makes me think that the "Human in the loop" of programming will persist for much longer than 10 years, but the impact on the contraction of the required software developer workforce is a big unknown, and very much worth highlighting which this video did well. Thanks again for the video, much appreciated!

One of the problems we are facing in higher education is how to teach programming given the new AI tools.  Before you can understand complex code, you need to know the basics.  However, the basics can be done much faster and more efficiently by AI than by humans.  Many students go to AI to do their homework, and then find themselves unprepared to take an exam.  The people with the highest efficiency in creating code with AI are those with a strong base in programming who can guide the system toward an optimal solution.  We don't want to stop students from using AI in their codes (in general), but we need them to be good at it.   We are continuously trying to find the balance between limiting AI so students develop strong foundational skills and fully embracing it because it is the future.

I think other fields will (or should) be affected more by AI than software. Some of them are currently far more prestigious, like general practice medicine, and clinical psychology. Even early symbolic AI had accuracy of diagnosis similar to clinicians when all the knowledge was manually encoded as logical rules.

It‚Äôs true that the most important thing about developing software is understanding the problem domain, but it‚Äôs not merely a matter of encoding what is already clearly expressed. Most clients don‚Äôt know clearly what they want, most experts in any field have never had to rigorously encode their knowledge, a lot of knowledge is held tacitly. Most importantly, I usually find that even apparently straightforward problems are much better understood only after the process of designing and building software to solve the problem. I would contend that, once a problem is solved with software, no one understands the problem domain quite so clearly or fundamentally as the software engineer.

I'm not a professional writer, so I can't give people an answer about how I feel about AI writing programs. The least I can give is a similar experience with AI making art. Yes, like you've mentioned in the video, it's not perfect yet; and yes, there are already art contests out there that were won by AI generated art, just like how there are students and even businesses already using the AI to do work for them.

My problem isn't really with the AI itself, but the attitude surrounding the use of AI. Especially the people who use the AI as a reason to put down, insult, belittle, and shame writers, artists, and any other creators of the like. Personally, I think, at least for an art AI stand point, is a wonderful tool to help you get things done more efficiently (think to the programs that help you smooth out your brush strokes if you have shaky hands, for example). But that is not how the majority of the art AI(s) are being used right now (again, at least in the art aspect of this). It's being used to put people out of their jobs/passions, cutting off their motivation, ability and oppertunity to grow as a creator, and being belittle for pursuing such a path in the first place.

If there's anything about AI that I want to see changed and improved, it's the laws that surrounds the usage of such a tool and the attitude people have while using such a tool. But that's just me. It's just my opinion, so take it with a grain of salt.

As a professional, working visual artist noticing the rise in AI art these past couple months, I think the majority of artists more so are irritated with it‚Äôs marketing as a replacement of professional artists rather than as a tool for artists. Having AIs ‚Äúlearn‚Äù on databases of licensed/copyrighted artwork made by living concept artists, where the OG artists receive no compensation or credit, makes the entire situation seem more like executives and studio heads just want to receive content and never pay the artists. A lot of these AI concepts even pick up entire sections of peoples artwork and basically plagiarize them. I can be inspired by other people‚Äôs work, sure, but if I started tracing entire sections of my favorite artists line for line, most people would call me out for stealing someone‚Äôs work, and rightfully so. If I write a song that‚Äôs inspired by Sungazer‚Äôs playing style, that‚Äôs fair game, but if I start just taking bass lines and merely transplant them into a slightly modified song, I think it would be kinda scummy. We can argue all day if this is real art or real music, but what‚Äôs far more important is the effect is has financially on working artists. If your albums were fed into a learning model (without compensation), and then that learning model was marketed as ‚ÄúHey, you can ‚Äòmake‚Äô a song in the style of Adam Neely,,‚Äù it‚Äôs not really a tool meant to benefit you, the artist, anymore, like MIDI or recorded music, or photoshop and 3D programs for visual artists - it‚Äôs meant explicitly to replace you.
