Artist here who has been making their income from private commissions for years now. I largely agree with you, but there's a few things I feel sort of lukewarm about after watching through and would like to try and offer my perspective as an artist who also doesn't like the current state of AI. Apologies if this is going to be long.

- While you could argue AI is taking inspiration from millions of images (taken without consent to be fed into a database), it is no way the same kind of inspiration an artist takes from other pieces of art to make their own. AI takes multiple images and basically mashes them together, which true, often comes out entirely new and distinct from any images it used, but other times it still has very visible imperfections, chunks of someone else's work, even their watermarks. AI cannot take inspiration from existing art the same way another artist can, and that point you tried to make there stung a fair bit. Inspiration makes art go around, artists never hated others taking inspiration from them, but copying part of their images, or basically frankeinsteining them together with others is not it.
- Another thing is that people now profit off of AI. First, the creators of these apps themselves charge people, and yes, they have put in work into making the app at the very least, even if the images they use are not rightfully theirs, people now pay no money or very minimum to generate images and offer them as commissions, designs for sale, and more. And people now actually consider buying a kindof awkward looking but cheaper generated image over paying for someone who drew it 100% themselves. I feel like this is where mostly the concern about losing income and theft comes from, and, it's both warranted, but not, and it is theft, but it isn't. It's complicated. From this same point comes even more people who already didn't think artists are justified to charge what they charge and feel entitled to their work for cheaper, or in some cases, for free. And make no mistake, there will always be people who will prefer to commission real people, who will stick to the creators they know and love, who think their work is worth it.
Of course, anyone can sympathize with not having money for needless luxuries, and in the end of the day, art is a luxury. No one needs it to live, you don't need a custom commission of art, or music, or anything to go about your day to day. But in the end, it's also wrong for people to compare the work of creators to AI and go "oh if they can do it for $8 why are you charging hundreds"? They can do it for $8 because millions before put in the time and effort for their work to now feed that program.
- While AI is unethical, and even if arguing about whether it's theft or not might not get us very far, the other reason why artists especially take it personally is because they have been getting this kind of disrespect since the beginning of time. They get their art stolen all the time, by companies to put on merch they have been not authorized for, by people claiming their work as their own, selling them on Redbubble, being used for personal projects without credit or direct claim to it, and when they speak up they are just expected to take it because "oh they like your work, it's a compliment, don't be selfish". So when a larger company who could ask creators to cooperate with them and donate images for their app to learn from instead just pulls anything and everything to then monetize the use of their app they built on the backs of others, it's not too difficult to see why it can feel like another kick. Some react overly strongly, but at least some level of upset is absolutely understandable.
- While I understand your comparison to music, and the revolution of music from "real instruments" to electronic, same way traditional art turning digital and people being mad that it isn't real: you are right, people absolutely were, there are always those who hate change and cannot see further from their own methods and techniques and will think of other mediums as less than. However, I don't think it's the best comparison, because while closed minded people will hate new tools for no reason, they didn't necessarily take their work to make that new tool a reality. While AI is also a tool, it's again, unethical. That's just the best way to put it. SOme works will come out of it way more transformed from the originals, others won't. The real question is, what gives the right to the people who made it to tell their users "yes, for a fee, you can use these creations we generated for you" when they legally do not own most of the source that made their creation a reality? Even if it isn't illegal, it's leaving a bad taste in people's mouths, for similar reasons to my previous point.
- And my last point: many people defending AI, or the creators of these apps, try and advertise it as a tool for accessibility to help people who can't draw, are disabled or can't afford art. And that would be nice, except they only use these arguments as a shield, because they completely ignore the fact that many artists are also scraping by to make ends meet, are disabled, and have set time aside deliberately to hone their craft, which to some now feels like is being taken and peddled for cheaper to appease people who are either lazy, don't value their work, or want to turn the generated images for profit.

In conclusion: AI is a fun tool, and could very well coexist with creators - if they really were made in mind with creators, too. Like you said in the video too, there are many grey areas and it definitely isn't all black and white.
I really recommend you or anyone to watch Steven zapata's "The End of Art: An Argument Against Image AIs" because he puts every concern, pro and con way better in words than I could (and also mentions how the same company who took artist's work without consent had no issues making an AI generator for music WITH the cooperation of musicians and using free to use and royalty free resources).

Having been a programmer for decades, productivity has improved steadily the whole time. Growth in living standards relies on us all producing more in the same time. AI is a productivity tool not a replacement for many jobs. Going back to my early career,  improvements in development environments, debuggers, language choice and compiler speed produced a 10x improvement in productivity. Then, the internet came along and made it easier to find code examples, get help, collaborate and produced at least 3 to 5x further improvement in productivity. That's between 30 and 50x improvement in 40 years. Now with AI, I have an expert coding assistant to help me which is  especially useful when learning new things and reducing the need to reference manuals or look for examples resulting in another 3x improvement and will no doubt get even better. For context, the first compiler I used commercially took to several hours to compile a few hundred lines of code just to discover I had a syntax error. At no time during this journey have I felt my job threatened. I just produce 100x more work than I did all those decades ago. AI is another productivity tool.

If you were to ask me what would be the fastest, most efficient way to implement AI in a way that would allow non programmers to build complex programs, it would be a node based system, with each nodes connection being controlled by a separate agent.  You click on the node, write in natural language what you want the node to do, then connect any nodes too it that would contain information you want that nodes function to use.  This would allow the user to guide the AI to only the relevant parts of the code it needs to achieve a function so it doesn't get confused by the overwhelming amount of data.  It would also allow the user to troubleshoot each function in their code by checking the input and output values of the nodes.

10:43 Expanding on this a bit: when I saw Gil Scott-Heron a couple of years before his death, he told this story about how jazz was originally called 'jism music' because it was made to entertain folks in brothels in New Orleans while they were waiting for their turn. Around the same time, someone stole a shipment of brass instruments, and soon enough everyone in the ghetto miraculously started playing the trumpet or the saxophone. They weren't brass musicians, because they didn't have any formal training, so folks called them 'ass musicians'. There was a lot of crossover between jism and ass in those days, and when it went mainstream in the late 1910s, early 1920s, people didn't want to seem crass, so they just called it jazz. Anyway, Adam Neely is my favourite jism and ass bassist

AI really isn't that big of a deal, regardless of how much ignorant people want to kick up dirt about it; just be transparent about it. Wizards especially just cannot be transparent about anything, because most of anything they do is exploitative.

Regarding the criticism of quality of AI art, that's just a matter of curation and the infancy of actual generative AI. As the technology continues to improve, and developers find better ways of implementing it and using it more as a tool in conjunction with artists rather than outright replacing them, you'll see the quality steadily get better. Probably even faster than you might expect. I keep drawing the comparison to the switch to digital art vs traditional physical media, and apparently that is still lost on people.

For all the scare people have over AI art, people are also forgetting how accessible this is making development for everyone. And since now it's such a popular thing to hold resentment for those who hold the reins of power to their most treasured hobby, like Wizards with D&D, this means potential for competitors to rise up to challenge them is greater than it's ever been as it's effectively lowered the cost of entry. AI isn't something that should be left solely in the corpo's tool belt, and if you're going to play ignorant and turn your nose up to an objectively effective tool and shunt creators who do utilize it, then I think you'll find yourself in for a rude awakening as the rest of the world passes you on by.

People want to make this a battle of AI vs artist, when it really should be anything but. I don't look at a paintbrush with scorn when it could do so much for me.

Honestly, this should be VERY simple. Did the AI company PAY the artists to use the music that they were trained on? If so, then they're good. If not, then EVERYTHING that AI generates is "copied from" rather than inspired from. The data that AIs want to train from has value, and they cannot simply strip that value away because it's convenient for them (read "free").

It's completely analogous to how all training has ever been through history - if you wanted to learn to be a blacksmith, you paid for that knowledge by working as an apprentice. If you want to learn to be a doctor, you pay for the necessary schooling.

It's really NOT that complicated a subject, in my mind.

This is a really fair and balanced video, and I wish that there were more like this that were less reactionary from both sides. But you're missing one key talking point. Technically, you did consent to whatever website you posted your art on using anything you post for basically whatever they want. Including compiling it into a database and selling it. That's what the "I accept the terms and conditions" button is for.

It's definitely worth also noting that there is a much bigger conversation here about how we were tricked into giving up our rights for the convenience of using all of these websites for free. Because if you think that this is just about art, you were missing the forest for a single tree. We sold all of our data, not thinking about the consequences. And you can't undo what's already been done, you can't put the genie back in the bottle.

Maybe at the very least, we can start considering using websites and technologies which do not harvest our data. They exist but they're less mature because no one uses them.

As a musician, I relate to the pain visual artists are suffering now because 25 years ago, sampling and DJs were doing the same thing with live musician's recordings. Now, AI technology has evolved so that it's almost impossible to define the "DNA" of an art style. It took me some time to understand that in art, copycats are the rule, not the exception - even for prominent artists like Led Zepellin - and how we represent copyright legally is very biased towards protecting companies instead of individuals. That said, AI companies should pay artists that appear in their data, but in the end, art is much more than a personal style; it is the meaning you're trying to convey with art. And that I believe AI will never be able to do because it would be forced to become human.

as an artist, I would like to point out that the "stealing from artists" argument honestly has very little to do with AI being able to replicate our art styles, and more to do with the fact that our art was used without our permission in order to program the AI.

Almost every artist I've talked to about this is more angry about the fact that our art is being stolen by random techies and fed into these programs without even bothering to ask us for permission. They're straight up just taking art from independent artists and using it for their own massive profit whilst the artists who poured hours of blood, sweat and tears into their craft aren't seeing even a single cent... even though, without the work of all of those artists, the AI would be have nothing to learn from in the first place and would be completely useless.

Thank you for another great video, Matt.
I am not a coder but intuitively, I agree that AI coding through voice/text prompts is the future. I also agree that such AI tool will be just another step above the programming language in the Layers of Abstraction chart. However, I don't necessarily see it as transparent as other items on the chart are. What I mean is that if a human uses a programming language, they understand it (ideally) and if they are not getting the results they want, they can debug their work. They can even make changes in the language itself or develop a new one! There still will be people who will learn to do so but all the others, without the knowledge, will be totally dependent on the AI tool and won't necessarily know how to achieve a different result if the tool doesn't give them what they envisioned.
At the moment, people who are involved with any of the items on the chart understand them (each his/her own field). This will not be the case with AI coding.
In summary, if the tool breaks down, there will be no coding (for people who didn't learn it).
Still, I am super excited for this development because even if I will never understand what it is doing under the hood I can get much better results than I can currently achieve with my zero programming knowledge.

My feelings about AI art (in the broadest sense of the term) are complicated. I think the technology is really cool, but I also acknowledge the harm that it can do under capitalism; I think that a lot of the problems (but not all of them) it introduces go away if we remove it from a capitalist context. However, as an intellectual property abolitionist (I will not get into why), a lot of the ethical arguments as it pertains to copyright and ownership are mute, because I don't believe that it is truly possible to own art beyond being able to say "I made this", whatever that means, and I actually did find that particular section of the video very engaging. BTW, I'm personally on the side of the 'right of authorship' for the photographs belonging to both Naruto and Slater.

However, I think that there is one aspect of 'the artist' that will be nearly impossible for it to replace (or at the very least, it will be a very long time), and that is community engagement. I'm specifically thinking about authors like Brandon Sanderson. Brandon Sanderson is so involved with his community/fandom, that being a Cosmere fan is nearly impossible to do without just being a Brandon Sanderson fan. He's so involved with his community, and I think that, at least while it's being written, an essential part of being active in the fandom is engaging with Brandon himself. Now, of course, this only applies to artists like Brandon Sanderson, who are extremely involved with their communities and fandoms, but that's not worth nothing. If anything, I think it could encourage more artists to be more involved with their fans and communities directly.

my best evidence against self driving cars is me. i'm indian. i took driving lessons for 2 weeks and was able to navigate all those crazy intersections with broken stoplights and other drivers who don't have any regard for traffic laws with only slight anxiety and i never collided into anyone. before the driving lessons i had driven around in an empty parking lot once. the thing with self driving cars is they likely won't be able to do this, at least for a long time. humans are really good at encountering novel situations and making quick decisions. once you learn to operate a motor vehicle, slamming the breaks or swerving as soon as you feel like you might collide with someone or something becomes instinct. there were a couple of times during my lessons when someone came out of nowhere and i immediately hit the breaks. and it was an abrupt stop because i'd only learnt how to drive like 3 days ago but the instructor agreed i'd made the correct decision and had good reaction time. it's going to be ages before anyone figures out how to write a program that makes a computer think like a person.

also i walk a lot and there's going to be no way for me to figure out if a self driving car is planning to let me pass or not. when it's people they either drive on or gesture at you to go. you can still communicate with them nonverbally. you can't do that with a car. people who are really into selling self driving cars keep forgetting that cars aren't going to exist in a world without pedestrians

I program CNC machines. I used to write G-code by hand. Then it got easier with conversational programming where a computer did the math and most of the g-code. Now a computer does almost all of it. Soon AI will remove the last little bit of fussy stuff and I‚Äôm all for it. Maybe robots will take over the manual portion of my job, but probably not in the shop I run before I retire in a few years. Any job done entirely on computers is not looking very secure. I know a lot of people are in denial and think they will continue to get fat checks for supervising AI, but that will not be the case. In industry you have a few tiers of machinists. I‚Äôm a master toolmaker. I‚Äôm at the very top. I can make anything, with any process, in any machine. Below me you might have a programming machinist. They program and set up cnc machines. You might have 2 of these guys in a big industrial shop. Then you have button pushers of various skill level. They basically are robots that take parts in and out of the machine and look out for any problems. They don‚Äôt get paid a lot. So that‚Äôs what will happen with AI coding. It‚Äôs even more grim when you consider that low wages countries have smart workers who‚Äôs only past barrier has been they don‚Äôt speak English. With real time translating on both ends of the conversation, that barrier is gone. Even with physical robots. If you have an AI powered robot working in industry 75% autonomously, a few remote workers can take over and help them out of a jam following AI generated instructions.

Automation was never meant to replace the human worker. It was always meant to be a tool to increase productivity. People will always have limitations due to the ways our bodies work. Machines were built to augment the worker in order to make up for our physical limitations.

Corporations see this technology as a way to replace people so the rich are the ones that profit, not their employees. Consider this, we've had automated trains and aircraft for decades and yet we still have people who can operate those vehicles.

The reason is that there's too many variables that can risk the lives of passengers and the destruction of cargo. What if a driverless car hits a pedestrian and they die, or the car wrecks and the passengers die? Who's responsible, the company that bought the car or the makers of the car? Someone has to be held accountable when people get hurt and automated vehicles raise more questions than they provide answers.

As an artist I deeply disagree with the video. You say you see art as a process and then argue for the side of art as the product the whole way through.
Art is not made to be efficient. AI as it is not a good tool for creating art, even if we ignore the ethics (which we absolutely should not, although techbros do it all the time and get away with it). There ARE machine learning tools that ARE useful, like is this site where you pose a skull and the AI searches images that have this angle so you can train to draw that angle. There are also algorithms that help pick colours, generate prompts etc etc.
The art IS NOT made to be efficient because art is found in the process of its creation. It's ABSOLUTELY putting masses of people out of work if even Disney doesn't mind generating a show opening with AI. And companies will ABSOLUTELY replace every single human with a program if that means saving even a dime.
Art is not MADE to be efficient until an artist creating it finds a way that works best for them.
And as a corporate artist I'm personally offended by the "not really creating just doing what they're told" bullshit. I'm hearing enough of it from managers who have neither taste nor common sense while I'm sometimes single handedly saving our company from putting the worst possible visuals the insist on into the public. And I'm not alone, there are thousands upon thousands of us balancing corporate greed, misplaced ambitions and pride with striving for good user experience and pleasant imagery.

People need to realize that "quicker" doesn't automatically mean "better". I'm so sick of everyone saying the "old ways" are "obsolete". That's what they said about vinyl records, and physical books, and they're doing better than ever. I don't think the other tools are EVER going to go away. We all have the choice to not use this technology if we don't want to. Tools should be seen as "options", and nothing more.

When it comes to this stuff, I don't have that same level of appreciation as with actual art. It's the equivalent of a robot climbing Mount Everest vs a human doing it. It's cool that the robot is scaling it, and accomplishing so much in a quick amount of time, but that's what it's designed to do. When a human does it, it's much more impressive because we're flawed, fragile individuals, and it's so much more satisfying when they actually reach the top.

Overall, I'd rather wait for perfection than haphazardly slap on an image and call it a day. The thing about "instant gratification" is that it's there one day, but then it fades almost immediately.

I see some people worrying about music, so here's my take. AI will most definitely replace all forms of mainstream music. Because mainstream music has been spiritually and artistically dead for the a few decades. 99.9% of the songs you hear on the radio are simply products. Let's take some goofy poser like Drake. He doesn't write his own lyrics, he doesn't produce his own beats, he does none of the engineering in the studio, he takes no part in the cinematography of his clips. This guy shows up to the studio, he's handed a couple of lines, he raps for 3 hours, then leaves. A couple of weeks later the people in charge of making everything for him release his track and a clip video and he earns millions for doing none of the work. He's just a face for something that isn't real. Drake isn't an artist, he's just the personality used to ship that art under. And that applies to virtually all the most popular artists nowadays. They're just posers. They're just a celebrity being handed all the fame and recognition for something they truly didn't do. And all of that soulless process is reflected in how unoriginal, boring, uninspiring and simple their art is. This mainstream music has been made with methods resembling AI for decades already. For example, all a beatmaker has to do is load up FL studio, load up a premade template, jam on his keyboard for 30 minutes, hand his shit to an engineer to mix and master it and boom it's done. That's why a beatmaker can make dozens of beats a day. It's the artistic equivalent of McDonalds. It will be REALLY FUCKING EASY for AI to replace these factory workers (not artists, they're factory workers because they're just the individual processing units that end up making a finished product). And honestly, I don't give a fuck because it won't make a difference anyway. It's not like there was any soul in this type of music in the first place. It will just become easier to ship out more artistic McDonalds so that drones can consume their daily dose of mind numbing noise.

Now to me there's another big category, and that is the artists that are still popular to the point of sometimes making it to the mainstream scene, while still having some form of artistic integrity. These people will either lose the rest of their integrity and let AI do shit for them, won't change their ways, or they might actually do the right thing for the art consciousness and decide to become better artists by partaking in more of their production, refusing to use that technology and trying to make higher quality art. But I'm not familiar with this caliber of artists so let me head to the next category.

Now that's where it gets interesting in my opinion. There are many artists out there making authentic music out true passion and for the sake of art. These young artists that currently have 25 followers on Soundcloud will become the next generation of renowned artists. They're the pioneers. Because their music will be so unique that AI will never catch up to it. It will be so expressive and intimate that AI will never even come close. If anything, I see AI as something positive in that regards, because it will weed out all the people who were never "artists" in the first place, the posers, the people getting the fame for doing 5% of the work.
Then the REAL artists will shine. Because they'll be the only ones able to deliver something that moves humanity's soul. The ones that were ignored because their taste and style were too out of the box, too unordinary, too special, or simply too thought provoking will finally get the recognition that they deserved. They won't be left in the shadows anymore, in very small tightknit communities, or just alone.
The first half of this was quite negative because I have a fundamental disgust for cheaply made "art". But the conclusion is positive. And I want to spread hope about this whole art situation, especially in music and in animation.
I know that to you reading this, I'm just some random guy saying some random shit. But please trust me when I say that the next decade will show a marvelous and beautiful expansion of the boundaries of art. There's going to be so much boundary breaking, breath taking, impressive art that will push the art consciousness forward in realms never seen before. The culmination of thousands and thousands and thousands of years of collective work. And it will be amazing. I'm genuinely looking forward to what these young unknown artists are cooking in their bedroom, or perhaps while traveling the world as vagabonds for inspiration.

You might actually be one of those artists I'm talking about right now. If you are one of them, a misunderstood artist who knows he has something to say to the world, something to make it more beautiful, desperately trying to show the world what you're capable of to no avail, don't lose hope. Your time is coming. I know that it's hard when people judge your work on shit that doesn't matter instead of your message or the feeling you're trying to portray. But one day people's consciousness will open up to your expression, and they will listen. Keep practicing your craft, keep being mad scientist, keep chasing the things that make you feel alive. Don't be scared to be your true self, no matter how much people reject you. And I genuinely wish you the best of luck, future pioneer. I'm looking forward to what you have to show to the world.
(and if you need someone to talk to, share your art to, and have conversations about that, let me know. The thing that brings me the most pleasure as an artist is helping people in the same situation as me and I'd be so happy to share what I've learned over the years.)

Godspeed.

Good interview, but I disagree with the introduction, where it is said that LLM's are "auto-correction on steroids" . Yes, LLMs do next token prediction. But that's just one part. The engine of a LLM is a giant neural network, that learned a (more or less sophisticated) model of the world. It is being used during inference to match input information against and, based on that correlations, creates new output information which leads, in an iterative process, to a series of next token. So the magic happens, when input information is matched against the learned world model, that leads to new output information.

Personally, I don't find the "AI is just a tool" line of argument very convincing for precisely the same reason I don't find the "guns don't kill people" line of reasoning convincing. Clearly AI is a tool, but saying it like that's the end of the argument denies culpability by those who ostensibly have the power to prevent a known bad thing from happening with that tool. In particular, at 15:50 you say "the whole point of AI is to make things more efficient, right? So, if you have to track and credit every single piece of data that goes in and goes out it will take way too long, so it defeats the purpose of efficiency". I'm a deep learning researcher and educator at my local university and when the topic of AI ethics comes up, I point my students to some AI principles that were put out by the Australian Government. These provide useful language to describe exactly what it is about AI systems that is unethical. https://www.industry.gov.au/publications/australias-artificial-intelligence-ethics-framework/australias-ai-ethics-principles
Using this framework, we can see several ways the current form of AI art generation is unethical.
1. Human, societal and environmental wellbeing: as you point out, it is being used to undermine the livelihoods of current artists. That is, it has not been made to benefit society, but rather to enrich some bad actors.
2. Transparency and explainability: The biggest problem on this principle is that artists are being affected without ever agreeing to anything. They weren't given a choice; their art was collected and used without their knowledge, and this isn't made clear either to users or the people who's art was taken that this is happening, or how.
3. Contestability: On top of not being given a choice whether they want to participate, artists also have no recourse if they don't want to participate. They can't just choose to opt out.

Importantly, these principles also provide us a way to understand how to build ethical AI systems. So, an ethical AI art system would need to be:
1. Designed as a value add, rather than a redistribution.
2. Proper attribution MUST be given. The process by which the art is generated must be identifiable, and what inspirations were used.
3. Artists must be able to opt out. Their artworks must not be taken.

And the thing is... this wouldn't fundamentally break the technology. It would just take a bit of work. I actually disagree with the part I quoted from you on a completely different level, too. What you describe, where attribution is tracked, and the data that goes in and out absolutely can be tracked. It's not impossible. The database already has the attributions in some sense, otherwise it would be impossible to ask for "art in the style of xxx". It must have been trained on that association in order to know it. So, the creators of these AI systems already have enough data to do attribution on the input side. Getting it for the output side is more tricky, but I believe it to be possible. Again, though, I think it is also necessary for the ethical creation of AI art.

The problem with making AI art a value add, rather than a redistribution isn't really a technical problem; it's a societal one. We have to view the AI generation as a tool, and treat it as such, rather than a drop-in replacement for a human artist. And we can see this happening! https://www.cnbc.com/2023/06/15/adobe-ceo-says-ai-will-wont-replace-human-ingenuity-itll-augment-it.html
I know this is a newer development, and this video is 5 months old, but the point I'm trying to make is that any time I see someone throw up their hands and claim that it's too complicated to make it ethical, I want to shake them and make them see the forest through all the trees. What the hell are we doing if not trying to make things better, overall?

I've just lost a lot of respect for you as this video shows how little you get into the real details, while claiming to have been "thinking about it a lot". Your level of undertstanding is at around 20% of my journey of discovery into "why programming is dead". At that point, I would have agreed with you.

For context, i am Lead SWE with 17 years experience, I read 3 AI papers each day, 5 years experience in AI.

What you missed:

- Complexity resolution scales exponentially. AI finds a problem twice as complex four times as difficult to solve.
- Overall iterative coding requires human coder input, and always will.
- Coders are not paid for hourly services but for expertise.
- Humans prefer talking to humans instead of robots.
- Most companies aren't cost optimisers. Many still use 90s software.
- Aggregate demand is infinite. When a project is finished, company wants to code something new.
- Look at production difficulties with RAGs. Read some experiences. AI stumbles on complexity of detail, and human input is required at every step, negating most of utility. These things aren't as easily solvable as you think.
- Closed source code is plentiful. Debugging embedded C++ software on a mobile device or microcontroller is distant future. You need physical hands to interact with devices.
- Early adoption of fully automated systems will be sensitive. A manager sees a bad result, and he gets pissed off much more. Psychological feeling of helplessness vs if there was a human to talk to. Will hinder early adoption.
- Self driving cars work just fine 99% of the time. It's the 1% stopping adoption. Programming will be the same. The 1% bug will happen 30 days after product launch, everything will stop, and a human won't be able to fix it in 5 minutes since they didn't code it.
- Telling an AI what to do, you need a pro coder. Using natural language and arguing with AI does not exactly save time.

I agree programming will change in 5-10 years, but your estimate of 1-2 years is really laughable. The skill upgrade you expect from AI will require extremely expensive and clean data sets, and new training techniques. People are talking about this, but this will take 5 years to do. Many companies will invest and fail.

And once all these companies downsize their workforce and replace them with AI - who is going to buy their products and services?  No jobs = no money = no customers.   Eventually their bottom line will be affected.

The 'Coding' part of Software Engineering may turn to full automation. However, coding is just a means to an end in business. Software Engineering mostly happens on the left side of the 'V' model (If you're familiar with it). Everything has to be prototyped, designed, requirements drawn up etc. That's where most of the engineering is done. The right side of the 'V' is just implementation. This could be automated but what happens when you need to debug this? You might say just throw another Ai at it. The Ai might generate code that performs well but is a nightmare to understand. It might not even write good code. Now with enough time this might be fine. But an Ai and neither a human will be able to find every possible edge case of software. As the complexity grows, so does the number of possible ways it can fail. You're always going to need an engineer around to fix it when it hits one of these edge cases. Just like we still need engineers around to update, fix, and provide new features for a languages compiler. Unless people plan on letting a digital consciousness (or multiple) to run their factories, logistics, and other areas of their lives, you're still going to need engineers around to fix them when they break. Everything can and will break given enough time.
We must be all adaptable in life in order to advance in life

As someone who works in AI, since the late 1980s, AI is not just for low level tasks, menial tasks or repetitive tasks.

One of the first systems I worked on was an underwriter assistant for property and casualty insurance; within a few versions, it went from an assistant for human underwriters to doing the work of entry level then low experience underwriters, reducing the number of human underwriters needed. I've since worked on several executive information systems with AI-based analysis and forecasting capabilities that are faster and more accurate than human analysts...among other high value, white-collar, college educated human task replacements.

AI can be assistive or replacive; all that's needed is the right conditions and financial incentive. With the larger number of skilled AI technologists and AI focused technologies and companies, the conditions and costs are going down rapidly.

What would have been possible but cost prohibitive just a few years ago is easily justified (financially) today, and the pace is accelerating.

A human taking direct, obvious inspiration from another artists style/technique and incorporating that into their own work is just fundamentally not the same as feeding a machine a dataset of images to cut up and piece back together in a soulless imitation of what was fed to it. It's missing both the wonderfully beautiful and complex filter through the human creative brain, and the actual process of physically executing your creative vision. I find the fan art comparison confusing because, though it's not an original ip, it's still something that has to be executed independently of the material that inspired it.
Swap illustration out for any other form of art and the fundamental issue at hand becomes immediately clear. If, hypothetically, someone created an ai voice based on your singing and used it to produce music, then going on to call it their vocal talent because they directed the ai, I assume you would have an issue with this, because no matter how much time they spent perfecting the ai & the result it spits out, it's not /their/ voice doing the singing. They could have put in the effort to learn how to sing while taking inspiration from your singing style, but they didn't, they instead chose to forcibly puppeteer a hacked-together simulation of YOUR throat to do the singing for them. This same principle applies to ai illustration. This is why it is, in a sense, theft. They are /solely/ using /other people's/ work and abilities to execute their creative vision. If they would just CREATE THEIR OWN ART and use THAT in their dataset, there would be literally no issue!!!

I'm a PhD researcher in natural language processing (the area behind text generative AIs), and one thing I think is missing here is that Bing's AI (I can't say the same for Google), was released while it was bad ON-PURPOSE so that society could start to create videos like this and imagine what life would be like if the AI was better and start to adapt while the AI is still bad.

Some other errors that I think may cloud people's thinking in this video:
1. AI can also create new things that have never been seen before (but Adam is right in that the new creations must be based off of data the AI has seen before.) I don't know enough psychology to know if humans can create truly novel work, and I'm not sure if that question is settled. (Note that Adam did not provide a source for the idea that humans don't combine old stuff in new ways in a similar way to generative AI.)
2. The Bing Chat engine is not just generative AI, it can cite its sources, and is more similar to OpenAIs WebGPT model. It still has issues, but it's not the same as ChatGPT, which is generative AI + intelligently ranking outputs.
3. Most of the scary "AIs will takeover everything" worry is done based on the idea called "X-risk" that if we do adopt this technology into critical parts of our infrastructure, and we program it wrong, it could destroy humanity. It's a big worry from the potential consequences perspective, but not from a "this is likely to happen" perspective. In short, it's a good thing to be worried about, but it shouldn't take all the hype.

However, those were pretty much the only issues I could find with this video. He's right about the AIs not being good. He's right about it running on hype. He's right about the ethics teams being fired. He's right about it copying humans' work who didn't give consent for their work to be copied.

If you have questions, feel free to ask in the comments! I'm happy to help clear some stuff up and explain how/why he's right.

There is one thing I believe AI isn't close to replacing: human connection. A song/art form/career isn't just that. It's a story. And we have to believe there's a human behind the story to actually get hooked. And I believe there's a rational reason for that and it has to do with why we like stories in the first place: they are there to teach us about experiences that have a likelihood of happening to us so we are better prepared. It's a survival mechanism! Therefore, it makes sense that we evolved to prefer stories that we feel happened to real people (otherwise, are they really useful stories if they can't happen for real?). AI breaks that component in our brain, rendering the stories (or songs) it creates very less enjoyable. That's my two cents.

To be clear, the Terraforming Mars campaign is for an expansion to the base game, and is not a standalone game. As such, the artwork in the expansion should be consistent with the artwork of the original game (which is bad). Otherwise, the new art would be out of place. Since there's no point in paying someone to make bad art consistent with the base game, I have no issue with Fryx using bad AI art. I also have no issue with them not wanting to give a handout to an artist to produce art for an expansion, when that artist did nothing to contribute to the success of their game.

Personally, I hope that there will eventually be a revised edition of the base game with better art. But until then, there's no point in hiring an artist for an expansion, as the game will still look ugly on the table.

Generally, I'm sympathetic to board game designers. They put in thousands of hours of unpaid work to create designs. Even if their game is successful, their "design time" is still ignored when it comes to fixing the price of the game, as customers aren't willing to pay for it. So hearing a bunch of people telling board game designers that not only should they donate thousands of hours of their time, but that they should also take out mortgages to pay for artists is ridiculous.

The above is also why AI art will win out. Telling people without money that they should have to spend money is never a winning strategy.

What was funny with this the day this came out was that it was already "defeated" before I got off work to test the effectiveness myself, which I wasn't able to replicate their results when I tried, so I think they are hand picking results and/or overstating the results.

What other found by the time I got home? Literally the first two obvious things people tried worked rather well and it really doesn't work as it's being represented to be.

What was even funnier was that the "poisoned" images were in many cases actually working BETTER for machine learning. We had people researching training methods of adding extra noise for improving results, and a lot of us have been noticing that training from generative images can work a lot better than input of human only content. Now the glazing is dirty of doing both, it's adding noise to features of interest.

People never like when changes happen... especially when it can affect people negatively. What they forget is that tech innovations are never temporary.
Cars were hated... until they became a huge goal for an entire continent.
Robotics in manufacturing was despised... until the people who had learned to love cars loved the prices and quality.
Music, which was once all acoustic, is now heavily assisted by a huge amount of tech.

And the kicker is this: while they are all assisted... none are ever done by just the tech. There has always been, and always will be a skilled and creative human guiding the process. Purely AI art is never going to match that done by a human... but once new skills are mastered, a skilled and creative human using ai as a tool will be able to make more. Better. And faster.
Businesses like the first and third parts... they always bought bad art that was cheap before, when it suited the need. Why would they stop now? The art for that game was enough to get the job done... as obviously evidenced by their sales. The only reason the use of their art has ever been questioned is the source.
The reason so many artists are already using the AI tools is because they see the potential in all 3 changes. To be better, do them faster, and therefore make more. Or did you think they didn't want some profit too?

Every time a new technology comes along, people who specialized in the old way will complain... except a few, who will embrace what is coming, and find themselves at the forefront.

Or one can always turn their back on it. It is an option. Amish quilts and furniture are master craftsman level amazing, and I am sure they do not regret turning their backs on tech. They look happy.... don't they?

Great video, but I had two issues with the logic here and maybe you just chose a poor example, because the two solutions I see that avoid the issue you brought up is that self driving cars would but drive all boxed in like that - that's just poor design. They would likely drive alternating like a checkerboard which allows "zipping" which is the proven method for the best traffic flow.

Additionally, we're assuming all cars are autonomous therefore if your car needed to swerve right, the cars to the right, which are in constant contact with your car, would also begin to veer right and the others around them slow down and quickly all of those cars could make space for your car without any car being hit by the debris.

So I think, while you bring up a good point, your example is flawed, as both seem avoidable with proper program, 100% automation, and low latency as vehicles all communicate with one another and work as a whole.

Use the analogy of a car.... in the early days, they taught people how to do mechanic work to some degree. Things like adjusting valve lash, adjusting spark timing, etc.  Now almost no one does these kinds of things.  Yes, much of it is computer controlled but it is still a mechanical device (with electronic/computer controls).  So it isn't that there is no need for people to know mechanics - but it has gravitated to a smaller set of very knowledgeable people known as mechanics to do that work. And most are electronics techs, in addition to being mechanics.   Same thing with programming.  In the early days they were encouraging everyone to learn programming or coding.  Now it's gravitating more to voice commands to interact with the computer or how to interact with AI systems like ChatGPT.  But we'll still need people that can program those layers of abstraction like Matt points out.   It doesn't automagically happen just like cars don't automagically roll off the assembly  line without knowledgeable Engineers behind the scenes to design and create that automation.

The ethics of human relations is one of the reasons that makes us unique. Machines did what they were programmed, and who did the programming in the first place?
I believe the true problem is that we as humans are coming to a point where we no longer want to maintain the intrinsic and inherent values of man, or take the burden of responsibility that comes with what makes us human.
Instead, we are trying to forfeit those values, in our foolish desires to seek comfort, and immediate satisfaction that comes from transferring that mantle of responsibility to machines and scapegoating to feel better about ourselves, when in fact, it is exactly that which destroys everything.
Simply put, to think that we can program intrinsic values and the ethical codes and state one outcome is ultimately better than the other is completely flawed, and shouldn‚Äôt be done.
Humans should do what they can and machines should do what they can.

I appreciate that you're trying to look at the issue from more than one perspective, but it seems like there's a lack of understanding here when it comes to how AI uses existing artwork versus how people use art and life for reference.

For example, the late Kim Jung Gi was famous for the "internal reference library" he developed over years of practicing art. He looked at things that existed in life and in other art and committed it to memory, to the point where he could mentally recall how almost anything was supposed to look while he was drawing. But he wasn't just "copying" those things when he drew. His art was original and unique. After he passed, somebody fed his artwork to an AI program, and the result wasn't even close to the art that KJG created. That's because artists are REFERENCING an existing image or IP to create an original piece of art that is unique them and their style. In contrast, AI is COLLECTING several images, and spitting out an amalgamation of all of those images put together.

AI doesn't "understand" the images that are being used to train it - it can't parse out things like structure and anatomy. That's why it can't do hands correctly, and why a lot of AI images tend to look a little "off."

The problem with the way the conversation is framed is that the machine intelligence or machine learning companies are doing something that no human being has done.

One of the reasons why a human artist is given a lot of slack with regards to ‚Äúinspiration‚Äú is very few of any human beings Can with any determine what part of something they listen to became part of the new song that they wrote. So we use a little bit of a fuzzy logic in order to determine what exactly has been done. And we have to use our judgment to decide if it infringes, and that‚Äôs what these court cases are all about. By the way, The thick case should not have been decided that way, just my opinion.

What‚Äôs different here is that the developers have created a mathematical computer model. They may claim that they can‚Äôt tell what‚Äôs inside of the algorithm that the machine learning system uses, but that‚Äôs almost a willful lack of knowledge. In other words, they weren‚Äôt able to come up with a true computer program to do what they wanted to do, so they were in a way a little Lazy(I know making a machine learning system is complicated, but it‚Äôs still simpler than programming each thing by hand), and so therefore they ‚Äúdon‚Äôt know what‚Äôs inside the black box.‚Äú

But that doesn‚Äôt matter. Because the computer system can do things with much more precision than human being could. What that means to me is that if they wanted to, if they cared about infringement, they could create a way to delineate where the inspiration actually came from in the ‚Äúnew works.‚Äú

More importantly however, because this system is computerized, and not a human being, these developers, in my opinion, have an obligation to make sure that any system that is trained on other peoples work has their permission.

A lot of machine learning advocates will argue that it should be an opt out system, not an in system. I disagree.

unlike human beings, who are difficult to keep track of, these tools are discreet. They can be altered in an objective way. And as a result, their developers have a responsibility to do so.

Otherwise, this whole endeavor feels like a colonial imperialist cultural attack. What ends up happening is that only those with a lot of resources can build these tools and make money off of them. So of course, to them, it seems perfectly reasonable that they are entitled to all of the work that everyone else is done without any compensation. And certainly without consent.

But if you look at the history of music specifically, this is Les the development of a new tool, and instead the development of a new era much like the beginning of the recorded music era.

At that time, most people didn‚Äôt understand the potential of recorded music. And so, somebody comes into town, says hey can I record you singing that song? They say sure, and they sign a paper. That paper, with complicated legal lease, signed over all of the rights not just to the recording, but very often to the song itself. These artist had no idea it was going on, because they didn‚Äôt understand radio or records or recording. And so it ends up happening is, MUSIC barons come in, get the rights to all sorts of music for close to nothing, make millions of dollars, and then in some cases even sue the original artist for infringement on the song that they wrote their rights away.

That is really what is happening here. It‚Äôs a new era of wealthy folks, and let‚Äôs face it they‚Äôre probably mostly white man, coming in and claiming rights to other peoples artistic works without any compensation.

I want to be clear, if you‚Äôre in a lab, and you‚Äôre trying to figure out how to build this sort of tool, as long as it‚Äôs limited to the lab, and not distributed to the rest of the world, train your beta prototype whenever you want.

But the data that you make it available to the general public, especially but not limited to making money off of it, you need to retrain from scratch your tool. You need to insist that anyone who contributes opt in. there is more than enough music and art and writing that is in the public domain that there should be plenty enough to train the systems. And then, much like stock photography websites, if you need more or want more source material, then you offer people the opportunity to opt in. Either give them the service for free, allow them to make their own little personalized machine learning generative system just on their style, or perhaps you have to pay them.

Both Adobe and Getty images are playing games with their terms of service and forcing their contributors to opt out, and while they have at least legally covered themselves, ethically they‚Äôre pulling a fast one. Mostly because the people who have contributed to those websites make part of their living off of being a part of it, and at least an Adobe case, they are extorting those artists by saying ‚Äúyou can opt out, but then you can‚Äôt sell your other works on Adobe stock anymore.‚Äú so then you force these artist to choose between whether or not they get to continue to make money, but create competitive works because it‚Äôs part of firefly, or they pull out of the firefly system, and have to find someplace else to make their money.

Artificial intelligence machine learning generative systems must be opt in. the idea that these companies can just pull anything on the Internet just because they want to is wrong. The main reason being that users can create prompts which will generate derivative works that are in the style of another artist, effectively making that artist style no longer unique to them.

And by the way, it does make a difference whether or not you have the skill to execute something. Yes, human ideas are interesting and important. But it is in the execution that the work exist. While it is true that a lot of tools have made this execution easier, generative AI systems frankly make it too easy. If you can generate a song and someone else‚Äôs styling under a minute, that may satisfy your creative endeavor, but you didn‚Äôt do the hard part which was created the style.

I think AI art should be considered as something different than human art.

This is what most pop music sounded to me while I was growing up, which is why I ended up being the only person I knew who liked Bach. Almost every pop song was devoid of any type of complexity, everything sounded the same. Sure, there were exceptions - Sinead O Conner Nothing compares (Prince); Bohemian Rhapsody, some of U2, but most other stuff just blurred into elevator music. Dsclaimer, I feel the same way about Mozart, and agree with Wagner, that when you hear it, you can hear the dishes being washed in the background (i.e., elevator music for the old royalty).
The scary part is that I believe AI will eventually compose a Matthew Passion and a B minor mass. Most of Bach is formulaic - it has to be, because he dashed off a cantata a week. We're just lucky enough not to know what the formula is - yet. But AI can spot it, and will churn out not 48 preludes and fugues, but 48,000 preludes and fugues. And go the good will blend into the awful in an even spectrum, because the one thing that AI cannot do (yet) is to appreciate music. Not a huge problem, because Beethoven composed the 9th when he was deaf. But that's effectively what AI will be doing. Composing by numbers. Writing, but never HEARING music. The role of human may finally be to curate the good from the bad. Like choosing Dancing Queen over Money Money. Or The Joshua Tree album over Zoo whatever it was.

When AC/DC sing ‚ÄúThunder!‚Äù, then I immediately tune into the emotions of them on stage (or even when writing the song). Or I think of a situation in a movie or in my life that fits.

I imagine that when I listen to an AI song, even a really good one that could have been made by AC/DC, then I don‚Äôt really know what to think. Should I think of the million songs training the AI, out of which the AI then distilled, say, a few hundred songs ‚Ä¶ so that someone (a person!) could select one of them? Because it sounds good enough to put on Spotify?

There is not much there for my mind to connect to. Because I never just hear music ‚Ä¶ I relate to music, and to the emotions and people behind them.

That includes someone banging around on kitchen utensils. Still an emotion, and a person there. Or even when I mishear or misunderstand the lyrics of a song. Misunderstandings are part of the relationships between humans, there is still something to relate to.

Would I listen to monkey music? Sure, and I would relate to whatever the monkey does, as a monkey.

Would I listen to 100% generated AI music? Sure, and I would wonder how the AI comes up with it, and what it means.

Would I listen to music from a trained AI that imitates the music it is trained on? Sure, and I would wonder what songs trained the AI, and what the human felt and thought who selected that particular song.

It doesn‚Äôt have to be an active thought, it often is just an instinctive reaction to what I hear and see ‚Ä¶ I automatically associate feelings, situations, performances, instruments, people and more. But now I can also associate AI and the people who use it. This can be just another thing on the palette. But when the art is cheaply imitating others, then it is not so interesting to me.

I don‚Äôt think we are capable of separating art completely from its creation. Even for Banksy art, we all wonder who Banksy is and what he or she or they might think and feel. Even when we don‚Äôt know the name of the artist or the title of the art.

Provenance matters to us ‚Ä¶ because it just does! It is what makes the art relatable. Even if we don‚Äôt know much about where some art comes from, then the speculation about it, the mystery, is part of the art. Think of Mona Lisa. Who is she and what does her smile mean? We want to know, or at least we want to speculate. That is what makes Mona Lisa fascinating. There is nothing about the picture itself that is particularly different from other pictures in that style. The smile is mysterious by itself, yes. But why?

Can an AI come up with a Mona Lisa? Yes, of course! But it takes a person to see that the AI-generated Mona Lisa is ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù in some way. And others can feel the same way about it. So, we really relate much more to the person who said: ‚Äúthis is interesting‚Äù than to the AI.

An AI can, in principle, just generate any form of art (simply by iteratively generating all possible art ‚Äî it would take aeons to do that, but in principle it could do it). Or an AI can imitate any artist‚Äôs art, and even meld it with the art of other artists. But it would be endlessly boring to look at every piece of ‚Äúart‚Äù chucked out by an AI. What we care about is the pieces of AI art that a human pre-selected for us ‚Ä¶ because they found them relatable.

A face on the Moon or on Mars is much more interesting and relatable when we think (and feel) that some beings created them. When weather and erosion created them, then they are still beautiful, but as an act of nature, and we relate to that in a different way. And if it was an AI who created these faces, then we want to know who created the AI, and why.

In the end, AI is a tool. This will only change at the point where AI becomes indistinguishable from a human, in all aspects. And at that point we have the deeply disturbing problem of finding out what makes humans human. Including consciousness, and how our experience of existing in the world works. We will be in deep trouble at that point, because we don‚Äôt really know how to find answers for these questions.

When I was a kid, I wanted to be an artist, a musician, and I also wanted to create video games. I got my first guitar and keyboard at 8 years old, just cheap $100 starter instruments, but never had lessons due to being poor. As a teenager I kept messing around with the instruments, but just wasnt as advanced as other people my age due to me just not putting in the time to practice and work through the sounding bad parts to get to the sounding good parts. Same with drawing - I pretty much gave up because it require way too much discipline and time that I would rather spend hanging out with friends, reading, or playing video games.
Then when I was 17, I finally got serious about art and music. I really wanted to express myself through those mediums. So I spent my free time playing guitar, playing piano, drawing everything around me, and learning the techniques that great artists and musicians use to create great music and art. It took a bit of patience, but within a year, there was a difference, and that made me want to see how much better I could get. It was a journey that made every work of art or piece of music not simply a reflection of my emotions or place in life, but a stillframe of a moment in my journey to better the skills that I had been working on and dreaming of since I was a little kid.
I'm 38 now. I play guitar, piano, cello, and bass. I sing, I draw, I do tattoos, and love using graphite more than anything as an artist.
Now, I have started to attempt to write a little bit of code, and am creating pixelated textures that I can use when creating custom levels in Quake 1 - this is the very beginning of that last dream I had as a kid, to create video games. I don't expect it to be something I make a living doing, but it's something I'm passionate about. I am patient, and I know that my patience and dedication to the hobby will yield results, as it would for anyone who spent the time trying instead of using a text prompt and expecting a copyrighted work of art.

I really really appreciate this video actually addressing AI as it actually is (rather than from some sort of weird place of ignorance). I've long been saying that there are arguments against it, but people weren't making them, or weren't making them well. That said, I have a few notes:

Programming is an interesting AI case, because folks just entering the industry (or folks without any experience) think writing code is the hard part, and it absolutely IS NOT. The hard part is asking the right questions and actually conceptualizing the full scope and impact of your intent. Easily the worst part of these code generators is that when wired together into a complex system, debugging becomes nightmare level because every component is essentially a black box to the person who made it. AI debugging will surely happen someday, but afaik no one has introduced anything like that currently (and I suspect that it will be one of the harder problems, as often times "errors" weren't errors when the software was written and are only errors because of changes in the environment the software runs in, or changes in the usage or requirements for it.)


It isn't clear if humans are actually any more capable of originality than the computer is -- a computer's originality comes from random numbers very explicitly, but human creatively necessarily also just comes from random numbers, albeit, in the form of small variations in current between synapses or errors in transcription of memories or other such elements. (Unless you believe that minds are not merely a system made out of your meat -- in which case, well, I'm not going to find your reasoning convincing.)

"My work isn't just remixing everything I've read, it's reinterpreting though my own subjective experience." Uh... what do you think your subjective experience and biases _are_? Are they not the messily synthesized sum of everything you've ever seen and experienced, plus any random errors in storage and retrieval? The main difference is that the current AI models that are widely accessible to the public are purpose-specific. So you have an LLM trained exclusively on text or an image generator trained exclusively on images. When they start being trained cross domain the difference between AI models and human cognition gets blurrier and blurrier.

Human's writing inspired stories DO result in lawsuits ALL THE TIME. (It's just that people suing lose those lawsuits.) Artist also get very very weird with each other over "copying their style", which indeed is a thing that you can't copyright but an awful lot of young-un's seem to think you can (and I see that carried over to these discussions -- the fact that it reproduced your style is not where copyright infringement could have taken place -- it's the training that leads to the new illustration that's at question, not the result.)

Current AI algorithms are, indeed, not doing what people do. I'd argue its more like we trained a pool of ... mmm... jellyfish or sponges to reproduce art. It takes so so so much data because it's ability to "understand" things is so very limited. That, however, is changing rapidly. One major area of study is to reduce training set sizes -- there are many strategies toward this, but ultimately it boils down to giving the AI more context to work from, more knowledge of the world. They're becoming legitimately smarter. And while "AGI" isn't a thing with a horizon anyone should take seriously (because its goalposts are on rocket sleds), everything in AI is improving at an astounding speed. Improving doesn't merely mean getting better at reproducing some person's art without horrow-show hands, it means actually making the system smarter.

Another use of this kind of "AI" that no one ever talks about and treats as perfectly fine is Google Translate, which is actually where this kind of "deep learning" was first deployed at this kind of massive scale. It was initially trained on things like UN documents, which are not copyrighted, but the Google search of the last 10 years is trained off of every localized web page on the internet, exactly like all of the other AI models going on now. If it's ok, then these others must be, and if they aren't, then it can't be either.

"Training it right" would insulate the companies but it wouldn't actually protect artists, all of the material harm would be the same. The only difference would be in the interior of the Machine, which artists have in visibility into, so maybe that resolves "ethical" issues but it doesn't actually resolve any of the material impact on the artists. And I've gotta say, I don't really care about anything other than the material impact on the artists. If my work is copied and I never know about it and it does not materially impact me, I don't understand why I should care. In fact, I don't understand why we should entertain someone caring in that circumstance.

The clown-shoes AI CEOs are deeply living in Silicon Valley Venture Capital culture. They're basically the same as Uber and a dozen other companies. The Valley has basically decided that laws don't actually apply to them, because they have enough money to just pay and ignore fines. Unfortunately, that's worked out for them thus far so I'd expect more of that behavior over time.

You covered the Google book decision, but that was specifically testing if Google could share excerpts of copyright work. AI training really doesn't align with that, as you noted. What it does align with is Search. Search has been ruled legal in different cases with different criteria. A discussion of this topic is not complete without addressing that.

(I also feel very weird about these discussions because I find the idea of ownership of artistic expression and other IP as fundamentally offensive. I feel weird, but none of that is properly relevant because deconstructing copyright law and other IP laws should not done by effing over the individuals currently depending on it [the corps can rot though].)

I think the main reason the artists are so against their art being in the database is because you could get the AI to generate art in their style without paying them, whereas before if you wanted art in their unique style you would have to go to the artist. The argument boils down to the potential loss of income from people getting art elsewhere, which seems fair to me.

If the value of human-created art comes from the process, then human artists have nothing to fear because people will continue to purchase human art for that reason. The problem is, people (generally) won't continue to purchase human art for that reason, because they put more value results.

Now, let's say that "real art" is always process driven, and AI art is fake art. Great!! Where does this leave us? People using fake art instead of real art. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄ
It really doesn't matter what we do with semantics, people will gravitate toward a perceived value.

The final limitation is that people cannot keep the context of a larger application in their head, so they will not be able to give instructions for features that are internally consistent. Their instructions will inevitably end up being inconsistent with what already exists, on a fundamental logical level. That cannot be solved by the AI, but it might be able to catch it and help humans change their expectations on what is actually going to work. Essentially, what tech leads and architects have been doing for product managers for ages. :)

I‚Äôm not sure if this is on topic, but this discussion has got me thinking about something. Would any art that an AGI (Artificial General intelligence) produced be considered ‚Äòinspired‚Äô or just ‚Äòcopied‚Äô. Before we explore this some more, I think we need a definition on the difference between AGI and the current AIs (also called weak or narrow AIs). ‚ÄúAGI is the ability of an intelligent agent to understand or learn any intellectual task that a human being can.‚Äù ‚ÄúStrong AI contrasts with weak AI (or narrow AI), which is not intended to have general cognitive abilities; rather, weak AI is any program that is designed to solve exactly one problem.‚Äù Note however that I got this from Wikipedia, as I don‚Äôt specialize in any AI or robotics field, so the definition I provided may be off. If anyone in the comments could provide a better definition or contrast that would be appreciated. There‚Äôs a distinction to be made between two definitions of ‚Äúcriticism‚Äù: the side that is about reviewing for the general public as a kind of consumer guide, and the side that is about reflection, interpretation and contextualisation. The former can be useful, but it‚Äôs limited and can often be reductive, frequently distorted by market pressure, and I can see why artists often hate critics who see themselves as arbiters of public taste. The latter can be an art form in itself, can participate in a dialogue between art and criticism, and can even shape the future of art and give birth to art movements. In the world of video games, it‚Äôs the distinction between arguing about whether a game deserved an 8 out of 10 because it was a bit short and had some graphical glitches, and thoughtful, often moving video essays by people like Jacob Geller who situate games within cultural, technological, political and personal contexts. I don‚Äôt read a lot of music criticism myself, but the difference might be between a Fantano and someone like the late Mark Fisher, or the various 33 1/3 books about great albums that go deep into the work, its history, its context and its cultural impact.

Great video, however there might me a misconception on why A.I is a problem, on the current state of things (there is no misunderstanding - referring to the misunderstanding 1 you addressed - by most artists as far as I could research, the problem is not whether A.I is ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúbad‚Äù, or what was intended for.

I‚Äôd say yes, there is unethical issues happening with AI, and it‚Äôs not (or not only) by the people using it and deliberately committing plagiarism.

The main problem is, AI was fed (there was content put onto its database, without the consent of the creators of those contents), which is in on itself, a violation of the artists rights!

The creators of A.I (and here it means, all of the AIs, such as image creators, music creators, text creators and such) literally stole from artists/creators to feed into the algorithm.

A.I might not be inherently bad, but it started wrong!
Considering it was fed content without consent, it needs to be undone/deconstructed, to be reconstructed ethically this time.

On a coding level it needs to be rewritten; specially on the sourcing part, and all its database needs to be erased and started from scratch with proper consent. A.I needs to be redone to be ethical and safer.

Yes, on the other hand, there might be a misuse of the A.I Tools. But there are already legal protections against plagiarism.
That is virtually a non-issue on the sense that the law predicts protection and punishment accordingly.

The problem with the misuse by the user are the deep fakes, the plagiarisms‚Ä¶ and that is another can of worms‚Ä¶.

But also, when it comes to the creators of A.I, or any new tech, it should always be considered and weighted against misuse‚Ä¶ like the atomic era, should wmd devices had not been created to begin with, then no one could have used against others.

So, in creating new technology, its harmful implications should also be considered, and the creator(s) is/are in some measure, responsible for the misuse of the users of the product it created. Even more so if it was created in such shady and unethical way as A.I has when compiling its database.

Furthermore, the misuse of the tool can have daunting and irreparable consequences; such as deep fakes and all the cascading effects that can come from this to the victims and to whoever might be influenced by the deep fake that an A.I might have created‚Ä¶
And safety measures must be put in place.

In fact, they should have been put in place before launching it, and the sourcing should have been done on a different level‚Ä¶. and that brings again the lack of ethics in creating the A.I tools as they were made‚Ä¶

No thoughts on implications, safety measures, misuse, what even would be ‚Äúproper‚Äù use, privacy and copyright rights, none of that were taken into consideration before it‚Äôs general launch.

I‚Äôm a college art student (at an art-specific school) studying to be in the character design industry for video-games. I was discussing this exact topic with one of my traditional media professors today, among some classmates, so allow me to share a college-art students‚Äô perspective.

Seeing AI‚Äôs power is scary. My professor shared my worry in discussing my career path- but not at all in a discouraging way, more of a, ‚Äúmake sure you stand out in your field, work to be very unique‚Äù sort of way. When discussing it with my peers earlier this morning, we agreed that it can be a very helpful tool, but more often it‚Äôs upsetting. Hearing that Kim Jung Gi‚Äôs art, (an extremely respected illustrator among creatives, and for good reason) was stolen and uploaded to these databases without his family‚Äôs consent a while ago infuriated me to my very core. It‚Äôs horrible. This happened the day directly after he passed.

If there were regulations, and artists were fairly compensated for their work being used, I think more creatives would be okay with the programs, but at the moment, it‚Äôs more than a slight cause of anxiety.

On tiktok, I see younger artists feeding their work into the programs, and being amazed at the results. I find that this is very harmful- most often, the AI completely changes the work- and while it may be cool to see, often using the programs removes a lot of emotion out of pieces. If there‚Äôs any advice I have for younger artists, it‚Äôs that- while it‚Äôs fun to mess around with AI (it can be a helpful tool! It‚Äôs not taboo) please don‚Äôt lean on it. The best way to improve is practice, studies, and more specifically studying your favorite artists‚Äô techniques.

I think you need to distinguish 'coding as assembling of blocks' from 'algorithm development'.
The latter isn't just looking up an existing solution and adapting it.
But AIs will be able to invent new algorithms soon (beyond just e.g. finding more optimal matrix multiplication algorithms).
And while people could choose to set things up for 'natural language to computation', that would be a terrible mistake, turning every piece of code into a black box a human couldn't inspect and understand.
Instead there will be a hierarchy of representations, natural language and diagrams/videos at the top, down through various more detailed and concrete levels, until you get to assembler and then finally machine code.
Jumping straight from natural language to machine code would be unwise for a large variety of reasons.
