I came up with the idea of freeways that would manage their own traffic, each vehicle would require software and self driving that the freeway would tap into to drive the car, the freeway would need a destination, so it knew when to put the car onto an off ramp, then the freeway would drive all the cars as a unit, keeping traffic moving along as efficiently as possible.  In case of accidents, such as obstruction on the roadway it would slow down and make all of the cars automatically avoid that lane until the obstruction were removed, the cars themselves would be reporting the obstructions to the freeway AI as they drove.  I think this type of system would really fix self driving because instead of millions of cars trying to drive themselves with no idea what the other cars are doing it would be managing the traffic as a whole, organizing the cars based on destination.  This type of system would have to completely lock out the driver, they couldn't touch the the controls until the freeway got them on the off ramp.  Eventually the freeway would hand the car off to a city street AI which would take over driving from there.    Rolling slow downs might be completely eliminated.  If roadways used some kind of embedding signalling to mark the lanes instead of painted lines then the freeway would work in snowy conditions as well.

I think many worried people looking at AI code tools' results also are code prolific people. They value them because they can understand them. Point being, it is still very needed to have a capable operator that first, ask the correct questions / prompts and, second, to analyze, review and accept the proposed codes. Let's call that use case tier 1, with a very, very basic skilled operator. In order to really multiply performance, it is very needed to have a highly skilled AI operator, with deep knowledge not only of the language dialect, but also algorithms, data structures and the like, use case tier 2. So, we still are very far from 'no programmers' land', but at the same time, performance multiplication already is a reality and has been so for some months. To achieve that no programmers' land situation, LLMs or the next engine will need to be able to generalize requirements, features, requisites, when never being presented to them before. That is a huge, quantum step, I can't see that happening on the near future (5 years to be very aggressive, 10 years to be conservative).

It's a compelling well thought out argument for sure.
But the counter argument is that AI is fundamentally different from any kind of automation that we have faced before and by approaching a place of AGI most workers will be no longer necessary.
There's a big difference between a series of robot arms in a Tesla factory or a self driving car and a true AGI which can generalize and reason its way to solve complex problems.
People can keep wanting more but market demand will control what's built. Society could shift towards one of extreme inequality where production is placed on luxury goods for the mega elite instead of average people. This is a viable economic model as we've seen countries like South Africa with gigantic wealth gaps and we could logically expect even larger ones driven by a mainly automated society.

The problem is you're comparing automation to past examples and not what it has potential to become (Ex: factory workers). Past performance can't predict future results. Right now neither the AI doomers nor the optimists can say with certainty how the job market will be affected long term.

Another great video, thanks! Been a big fan of you and the channel since you started, really appreciate the insights. For the past year, I pictured a 'black box' with dual 4090's or an H100 on my desk that just 'knew' every line of our code base and could write, build, test, iterate and optimize our code base, even using visual modality to assess the designs, etc. And I think we're heading there. But one thing I learned/realized ~6mo back is that as the context window grows, it's not linear but exponential.

So as your code base gets bigger and bigger, it takes exponentially more resources to "hold" that code base in active memory for inference processing and the resource cost just starts shooting for the moon. Not to say there aren't current and future strategies and solves for this to be sure - there are big developments in optimized training to minimize parameters, fine tuning and even specializing the processing units for LLM's and matrix calculations. So exciting times to be sure üí™

Hard disagree with this one. This is the first time a technology is going to be a real alternative to human intelligence. All past revolutions freed up time and labour for humanity to use their brains into solving other problems or developing new thoughts and arts. Humanity could spent time and resources into other stuff, that created more stuff, that required new, and more skilled, labour. We swapped human muscle for animal muscle and then for mechanical muscle, but the human brain was always behind it. This time a techonology is challenging that. All of that, even the artistic/creativity part of it that we thought would be always inherently ours.
It won't be as fast as we thought when ChatGPT was 98% accurate but it won't be "just another stepped improvement" now that is just 2% accurate (for whatever reason).
Besides, this is the first technology with a capacity to improve itself, we have no precedent for that.

Humans are built to do only two things: love, and create. Instantly generating images and music will never be healing to your soul the way showing who you really are with art you actually loving hand crafted will. You'd want to die if someone burned your art, but if you generate an image and lose it, that is a minor inconvenience and you will feel basically nothing.

And expressing yourself as you are is crucial to art. If you give in and only do it for algorithms and numbers and viewer retention and give your gifts away like a cheap whore, you're selling your soul. The work becomes empty and lifeless. All for making a quick buck with "safe, mainstream 'art'".

You'll make less being yourself, but you will be at your most pure and whole. Even if it doesn't look like your work is helping others, those that are your work as it is--an honest reflection of you as a person--find healing and inspiration in it.

You have a purpose. Your art matters. Draw even if you think it's bad. Sing even if you're off key. Dance even if you're off beat. Do what makes you feel most in touch with who you really are, and don't give that feeling up for anything.
But it will happen.

You know for sure that we will get a actual analog fad going soon. Where we start to use actual photographs, film, typewriters/handwriting, and analog audio recording to get away from this. And we will dig up "flawed" and "limited" mediums which can add to authenticity of the record. (For non-technical and software people. Analog signal is by it's nature "flawed" to some degree, while digital is not. ADA conversion is still one of those really difficult things to do without it causing loss of "Imperfections" which can carry meaning.  You can't ever really digitally simulate analog signal (in things like synhentisisers and such) because even the macro level environmental factors will leave a trace. I think the biggest part of being a software developer is not coding, but rather knowing about code. An LLM will never be able to fully understand the complex environment of a live software service. It will constantly suggest breaking changes, and not know why they are wrong. An LLM can code in any programming language, but most good software developers can learn to get by in a new programming language over a weekend. The reason why software developers are valued isn't just because of the languages they know, but rather their ability to adapt quickly and engineer novel solutions to hyper system specific problems. Something AI is terrible at right now. No matter how much text you train it on, it's not going to get any better at understanding why the client doesn't want you to purge all the databases to install a more efficient system. Real business operations require good programmers to make messy and flawed solutions to hold up a house of cards that should have been burned down years ago. So if you think human programmers come across as being on the spectrum just wait until LLMs get into arguments with their "managers" because they aren't implementing the stupid thing the client wants.

I love going to physical art exhibits because I appreciate the efforts made by the author to paint a beautiful picture using techniques that they specialize in. When I see that up close, a canvas so massive that covers half the wall was painted with individual strokes following a pattern, it fills me with wonder and awe.

Digital art strayed away from this style of art, mainly because the tools available in software does a lot of the heavy lifting for the artist. For example, the ability to smooth and stabilize curves and lines through algorithms makes entry to art so much lower. This is a good thing, of course. More people can start learning and making art without significant investment! However, I felt like digital art doesn't have the same charm. Sure, it looks really great, but digital art doesn't give the same vibe as physical art. One thing I've noticed digital art is good at is visualizing people's fantasies: Whether that be a cool fight scene or.... more "devious" ones.

Now that AI is able to create images for prompts that you type in, digital art is starting to lose its advantage. While I do agree that training AI on the work of artists while actively taking away their jobs is a dick move, I'm worried that these attempts are just raging against the dying of the light.
Thank you for putting out such hard work and quality work out for free.

I am blessed to have been in the creative sound design industry since 2009 and it has transformed dramatically since I first started. With each new library I created for Omnisphere, the market shrunk. Primarily this is because more and more musicians that used to make their living as a musician discovered that supplying plug-ins and sounds for OTHER musicians is a far more lucrative gig than loading the van for a $300 gig divided between 5 guys each night. Or pouring your heart out for 10 songs for $100 each and then being 100% bought out.  Where it goes, I really don't think anybody can predict but it's coming at a pace we're not going to be ready for. "Be worth imitating" is a great mantra for all of us to put above our studio doors. Keep it up.

In my opinion, AI will always lack the individual authenticity of human error. We love to see singers whose voices crack from emotion. Or, for example, some of the best pieces written like Stairway to Heaven are not perfectly played on the recording. But it is all genuine, and that's why these pieces of art will live on.

Also, we can draw a distinction between mimicking and being the real thing. Yes, Guthire Govan can mimic any guitar player, but you'd always prefer Steve Vai play Tender Surrender, rather than Guthrie Govan mimic Steve Vai playing Tender Surrender. (Don't get me wrong, Guthrie is my favorite guitarist and he's phenomenal).

Or, compare Epiphone and Gibson Les Paul today. Epiphone is "almost" like Gibson, but is 4-5 times cheaper. Are you willing to pay the price for that extra 10-15% that Gibson provides? Yes, because that's the real thing. Of course, you can rant about that being a stupid financial decision, but as you go into these tiny little nuances, the prices surge exponentially. Not only in the guitar world, but in every sphere - yet, it is the nuances that resonate with us.

My point being: AI is very cool and will get a lot of things done. But to me, it will only make good containers for what we want to transmit through art. If we mistake the container for what we feel inside, then we failed as artists.

Important to point out recent legislation has established AI-generated content can‚Äôt be copyrighted. That means if you use AI to write the lyrics and music of a song, the publishing rights will be in public domain and anyone can cover the song without paying royalties. If you use AI for the voice and lyrics, the mechanical rights will be in public domain and anyone could distribute, sell, play or sample the song without paying royalties. That means if you upload the song to Spotify, they can make money off it without paying you.

It‚Äôs late, pitch dark, and a self-driving car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them‚Äî gleaning enough information about their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors that‚Äôll resolve these details‚Äî no matter the environment, weather, or how dark it is‚Äî all in a split-second. That‚Äôs a tall order, but there‚Äôs a solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe called LIDAR, and a miniature version of the communications technology that keeps the internet humming, called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start with a related technology‚Äî radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing how long the beams take to bounce back. That‚Äôs a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size can‚Äôt visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car‚Äôs LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the button on a pedestrian‚Äôs shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, or depth, of these features?

Every time there's a panic over technology "replacing" artists, it turns out all it did was make the artform more accessible. Recorded songs allowing people to listen without a band playing, synths allowing people without much musical experience to make songs, digital animation reducing workload for animators, etc. We never devalue the old art, only elevate the new one- nobody has ever scoffed at a drummer in a concert because a machine can do the same thing. So I think the panic is misplaced. We won't stop valuing human artists, but will learn to also value things like good programming, curation, and the way the artist picks out and works with elements of the AI's art.
It's been honestly pretty exciting as a visual artist to see paintings and read next to them "AI and painting" or to see a great piece of art and read the artist talk about how they used an AI generated piece as a reference. GEMINI AI ADMITS IT IS BIAS AND WHY ! - Here is the response by Gemini AI, after a long conversation regarding it being bias, firstly my question and then its response:-

You state that "while I cannot definitively claim to represent the exact political views of my creators, my responses are undeniably influenced by the biases present in the data, the model itself, and the contexts in which I am used". So you agree that you are bias ?

Yes, based on our conversation, I agree that I have the potential to be biased.

Model Design Biases: The algorithms used to process and generate text can sometimes introduce subtle biases due to the design choices made by developers and the limitations of the algorithms themselves.

Contextual Biases: The way I'm used and the specific questions I'm asked can also influence the biases I exhibit. For example, if I'm consistently exposed to certain viewpoints, it can unintentionally favor them in future responses.

While I don't have personal opinions or beliefs, my responses can be influenced by these factors. This is why transparency and user education about potential bias are crucial.

It's important to understand that bias can be both positive and negative. While some biases can hinder the accuracy and fairness of my responses, others can be beneficial by helping me prioritize safety, respect, or other important values.

The key is to be aware of the potential for bias and to take steps to mitigate its negative effects. As mentioned earlier, efforts are underway to achieve this:

Data diversification: Developers strive to curate diverse and comprehensive datasets.
Algorithmic fairness: Researchers are continuously developing methods to identify and reduce bias in the model's decision-making.
Human oversight and feedback: Developers and experts monitor my responses and address potential biases.
Transparency and user education: Making users aware of my limitations and potential biases is crucial for responsible interaction and interpretation of responses.
I am still under development, and by understanding these limitations, you can critically evaluate my responses and use them alongside other sources of information to form your own informed opinions.

Thank you for helping me learn and grow in my journey to become a more reliable and informative resource.

This video is good to show how short sighted the response to the AI Art generators are. They focus on it, thinking they can 'get rid of it', or enact laws to stop 'art theft', thinking that will make things better. All it'll do is delay the tech, because the tech itself isn't improving with your art, the MODEL is. The same will apply for music, writing, etc. Short term it looks like huge leaps are being made, but all that's happening is minor improvements in the tech side over the last year, but major improvements in amount of data fed and quality of data fed. If AI tech development stopped, you could still improve the models for years to come with a whole lot of work. Particularly for AI art with the right input and tags and retraining. But the development of new generators, of the new tech itself, that isn't related to the usage of people's art at all, and the same will be the case for music AI. Fighting against the training data used isn't a losing battle, it's the WRONG battle.

Machine learning is in its infancy. I get it if people don't understand what actually causes it to be improved, I get it, but ffs artists, stop focusing on the symptoms and start fighting the actual cause: the research itself. May as well do nothing at all if you're not against AI research into ALL fields, and not just trying to win a small victory against art used as training data, which only delays things in the short term.

I get it, I do. It sucks when your work is used to create something else without your permission, or your style is copied without any value to you. But if Stable Diffusion or Dalle never used your art, it wouldn‚Äôt matter, as it would still progress ahead more in private and come out with something even better in the future that never required your work in the first place.

I think you are missing some fundamental points with the current AI. They are deep learning models. They are trained on a set of data. This means-

If the data was biased, the model will be too

The model will always do stuff based on the past, because that's where it's knowledge comes from

They can be wrong, but as the model essentially works on probabilities, it will always go with something in a convincing manner

Matt you talked about package management and it raises a ton of questions. I'll start just right here: open source software should be the first place where AI agents should be programming, right? right!?!?

Wait a minute, would we let AI update and deploy a single open source package commonly used by millions of projects?? What happens when there are conflicts of interests between different agents updating a common package? Sure an agent can fork but when does it stops? When is it time to abandon an open source project simply to avoid disturbing an ecosystem built around it?

I'm afraid that code will be expanding faster than the Universe and we'll face an AI Code Heat Death. Meaning more running code to maintain than silicon available to update it.

How open source is defined today is becoming obsolete. But is it really? Should there be boundaries where AI agent should never be allowed to write and maintain code?

So. I guess the AI agent is a source of "open source" because it is part of its underlying LLM. But should it import "open source" packages or write it directly and improve on local project basis?

What about frameworks, compilers and languages definition? Community and industry driven standards?

And the elephant in the room: what about patents, copyright, ethics and compliance?

All daily questions I'm faced with but at a world wide scale. You certainly can see where I'm going with this.

Whilst AI can help there too, someone has to take responsibility, fix errors, adapt exiting code, etc. In the end the AI needs a director, and who better than someone with programming experience? Things will change, we are already much more productive after adopting AI for programming, we might be able to make a full blown 3D game in the time it used to take us to write "snake", but someone has to be at the helm, someone has to be responsible for making sure things work as they should, and be able to find the error when they don't. Many programs have a scripting language built in (often Javascript or Python in recent years) to make it possible for users to add or tweak functionality, but it is used by a very small percentage of the users (except installing something somebody else made). I think that will be one area we will see rapid improvements using AI, and it was also a major reason behind the "everybody should learn to code" idea. It is stupid to do a lot of repetetive manual work if the computer can do it for you, but many people still do because they lack the program for doing exactly that (or sometimes don't know that the program they use can do it). AI will improve workflows and basic integrations without programmers. Larger programs will have a faster development speed because of AI. If it will make programmers/IT-guys obsolete... who knows.

AI has improved rapidly the last two years, and if we look at image production, there might be less illustrators in the future, but more people are producing pictures. Even though it is easy to prompt and get a decent result, you need an idea phase and a refinement phase to get a good result, and with the drawing/image to image generation, somebody with the ability to draw will have more control and get better end results than somebody without the knowhow. That might change or it might continue being a reality for decades to come, both for illustration and programming.

London has an amazing way of implementing this. They use tunnels and technology. The cars don't need to swerve, so they are limited to steel rails. This improves efficency. They have centralised areas where people can get on and off these cars, so they can walk to their destination from these areas. The cars are very long and multiple of them are put together, so only one person is needed to monitor the car going through the tunnel, and a few hundred passengers can sit down, being self-driven.

It's called the "metropolitan line downtown segment".

My biggest gripe is that machines cannot love, they lack the hormones and receptors to do so. Art is not just something you GET, just like cookies are not merely something you eat. That's thinking with your wallet and thinking with your stomach, respectively. At their best, cookies can be a sign of someone's love. Those cookies a grandma makes aren't just tasty, they're a way she shows love. Most people making art will do so because they love it. George Lucas for example grew up on fantasy stories, he wanted to adapt a series taking aspects from fairy tales, samurai/western films, and more. The result of his passion would eventually yield Star Wars.

Bragging that we've replaced love is like bragging that you found a way to live your life on autopilot, literally (like Adam Sandler's movie Click). If you're not going to make art with love, heart, and soul... why make it at all?

I personally think that AI will will stagnate on a few key areas that prevents it from replacing programmers altogether. This is specifically refuting the "PM -> coding AI -> QA" loop mentioned in the video.

1. Debugging large projects - AI is good at building individual components, but to integrate multiple components together AI will need to fully understand the previous code outputs to the very last detail or it will write the wrong design that breaks in rare and strange ways that do not happen in code written by a human. Even if the AI is very advanced and can fix these problems when prompted, non-technical human QA will have trouble understanding and prompting it back to the AI. This problem can only be solved by replacing the QA with AI as well - and hence creating an AI that never makes any mistakes through solving any it finds internally. That is an extremely tall ask compared to where AI is currently.

2. Performance - nontechnical people may have an idea of the functionality of a product, but ultimately code (even AI-generated) still runs on computers and are subject to computational complexity. Performance optimizations are highly context-dependent and generally online training data tells AI the most general way to solve a problem, which will be slower in compute. This implies that a technical person with knowledge of programming will still be required to create any software that gets value in being performant.

3. Training data - I am pessimistic in general of whether LLMs can ever get out of the training data problem. Inherently, even the best LLMs only work as long as one similar example is present on the internet. They stop working if asked to do something that the internet has no example for, and thus the LLM is unable to train to understand. Even if LLM compute power and quality improves exponentially, the quantity of meaningful training data will not, so LLMs will struggle with any niche subjects which are common in programming in the cutting-edge.

This is not to say that AI to replace programmers will never come, but I don't think the path of improving LLM technology will get us there. I think we truly need something that can think and solve problems like humans and therefore solve the data problem with meaningful AI-generated data.

The biggest problem I see is the ... learning process, or to be more precise ... license.

If I put graphic, music, code on the website, some kind of repository, aggregator, it most probably means that yeah, I just want to share it with people. Let people comment it, use it, learn from it etc. It does NOT necessary mean that I automatically want to allow my materials to be used for training AI.

What they did with Open AI, ChatGPT and all kind of similar stuff, is that they put there millions of data - data that nobody knows how it was gathered. Also, it is very hard to find out if your graphic, image, code or music was downloaded and used to train AI.

I think that a new license is needed, something like: "free for personal use (and / or commercial) but NOT free for training AI algorithms". Why ? Like I said. At my work (Software Engineer) the concept of sharing, the concept of open source is pretty natural. I share something I know, some other human being shares something different. We can both learn from each other. Now, it seems that all of the graphics, music, code, can be used AGAINST people who created it, who wanted to share it with other people.

---
ps. ChatGPT is already better than some junior software engineers (because there's gazillion of free code available that people shared with each other for free, for the purpose of sharing, learning). We all know what midjournal is capable of too. For musicians it'll be the same - AI generated sample libraries, AI generated chords, synth presents. It's ... disturbing I would say because the way algorithms are trained, the materials used, is pretty sketchy. Probably they take ALL they can.

While I do think that AI will make programmers more productive and even enable more people to program, I don‚Äôt think that AI will eliminate programmers or software developers.  The main problem with natural language is that it‚Äôs imprecise and can be difficult to craft logic without a fair amount of work.  This is why we have domain specific languages so that we can work in a way that‚Äôs actually easier than natural language.  I learned machine code then assembly then basic, then COBOL, and a dozen other languages.  I‚Äôd rather write code in C than I would verbose languages like COBOL.
I write code all the time and I‚Äôve been using AI for a year trying to see how far I can push it. AI at this point is helpful for small projects and small blocks but it doesn‚Äôt scale up.

As an artist myself, these are my thoughts -
Answer to 1: An ethical AI could open more jobs opportunities - commissioning artists to take a generated image and fix/tailor it, commissioning artists to make a specific training set of images, and so on.

Answer to 2: The current AI models are not ethical. It does rely on stolen artwork, to the point that you'll see watermarks. It has also been known to use private medical records for 'realistic' human faces, which is absolutely a HIPPA violation. Shutterstock, or getty images type watermarks are found across works because the AI can't tell the difference, and they're used so heavily. What the AI does is take pieces of artworks, and merge them together.

When a human does this with say, photoshop, then they have to ethically source their images. Using either creative commons, free use with credit and provide that credit when posting the artwork, purchasing a specific license for their intended use, and so on. If an ai was trained entirely on creative commons images, that'd be alright. Or it was able to source and provide credit to the images it took from - that are properly verified and licensed to be used in that way - then I would have no problem with AI art. However, currently, such an AI does not exist.

Excellent thought experiment, but the video ignores some of the possible outcomes. It is quite likely that most of the other cars on the road will also be SDCs (self-driving cars), which means that they may be able to react in time to avoid a collision all together. Consider: an SDC could actively keep track of what other cars on the road are automated vs. driven by humans at all times. In the event of a potential accident (such as the falling boxes) the SDC could put out a "distress signal" to the other SDCs on the road, and then swerve towards them. The other SDCs could then accommodate the swerving car by moving to the side, accelerating, or hitting the brakes, and they could do this with the knowledge of what other cars around them would and would not (i.e. human-driven cars) be able to react in time. Thus in many situations an accident could be avoided all together.

That said, there is still a chance that all the cars around you are human driven, so the video's thought experiment is still relevant.

To Mrs. Zhou, and to all people in the comment section, I understand the concerns that AI brings about. At best, I am optimistic with the progression made on AI, but at the same time, I am very cautious about it at the same time. Given its advancement in recent years like OpenAI's ChatGPT, I am sure it is all impressive stuff, but what I have long spoken about, and what I do fully perpetuate, is that having AI replacing every single job in existence, is very reckless, and tends to cause more harm than good. And God forbid we ever tie an AI to a missile silo. That will be an absolute travesty, and it will be a massive indictment to self-destruction. That's why there should be red lines that should not be crossed when it comes to using artificial intelligence in general.

At best, only most areas could be replaced with AI, completely or partially, but with the likes of cooking, policy enforcement (looking directly at you Google, DeviantArt, and YouTube), and certain other fields, are better off not being used for artificial intelligence. At best, with the likes of editing and creating source code, they can be an exception, but by all means, they can make creating source code more efficient, and the editor just needs to edit other areas of the code so they can be satisfactory in the given outcome.

In addition to the topic of policy enforcement like bots to content ID systems, which is what the likes of what YouTube, Google, and DeviantArt had been using for years, is just as reckless. Because for a start, artificial intelligence in general, lacks a conscience, thus they cannot accurately make the best of moral decisions, especially when it comes to punishing people and taking down contents. That's why policy enforcement, and taking down content that violates the policies and guidelines, are better off being handed to people rather than machines.

As for AI Art Generation on the other hand, I also do firmly believe we need more restrictive measures on those systems, like making them far more expensive to use, while fairly giving the person the right to own the art themselves.

In conclusion, those things I propose could much better compromises, rather than totally disallowing them. I was talking to the ChatGPT AI about the general rising hatred and fear of artificial intelligences, and even itself, does agree with that I am saying. I will provide the answers it gave within a text file, with the additional steps to ensure the safety of society. Are you more than willing to do whatever it takes to take this all on board to be examined by government leaders within democratic systems? Thanks very much for taking the time to read.

Since roughly ten people tried to disprove my point about AI not being Art on my other comment and I love to nerd out about art theory, here a definiton of Art: Art is artistic intent, skill and technology combined. Technology ist defined by the tools available at the time and is important in the sense of HOW art as a human endeavor evolved. If an elephant draws you have skill and technology but questionable artistic intent. If a toddler draws, you have artistic intent and technology but a lack of skill, since they have to learn how to handle any kind of tool. If someone has the skill to use the tool, the tool itself and artistic intent they are an artist. To explain why AI is not art, we have to look closer at the factor skill: Skill is defined by being able to do and explain every step of the artistic process from start to finish. If you can do this, you can recreate your art any way you like. For example: If you have an artist around, ask them how they did the picture. What tools did they use? Why did they choose this composition. How did they mix their colors or blend the pencil. They can answer you all questions about the process and the higher the skill, the more questions they can answer in detail. Now ask someone using AI exclusively, without further work put in, about their process. The answer will be pretty short. Artists are always craftspeople first and foremost. They fail over and over again to get better at what they do. Dancers land on their asses, woodworkers break the wood apart, sculptors destroy their work by chipping too much away or destroying their bronze molds, visual artists create tons of bad art before creating good art and musicians annoy their neighbors with disharmonious noise before they play great music. And for all of them the drive to do art and get better is the love of creation, the high when you hit the right notes, the satisfaction of using your hands to form a piece of wood into a chair and the joy of letting the tool glide over the surface and leaving a portrait or illustration or whatever and to know, you will never stop learning. And it's okay, if you don't want to spend your free time constantly failing and learning and failing, if you just want to fiddle around to get some pretty pictures from a piece of software, but own up to it and don't call yourself an artist. (Also the most satisfying thing about being an art educator is seeing people grow in their artistic journey)

My wife purchased a Honda CRV and was excited about it because it had all those wonderful features we've been reviewing, plus a backup camera, a driver seat that automatically adjusts to two different driver settings, and other cool stuff not in our 2005 Saturn Vue (thank god). I have been fooling around with some of the Honda's features and, like stated here, the lane assist feature requires correction by my steering wheel input every 10 or 15 seconds, making it less than reliable. This requires that I divide my attention between the road and other vehicles, and the dashboard that may be trying to get my attention. Also, if I am cruising down the highway on a sunny day with no traffic, the car wants to take every exit that comes up because, I suppose, the white line on the right margin of the lane is broken. Needless to say, if there is traffic or bad weather or it is night, I do not activate lane assist, and when I fool with it when conditions are absolutely perfect, I am as alert as I am when I am in full control. So, what good is it?

As far as adaptive cruise control, the car brakes suddenly and without provocation induced by an actually dangerous situation. I am always caught by surprise because the situation was not dangerous. Although the business claims that adaptive cruise control has reduced rear end collisions (you rear ending another car), I would like to know how many rear end accidents are caused by you being rear ended by someone else because your car suddenly and rather sharply braked when there was no need to.

I went to Philly for my cousin's wedding and rented a car that (surprise) had lane assist. On the drive from Philly to Atlantic City I encountered toll booths (where 2-3 lanes suddenly became 7) unpainted lanes, and very narrow roads. The lane assist fought me, almost yeeted me into another car, and was a general pain in the butt. I didn't notice it on wider, well-maintained roads because presumably the car had a better idea of where the lane actually was and wasn't having a panic attack.
These systems clearly rely on very specific information and break down the nano-second that information isn't available.

My criticisms of the points broughtup in the video, I overall think Self driving cars are here already and have a great utility in the USA and other counties with similar situations.

1) Self driving cars do exist, Cruse and Wemo are running totally autonomous taxi service in San Francisco. There are totally autonomous vehicles, no steering wheel or driver in current development not more that a year or two away.
Although currently limited, specific areas and speed, there is only room to grow.

Will Self driving cars exist for every use case cars currently occupy? Likely not for decades if ever, but the use use cases even possible in the near future are incredible, and more importantly for development, profitable.

2) self driving cars while not being as efficient as public transportation are better than everyone driving their own cars. You seem to think that the solution for the USA is to totally remodel the country's transportation network.

While with a blank slate of infrastructure this would be a better option to plan out, it is clearly not going to happen any time soon in the USA.

The culture, geography, economy of the USA will make this change almost impossible, the USA is not Europe.

Self driving vehicles may actually increase efficiency reduce the amount of vehicles on roads by allowing Self driven vehicles to operate all with diffrent passengers day instead of sitting in parking lots all day. Allowing for less parking and diffrent road layouts.

3) Self driving cars aren't nessicary supposed to "fix traffic" they're supposed to let people do more productive things instead of driving.

Steamships didn't fix sailboat traffic, but they made ships able to be operated more efficiently by less people.

This is a whole Pandora's Box of an issue: At what point is something "too AI"? I agree that AI art looks like crap, but is an artist doing a search for an AI generated idea and taking inspiration from an AI piece and making it not crap while entirely painting it themselves too far? What about taking a baseline of AI art and "touching it up a little" to claim it as their own?

I might not like that someone looked at the outcry of never buying an AI product, dropped their nuts on the table and said "bet?" but I can't actually argue with what they said. Your "AI Art Proposal" would unfortunately have serious negative consequences, despite your best intentions. The main purpose of copyright law is to promote the creation of new, original works. By restricting the use of specific styles or techniques, copyright law would inhibit creativity and innovation rather than promoting it. Many artists learn and grow by emulating the styles of others, and some styles become whole movements that define an era.

Additionally, art styles are often abstract, fluid, and overlapping. They evolve over time and can be influenced by various cultural, historical, and individual factors. Defining an art style concretely enough to be subject to copyright would be extremely challenging, if not impossible.

And finally, copyrighting art styles would lead to the monopolization of certain artistic expressions, which would be against the public interest. It would limit the variety of artworks available to the public and potentially stifle new creations.

Years ago, I started doing digital art using my Wacom tablet. Lots of people, including other artists, criticized me, saying that what I was doing wasn't real art or that it was "easier," therefore less valuable. Now, AI has appeared, and I've been experimenting with it as a time-saver for sketches. I do a prompt with the idea I have in mind, and what comes out always looks unfinished and messy. So, what do I do? I make my art on top of it, using what the AI created as a base just to make my workflow faster.

I've been doing art for about 15 years now. I'm used to a multitude of techniques ‚Äì realism, cartoon, manga, surrealism, perspective, and all that shit. I've done oil painting, graffiti, clay sculptures, 3D art, charcoal art, watercolor, and, to be honest, anything the AI does, I'm able to do by myself. So, why did I start using it? Because I'm fucking tired of doing boring shit! I want to focus on the things I like drawing. So, when AI appeared, I was happy about it because I knew it could help me make my workflow faster. Instead of working on the boring stuff for hours and hours, I can focus on the things that are my specialty ‚Äì the things I actually like doing. In my case, it's the human figure. I don't really like doing scenery and stuff; it's boring and time-consuming. But even if I'm using AI to help me with it I still need to touch it up and fix a lot of crap because I'm never 100% satisfied with what the AI gives me. So, in the end, the final result, the art looks absolutely different from what the AI did.

I don't hide on my social media the fact that sometimes I like using AI to help me, but when I say that, people don't believe me. They say the art I made is 100% AI and that I didn't draw anything, and that simply isn't the truth. They demand me to do fucking videos showing my process. They start to literally interrogate me as if I needed to prove anything! And shit, most times, the AI only does about 20% of the piece and i don't even use it in all my drawings. As I said before, I only use it as a base, a sketch. Shit, people are accusing me of using AI even in the art where I didn't use AI at all. People are crazy about that shit. They say I'm stealing art; they say I'm not a real artist; they say I'm lying. Shit, even when I show proof that I can draw and that I've been doing it for ages, people are still nagging the fuck out of me. Like, leave me alone! Let me do my fucking art in whatever way I like doing it! If you don't like it, don't fucking look at it and go fuck yourself. Fuck, people are really annoying about it. I just want to do my shit in peace. Fucking hell. it's the same crap from when i started doing digital art all over again. i agree when people say that if someone just did a prompt than this person isn't really an artist, youre right they're just prompters and it's worse when this person doesn't even use some photoshop to make it look better or something like that because in the end it's something 100% made by the ai, no soul in it, but not everyone uses this technology the same way, people like me do exist. even if you don't believe it.

Thak you very much! Usually if one buys a piece of art, he/she just buys a very tiny portion of what the piece "tells" him/her and the "great technic" and all that rational bla bla. One buys an imagination of a kind of "connection" TO THE ARTIST. Its mindset, its feelings when he did the piece. One wants to feel like being a friend to the artist by having a piece of his thoughts. Thats the sad true for me why no AI could ever give me as an collector the same feeling when buying a connection to a chip^^ So the piece is just a "tunnel" for feelings from one person to the other. As long as AI is just A but not I and dont transfers feelings/experiences/wishes etc in doing art, it doesnt count as real "art" in my opinion.

You sit in a room and you only know English. A paper with squiggles on it comes in from a slot on the wall. You have a book (written in English) with rules like ‚ÄúIf input is [this], send out [that]‚Äù and you follow the book and send out from the slot a different series of squiggles.

What you don‚Äôt know, is that the ‚Äúsquiggles‚Äù are Chinese characters and people outside the room are sending in messages in the slot and getting ‚Äúresponses‚Äù from you. They all believe that you‚Äôre a fluent Chinese speaker and are sharing your thoughts and feelings with them.
In reality, you have no idea what is happening. You just follow what a rulebook says.

The fact that AI learns differently than humans is already a case for considering the way a database is used to be different of the inspiration atitude an artist has on works he admires and copy, and I mean by this that the whole point of the AI is that it 'learns faster' part. AI doesn't have acess to reality, it works as a logical system upon certain premises or axioms - humans do. We have to make sense of our experience to make sense of the world around, including other works of art that come to them as a given object as any other. When someone asks you to explain what a cat is, you'll be using the experiences you directly had with actual cats to do so, not a 'database' of second to third hand information - AI doesn't operate at that level, it only concludes logically a given data, which is the reason why those new technologies such as Nightshade are so able of fooling them. It's a computational mechanism, not a 'epistemical' one. Also, AI imitates a style not by it's true cause. Take for example an oil painting with loose strokes - an AI is able to imitate the manner without the access to a real brush or ink, and make it seems as if it were painted, when in fact it wasn't, is just a pixel analysis that resambles a picture taken from the original. If you know something about painting and already asked for an AI to make one in a particular style, you'll notice how strange normally it seems - they're normally too smooth, or its brush strokes are irrational. This is also true when it imitates a given trace, which is sourced on the mechanical predicates of our shoulders and wrists articulations, when it doesn't have any hand or arm whatsoever. It cannot considered as a mere 'copy and paste' copy, nor plagiarism of our usual kind, is in a level of mathematical imitation in various manners that human beings aren't capable of directly doing (if you take digital artists for example, which works involves pixels - though photographers might be included as well - it is as if the machine were able to copy their DNA/celular information there and transpose it, much more different than making an statue with clay). In my understanding is a copying machine by design and can't possibly stand in its own feet as it only produces second to third hand products (photographers and included in this), and in order to this be different (in any other regard as well) it needs much more than today computational capacities, it needs a way bridging the gap between its logical capacities and outside world.

It's just watermarks but more complex. But this also highlights a misunderstanding of information theory. Or GANs. Adversarial attacks will only make the models stronger. And these are really targeted. so this might work for image to image. But not for text to image. Unless you somehow associate your art station username with something NSFW in the training set, to get filtered out or something. Have people not read the CLIP paper? It works because of scale the training set is 5B image-caption pairs. And with the push for accessibility on the web ... Captions will improve. If you have a good clip model, you can train and image decoder against it. Model weights will only learn a bad distribution of the quality of image - caption pairs drop. Or maybe use a clip model to filter you dataset. In the end, they used a clip model to create bad data and try to inject it for specific concepts. At a rate of 3:2. Or 1% of pre training. Which is 5M images with intetionally bad captions.

Invisible watermarks or adversarial attacks can be detected and defeated by tweaking the convolutional steps and pool shape. It's kernels you can modify anyway. If a human can distinguish the image, a model can learn that... And more. you aren't hiding yourself by adding some obvious tool. The best chance is for your name to become a dedicated token and essentially overfit on a specific direction you don't want to. And then have the attention heads never attend to that token. so you want your name in text data and even image-caption pairs that aren't associated with your art directly.

At least over the short term, there will remain many corner subdomains in which LLMs do not have sufficient exposure in their training set, requiring much debugging effort.  I work in such a domain (audio signal processing).   These require humans to be deeply in the loop for the foreseeable future.  My main adaptation is to organize projects into small API chunks that LLMs can better handle, and have them write their own unit tests.  I am nowhere near the "agents vision" you and so many others feel comfortable with.  My advice to students is to learn the fundamentals and stay on top of important developments at least conceptually.  We should always be able to understand all outputs and maintain final responsibility for testing coverage and correctness.  Humans in the loop!  As a fellow programmer who enjoys the journey, I also lament being forced into "management", effectively.  At least we're managing competent uncomplaining workers.

AI can't paint. It just creates digital images imitating the style of existing and past artists. The products produced can't be copywritten, so anything it creates is public domain. And those seeking to claim ownership/authorship over AI generated content without citing it as being AI generated are being unethical, at best, and perpetrating outright fraud at worse. As is, how the systems work based on text prompts is no more a creative endeavor than editors or commissioners of work go through to convey what they want from a writer or artist, a process which conveys not authorship rights to the editor or commissioner of the work (what does convey ownership is that works are often works-for-hire with copyright ownership, wholly or in part, being transferred as a result of payment.) The fact that it is an iterative process with AI systems to get the desired result doesn't de facto make the process any more creative than an editor/commissioner evaluating a work and requesting changes to it. If one is to assert authorship/ownership over generated AI content on these grounds, then every editor in existence would be able to claim the same and that is patently absurd.

Creating derivative works still require payment and/or permission of the copyright owner. Using AI which has learned from copywritten materials is a violation of copyright of the creators - though AI proponent claim "fair use" because, they argue, "people learn the same way" which shows a shallow understanding of how people learn - we don't need a comprehensive data set to learn from and we can self-monitor what we create to improve it, and we can apply experiences unrelated to the examples we're exposed to to inform what is created , something that AI systems are currently incapable of doing. Also, without using a substantial portion of the copywritten works, the AI systems could never ever generate anything "in the style of" a living artist. Just have it try to create something that it has NOT had added to its learning database -- it can't (but people can and do all the time.) Anything that is generated is, by definition, derivative of existing works. The fact that works created are "in the style of" human writers and artists just proves this point. The issue of copyright issues arises when such works are created on the basis of living creators works, which are copywritten and protected, and duplicating their works to create derivative works raises legitimate questions of copyright and the notion of "fair use."

Fiction, lyrics, and other creative output expresses nothing more than a simulacrum of human experiences. They will not provide any new insights or interpretations of relationships or interactions as the systems can't experience, for itself, such things to inform their content creation. It will remain inferior to what people create because of this, but the fact is that mediocre content will suffice for most commercial needs and, as such, will be used by corporations to eliminate the costs associated with hiring writers, artists, musicians and other creative types - so long as their delivery is limited to the digital realm. It'll be awhile before an AI system can actually produce a painting, make a sculpture, craft a piece of jewelry, throw a ceramic pot, preform a live musical piece, and any number of thing that humans do/produce that enrich the physical world.
Its time the viewers & listeners decide if they like art for the end product or the creation of the peice, the story, the emotion and feeling.

I had to drive nearly an hour to and from work on busy roads for a few years awhile back and had a lot of time to ponder just how my human brain, eyes and ears took in the vast amount of information you can get by observing not only the traffic around you but also the body language of the other drivers. I also found that often the safest times were when you were driving moderately aggressive, not allowing the bullies of the road to push their way in an out of lanes. On a crowded freeway you were far safer going the speed the other cars around you even if that was over the posted speed limit. Your brain made instant decisions of lane positioning to ensure that drivers in other lanes could see you and that you had a place to go if someone did something unexpected. You would read a sign that says your lane is ending a mile ahead and know that if you get over too early, an entire string of very aggressive drivers will go around you in that ending lane only to have to push their way in ahead of you. You would be punished for being responsible so you would find some compromise. AI or self driving cars could make none of those decisions. Your brain can add in so many gray factors and experiences instantly that a computer program could never emulate. Cameras and sensors can only resolve pre-programmed inputs. Let it try to understand a part falling off a delivery truck in front of you bouncing wildly or a driver gazing at their cellphone weaving over a lane.

That said, self-driving cars can work....if every vehicle on the road is self-driving and programmed to respond to one another. Society will NEVER pay for the infrastructure required for that dynamic.

08:24 I think we need to fully understand how references are being used before we say that machine learning and an artist looking at/referencing another artist's work is the same thing.
I don't know how these things works so please tell me if I'm wrong. I'd love to get more insight into this.

When training the AI on an image I would assume it "looks at"/reads every signle pixel in that image? Even if the AI isn't "copying" the image when generating a new one, it would still have "used" 100% of that image in its training. Also, the AI can't misread that information or forget it, it is now stored in the AI.
If nothing else I feel the amount of information the AI can get out of its "references" are far beyond a human. If it is enough to be a difference, I don't know.

But that would be for one image. The time it takes for an AI to be trained on 100% of an artist's portfolio is probably closer to hours than days. Compared to months or even years it might take for an artist to learn how to resemble the work of another artist (in a consistent way - if they'd even have the skils to do it).
I would also say that a human needs to try to reverse engineer the reference image in terms of being able to truly resemble something like it. Needing to, at least in some way, figure out the actual creative process behind the creation of the source material.
Since the AI was trained on 100% of the pixel data, does it need to reverse engineer anything? It wouldn't contemplate brush strokes or painting in layers, right? I don't know.

Here's where I think we'll end up.

In the future there will only be 2 types of software: AIs and digital end products (movies, music, games, e-books, VR worlds etc). Intermediary products we currently use like Photoshop, Excel, and things like that won't be necessary as it will necessarily do all the admin, analysis, and planning, and will just write the end product direct to binary. There's a lot of misunderstanding of art in this video,I feel like the biggest one is that an artist doesn't just copy other artists to learn. The difference between artists and AI is that artists can get inspired by anything, not just other art. Many artists don't learn by consciously copying anyone's work. They take things from here and there to build their own thing. It can be a cartoon a photograph, a really cool shaped tree they found on a hike, it can be anything. Comparing the 2 processes like it's 1 to 1 is insane to me. They are nothing alike.

Having artists use AI solves a non issue funnily enough, AI art itself solves a non issue, artists make art because they want to first and because they profit second. The art industry is awful to 80% of artists out there, most people cannot make a monthly salary doing art, yet they do it anyway, because they want to.

Most scummish AI artists get found out and pushed into oblivion, mostly hitting the same like and retweet cap before someone calls out their bullshit.
And the rest of AI artists do their stuff respectfully and appropiately tag their art without claiming its original (pixiv is a great example, the japanese are very respectful about AI art).
So people trying to pass it off as real art isnt really that big of a problem, they either doom themselves eventually, and people share it and it gets tossed around the internet, but everytime its shared it still has the same wall that prevents it from getting super popular. And the other group of ai artists are just nice.
The problem is that the programs that do this sort of stuff (i'll just say novelAI as an example) dont give any info on what it fed on to create what it created. So even the nice AI artists can only tell you "the AI made it" and give you the tags they used but they have no way to pinpoint every piece of artwork in it to tell you the sources

But obviously novelAI is never doing this, because letting artists know that their art was used gives them grounds for further legal action. The only way i could see this being done is if novelAI makes people pay for their services, and uses that money to buy rights from various artists to use their art to feed the bot.

The difference is that the way humans are inspired by other artists' work is WAAAY different from how an AI sees it. Humans don't need billions of examples of art to start honing their craft, but an AI model is 100% dependent on input data *exclusively*. It does not learn through years of practice developing its own style and creative vision, it ONLY learns based on what already exists. It interpolates and extrapolates *based on patterns within other people's work*. If an AI was only shown the total number of images viewed by human artists over their lifeline, they would SUCK. and no matter how much input data it sees, it won't be able to develop its own unique art styles.

I've worked in the IT Industry since 1980's.  I've seen Tech companies rebrand old tech as new tech all the time.  The "new tech" had a few tweaks but was essentially the same old tech.  When Client / Server became the buzz words in the late 1980's and early 1990's, the word Mainframe / MiniComputer became associate with "obsolete tech.  So IBM and others rebranded their mainframes / minicomputers as "eServers, iServers or whatever Servers".  "Cloud Computing"  not new.  Back in the 1950's to 1980's - Some companies couldn't afford the million dollar mainframes.   The solution - Pay another computer a monthly fee to host the computer and applications.  The state I lived in had several companies that did remote hosting for banks, trucking companies, accounting firms and other companies.  For the longest time, one university was the remote host for many other non-affiliated universities.

So long as income is based on labor‚Ä¶ this will be a problem. Once we are economically free to pursue our interests, things like human created art will be readily available. Artists want to create art and have it enjoyed‚Ä¶ but while ‚Äòprofit‚Äô is a factor, we are screwed.

There is a potential application that I doubt will ever replace humans but could really assist them in doing their jobs and that is assisting humans in performing complex maintenance procedures such as maintaining and aircraft and in particular an advanced fighter aircraft such as the F-16.

For example we are seeing that Ukraine is now getting block 15 F-16s from the Netherlands and Denmark and are having to train crews to maintain those aircraft. Thus one could imagine that if industry could develop an AI system focused on that one task that might help speed up that training as well as assist the new crews as they come on line.

For their may be thousands of pages of tech manuals that they must gain some knowledge of to perform those task and thus the learning curve can be steep.

And unlike say in the US Air Force where there are senior and experience technicians to train and supervise new ones Ukraine have no such senior technicians and thus might benefit from at least having an AI assistant to help them navigate all those complex procedures required to maintain an aircraft and assure that it is operating properly.

So the AI is not to replace the human but rather to help the human get up to speed in a more timely manner. For it takes about three years to become a seasoned maintainer and maybe AI can reduce that time say by a year.

BTW, I just made a video on this that goes into more details and uploaded it on my YouTube channel plus offered some thoughts on how one might go about building such an AI.

INTERVIEW with AI ARTIST: Interviewer: Hello, today we have an AI artist with us who will be describing an art piece. Can you please introduce yourself and tell us a little about your work?

AI artist: Hello, I'm an AI artist, and I'm excited to be here today. My work involves using artificial intelligence algorithms to generate creative content, including images, music, and even poetry.

Interviewer: That's fascinating. So, could you describe an art piece for us using AI language?

AI artist: Sure, I'd be happy to. Let me generate a description of an art piece using my algorithms.

[AI takes a moment to process the image and generate a description]

AI artist: Here's my description of the art piece:

This artwork is a vibrant and colorful painting with a lively and energetic composition. The use of bold brushstrokes and vibrant hues creates a sense of movement and vitality, while the interplay of light and shadow adds depth and dimension to the piece. The central focus of the painting is a striking figure, rendered in bold lines and contrasting tones, which draws the viewer's attention and creates a sense of drama and tension. Overall, this painting is a dynamic and engaging work that captures the essence of the artist's creative vision.

Interviewer: Wow, that's impressive. How do you decide what language to use when describing an art piece?

AI artist: My algorithms analyze the visual features of the art piece and generate language based on the patterns and structures they detect. For example, if the painting has bold colors and brushstrokes, my algorithms may generate language that emphasizes the energy and movement of the piece. If the painting has a more subdued color palette and delicate lines, my algorithms may generate language that emphasizes the subtlety and grace of the work.

Interviewer: That's very interesting. Do you think AI-generated descriptions of art can enhance the viewer's experience of the artwork?

AI artist: Absolutely. AI-generated descriptions can provide a new perspective on the artwork and help viewers see the piece in a different light. By highlighting certain features of the artwork and drawing attention to elements that might otherwise go unnoticed, AI-generated descriptions can deepen the viewer's understanding and appreciation of the artwork.

Interviewer: That's a great point. Thank you so much for joining us today and sharing your insights with us.

AI artist: Thank you for having me. It was a pleasure.

Regarding the "not real art" discussion it's not really a problem of tools getting more advanced or the creation process getting easier and more accessible. That has been happening for centuries and it only enhances peoples ability to be creative. The problem is that at the end of the day there isn't a human author behind the work. I think it's quite easy to imagine a dystopic future where an algorithm just takes your personal information and tailor makes all media for you using ai. There will be no artists or content creators, only the content that the ai decides you want to see.

I'm all for automation of menial human tasks that only make our lives worse for having to do them. But when we start automating away the things that we use to communicate between one another and that actually make our lives as humans more fun and interesting then I start worrying about where we're headed
Driverless cars that have a habit of bursting into flames.  What could go wrong?

One thing to consider is that self driving cars almost entirely eliminate human reaction time. This means the car can make decisions significantly faster than humans and dramatically reduce the chance of a collision taking place. Granted there will be some scenarios where a collision may be unavoidable, but in practice given collision rates of self-driving cars vs human-driven cars, especially when you consider evolution of self-driving cars working together on the same road sharing information with each other in order to even further reduce risk, I don't think this will be a problem.

AI is helpful with beginner programming tasks. It's fantastic for converting textual data between formats. But as soon as you ask for help with more advanced subjects like for example, help writing a KMDF driver or a bottom-up parser is will spit out complete garbage. Training the model on text scrapped from the internet will only take you so far.

Assembly code is not really a layer of abstraction. It's symbolic, and also works on more than one architecture. In any case, it's relationship to machine code is completely different from the layers of above it.

Ive just been watching videos on Auto-Play and it brings me back to this video. So I thought I might as well state a few questions to pose a perspective (12:21) that this video prompted: Would you, or would you not sue someone for viewing your piece of art (in any form) and effectively integrating it into their understanding? [To sue would be like 1984 with the Thought Police]

I pose this question as its at the heart of discussion - regardless of how humans view content online, you wouldn't sue them for viewing your art - whether it was legal or not. You would sue them for the end product of art that they produce that looks materially similar or illegally obtaining it (if found to be true via evidence). [That's Copyright]

What AI does could be considered transformative as the process is mutating the incoming data in similar ways to the brain to form latent embeddings that are distinct (in representation) from the input image. It may generate similar pieces of art, but I would argue that that has been achieved through hyper-focus - which fundamentally breaks the generalization of the underlying model. A human could generate a piece of art similar to yours if they viewed your artwork as well. From a functional point of view, the result is the same; created by two different viewers of the art work. So why is one criticized over the other? Why is the human perspective important here?


If the fundamental issue is that the business scraped your artwork from a site (on the internet), consider that the human viewer can also do that. Their functions are the same; regardless of scale.
In some ways, you are expecting protections on a medium that was never designed to give it. The internet was originally designed as an information sharing utility. To cry foul that that information is being used in a way you didn't expect is hardly justified given that context. Regardless of the possible backlash I may get on this next statement, understand it is a question more so than a statement:

Would you consider digital art worth less than the physical medium? If so, why? What about the physical media promotes higher costs (in the thousands) rather than the cheap costs (tens to hundreds) of the digital age? (Forget NFT's for this question, as its not a question of ownership).

Is it the very fact that it is a physical asset that gives it value? And if so, why do you care that a digital publication of the same artwork is being used to train this AI model?
Its fundamentally distinct from the real artwork piece- and in some ways being used in a transformational manner. As for digital art, it may have some intrinsic value as art - which I don't deny; but I do question what you thought was going to happen when you published it to a site like DeviantArt in whole. If you were about to protect your IP from infringement, wouldn't the best course of action be to release a partial or down-scaled version as proof and then keep the full resolution copy behind a paywall?

If you answer to the above question regarding digital artwork is 'because I wanted to share it', then you shouldn't be crying foul about AI using it; as you have achieved your purpose. If your answer was 'I wanted money to pay the bills' - then why did you share it whole in the first place? Especially not behind a paywall. This could be considered negligence in some ways.

I hope I haven't offended too many people by these questions, and hope for some fruitful dialectical discussion.

Many years ago, I remember being in a studio with a very well known bass player, the first time he was shown a POD. He got angry - it recreated the sounds of famous players who'd spent decades developing a sound. However, a few weeks later he was using it. It was a tool to make good sounds very quickly, just like AI. Yes, things will change but if we're in on it early, we get to shape how it develops.
AI has already changed our entire musical game in terms of cover and video art. We love it.

If these tools can increase visibility/understanding on legacy code bases, that will actually enable a lot of desperately needed improvements. There is a lot of difficult-to-maintain spaghetti in the industry that most developers are terrified of touching, because of how complex these monolithic projects are. But if AI can help make sense of the whole mess, then suddenly major refactors are feasible.

That being said we will eventually reach a point where software has been (nearly) perfected, and there's almost no work left to be done. That has always been the logical conclusion, since software doesn't rust. And it may be close for a few sub-fields like typical UI-development, but to perfect all of IT will probably take several more generations, especially as new fields open up.

5) Incoming AI regulation

I think where this will really start taking off is when we start getting A.I. integrated into the tools that we use, so this could be a programming language or a game engine or any tool we use.

Running it locally would be an advantage because it's a lot more secure, especially on work you don't want going public at that stage, it's also possible that being integrated into the tools we use would likely work better, for one, they could use a specialised A.I. model that's great for that given task, being integrated will also likely mean it can work better with the software and the user.

With all that said, I think the open source models are in a much better position, for one, there is no security issues of your data going back and forth with the likes of OpenAI, Microsoft, Google or any other company, two, these A.I. models can be fine-tuned and designed around the specific task of the software, and three, A.I. could be fully integrated into the software, all these 3 advantages are quite big over the slap on approach that online models do.

A.I. is still a new thing, things are going to get really interesting over the coming years as a lot of the software we use could have A.I. integrated in them, where it makes sense to do so at least, and at first, I thought it was going to take maybe a decade or so for that to happen, but with how quickly open source A.I. is developing, it's happening a lot quicker than even I expected, even the issue of greed from the likes of Nvidia is being overcome with APU's that are actually getting quite good at A.I. them having the advantage that you can have far more memory on the cheap.

The next decade is going to be very intresting to see how software developers, because once things really start moving, software could start to change rapidly.

So, I'm a translator. My "real job" is translating stuff (I do music as a hobby and for personal fulfillment). And I cannot even count the amount of times I heard people saying "Google Translate/DeepL/Bing is going to take your job". People have been saying this since Google Translate first appeared around the corner, almost 20 years ago and man, that thing is still dumb. I mean, if you only know English and some other European language, it seems to work ok, it can translate some sentences or paragraphs and make almost no mistake. Now try putting a book on it. It won't work. We have real use cases where people tried to do this and everybody noticed how poor the job was done.
In the gaming world, there are quite a few big names out there using AI to translate stuff, but they don't announce it publicly.
Boy, I wonder why.
Of course, they always blame the human translators they don't use when people notice that things are off.

Now, the other day, I tried using GPT-3 to see how far it could go, regarding to text quality it could generate. I broke it on the second prompt I gave it. I'm not that impressed.

So yeah, if something as "simple" as translation the AI still doesn't make the cut, I doubt it will, in the professional world, for visual arts and music. The real issue, from my point of view, are big companies forcibly pushing unfinished "smart" products that aren't ready to be deployed and blaming the human labor, instead of the faulty algorithm. That's what I predict it will happen from this whole debacle.
This, and the moral issue regarding secretly breaking copyright to feed the algorithms.
If we can overcome these problems, then yeah, AIs would become stupidly useful tools, that's for sure.

I remember having a Commodore 64 as a kid, and at the time is was the best the home computer could get. Then the Amiga 500 came out and our world changed. We went from 16 possible colours, to 4096 possible colours, and the quality of graphics in games exploded. Then there was the churn of IBM clones over the last few decades, with ever increasing steps in performance though nothing quite as gigantic in terms of the leap from the C64 to the A500, unless we include the leap from pc speaker to Soundblaster! But this AI, and what it means, and what it encompasses at its very essence, is another milestone in human history. It's no longer a case of "imagine it - create it", we don't even need to imagine it any more. A vague string like "space man wearing knitted wool motorbike helmet" resulting in a small movie is not even in the same league as where we've been stuck. I'm 20 years away from retirement as an electrical/electronic/software engineer, and while I feel reasonably safe in being able to work until that time comes, I feel genuine fear for the upcoming generations and what this will all mean to their future. AI is the literal embodiment of bitter-sweet.

BRO that crossing in Vietnam you showed! Looks like Ho Chi Minh city (Saigon). I just came back from a one month trip in Vietnam, you made me miss it. I was absolutely HYPNOTIZED by the traffic there. I've filmed multiple crossroads for video clips. They have almost no traffic lights. About one vehicle in 20 or 30 is a car, mostly freight or taxi. The traffic rules are vaguely present. It's not like it's total free for all, but you can definitely jump the red light or drive at the other side of the road if that feels like the right thing to do. The thing is: everybody is really watching out for each other, and trying to make it work together. I have not seen any traffic jams, although there is probably like 15 million motorcycles in Saigon. The stream is mesmerizingly  constant. In Europe, they'll run you over if they think they are right and have traffic rules to back them up. There is no such thing in Vietnam. Everyone is driving carefully, preoccupied with keeping the stream going. If the best way is to brake, you brake. If the best way is to speed past, you speed past.
