Okay, as an artist, there is a really big misunderstanding that's going around about how artists begin their process to become an artist. I hear a lot of people say that artists simply 'copy' other people's art in order to improve. This may be the case for young artists, aka children, but for a lot of artists in the community we stick to a lot of rules in order to be respectful of others' art. For example, we may copy elements of an artists processes like colour, composition, or linework. These things are simply fundamentals of everyones art that everyone incorporates when making a piece of art. I hear non artists say a lot that we simply copy the whole art in order to learn but this is something that is very frowned apon in the art community and never acceptable. As artists we believe an individuals style is created by external elements like upbringing, culture and also other artists processes. All of these elements are what make another persons art unabled to be copied because it's unique in the way their brain and hand processef that information. In my opinion that's what makes art, art. Please be more careful when talking about the comparison or how an artist vs Ai learn becayse it's not even remotely similar and that's why AI art always looks like a copy of someone's original work. When i look at AI art i can tell directly the artists that were plagiarised to make the 'art' and just because you can't doesn't mean it's original work made from 'learning'.

I am an unknown musician, I am also ADHD/Aspie. Those two things go together, despite Gary Numan, David Byrne, David Bowie, and the other luminary Aspies who broke through - and showed the world what ‚Äòpop‚Äô could be, in the hands of a sensitive genius.

I have been constantly appalled by what neurotypicals call music, and musicianship.
I remember back in the day of video rental stores, wandering the endless shelves of sub B grade rubbish, and trying to wrap my head around the catastrophic feedback loop of superficial seekers of entertainment which hit the right balance of novelty and predictability, and film makers desperate to satisfy the whims of those airheads.

The same happened to music of course, accelerated by analytics-driven corporate ‚Äòownership‚Äô of what we call ‚Äòour culture‚Äô - such as it is.

I also remember an interview with a laconic black American blues player (can‚Äôt remember who) who said something like ‚ÄúNowadays, with all this new technology, any idiot can make broadcast-quality music. But I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a job for any idiot ‚Ä¶‚Äù

I myself am a musician of the visionary kind
i.e. driven by a musical vision. (No musical, audio, equivalent to ‚Äòvision‚Äô. Though I often ‚Äòaudialise‚Äô).
In other words, an artist, not an entertainer.
I won‚Äôt expand on that, to avoid writing a treatise here ‚Ä¶

I have no wish to be an ‚Äòentertainer‚Äô.
A ‚Äòperformer‚Äô.
A circus act.

Entertainers are organ grinders and their monkeys.
There.
I‚Äôve said it.

True artists bring you ‚Äòthe news‚Äô, defragged, and sculpted into aesthetic forms.
The ‚Äònews‚Äô is -excuse me for this - spiritual.
Matters of the heart.

It has been reduced to collective public masturbation.

So don‚Äôt come bitching to me that your ‚Äòjob‚Äô is gone.
Visionaries will not be obsolesced by AI.
Because AI can‚Äôt bring you ‚Äòthe news‚Äô.

This will simply rationalise the situation - if you want formulaic, ‚Äòperfectly produced‚Äô novelty for airheads, probably best if machines do it.

Then you will have to find something worthwhile to do.

IMO - the problem is not that the AI image generation creates images of black founding fathers or black vikings per-se - it's the fact that when you try to hone the input to get a more accurate depiction (i.e. by asking it to generate an image of 'white male founding fathers'), the AI tool refuses and gives you a lecture on DEI - yet it has no problem if you ask for images featuring 'black' people, 'Asian' people or 'Chinese' people.

It has clearly been programmed to pre-filter the inputs - and it is those pre-filters which is where the worst bias lays.

I use AI images generators quite a lot (e.g. Automatic1111) and that has no problem generating images of people of any ethnicity in any context. It just takes the prompt as written and generates an image based upon it - you don't get a DEI lecture if your prompt isn't "on message".

Of course there may be some bias inherent in the model which comes from the training data it has been fed - but this is going to be true of any AI model (and in some cases is actually desirable). If you want an AI model that is optimised to create accurate depictions of Asian people for example - it makes sense for Asian people to make up the bulk of the AI training data set. If you want an AI model that produces accurate images of cats, it makes sense to train the AI model on images of cats.

The main consideration here is that the world economy is a work-allocation system. The "pay" simply directs people to perform labor in areas where there is a need or demand for it. Automating labor and therefore removing needs is accelerating. While in the past newer needs could be identified or created (like new entertainment), allowing technology and economy to adapt to each other, we're reaching escape velocity, where needs might be soon eliminated much faster than the economy system can expand new ones. Already we're seeing relationships being replaced by simplistic LLMs. One more breakthrough in capability, as we're seeing here, and new segments will be gone. Entertainments are already so plentiful that we're talking of "attention economy" for the user. But each user has a limited amount of time to consume entertainment as well.
In the big picture, we can solve this problem, but that requires altering the work-allocation system into something entirely new. In a world of machines replacing jobs, we will simply need an alternative economy where the "pay" rewards something different instead of labor. What that might be is both exciting and worrisome, especially given it will likely happen in our lifetimes, at this rate.

While I apreciate the effort put into this and I agree with the fundamental end point thesis, the arguments made are rife with what-about-isms and does not fundamentally answer the most profound question in the line of inquiry: A person is basically a physical frame driven by a data processor. We have been able to create an enhanced physical form through the field of mechanics and it allowed 1 man to do the work many used to take because the physical enhancement allowed manipulating the physical world to no longer be the bottleneck and instead it is the data processor that is the limiter. What happens when you give a tool that allows 1 data processor to do a task that once took many?

It is blindly optimistic to say "We will figure something out for them to do" when a vast majority of today's population don't even know what a for loop is and yet somehow unemployment won't be an issue because they'll all acquire lucrative high paying jobs from these companies, jobs you say you can't fathom now but are SURE will come (this to me sounds like quackery as this type of argument structure, I have seen in many anti-gmo or whatever argument). With this line of thinking I can say AI may be unable to handle edge cases now but 30 years ago it wasn't able to create pictures and we could not imagine how computers would ever be able to.

Sure, factories today still hire individuals to work there, but the work they do is so fundamentally different to what it used to be that mechanical automation did take jobs, it just provided new ones for others with different skill sets.

Again, while I agree with your final thesis I fundamentally disagree with how you got there and to me this video, while there was clear and genuine effort put to it that I appreciate, uses similar arguments to people trying to hype up AI just in the reverse direction. And I can imagine it is possible you know more about the topic that led you to your conclusions but felt the need to cut it out of the video, its just that without expounding uppon the whole scope of the topic to a level that would stand up to scrutiny, the only people who would agree with this video are people who already do.

Those in the know understand that machine learning and large language models by themselves are capable of doing nothing.. they are merely tools and are only ad useful as what/who taught it and using what data.

Just like the "cloud" is merely a snazzy word "someone elses servers and datacentre" the term "AI" is merely "predictions based on a large dataset"

Interesting to think of the similarities between AI voice-cloning content and Vocaloids. Now, Vocaloids are pretty clear about not being real people, but their voice providers are. However, the people providing their voices do at least see profit from the use of them, which could be a fair template for how voice-cloning models might work in the future.

Additionally even though the voices aren‚Äôt real, that means that there‚Äôs more emphasis on production in the vocaloid community, with different people having their own styles of ‚Äútuning‚Äù the voice, and vocaloid fans likely being able to name their favourite producers fairly easily.

Something like ÊÑõ„Åó„Å¶ÊÑõ„Åó„Å¶ÊÑõ„Åó„Å¶ (Love me love me love me) by Kikuo wouldn‚Äôt work as a song remotely if the production and non-vocal elements weren‚Äôt well-crafted. Even if anyone can buy Hatsune Miku, not everyone could make a song like that.

Now, honestly, I think a lot of people getting invested in AI content nowadays are massive hacks who want to make money off of people more talented than them. But it is interesting to see where creative people will go with this technology, and I think the real success is probably going to be in joint human-AI collaboration. I mean, if everyone can generate a voice or a drawing, you‚Äôve got to make something interesting to stand out and do something that a statistical model wouldn‚Äôt think of.

Here's my two cents as a musician: I think AI has the ability to kill music that doesn't push the creator in its marketing. Why would anyone make anonymous elevator music or lofi-chillhop for youtubers if youtubers could ask an AI to make them 100 different versions until it got it just right? They wouldn't. So bedroom producers making simple instrumental tracks won't make money anymore. Ariana Grande, Billie Eilish and Ed Sheeran will keep making money because people care about them as people ‚Äì they want to know what Ed Sheeran has on his mind. Same goes for virtuosos like Polyphia where we don't care how quickly a computer can "play" something, but seeing Tim Henson innovate on the guitar will make people chose Polyphia over AI every time.

I think the divide between album listeners and playlist listeners will grow, where playlist listeners won't care who made the music (if they ever did), whereas album listeners will care all the more. They're already the people who went back to buying vinyl, I think. For better or worse I think the music scene ten years from now will be one where the likes of Jacob Collier and Laufey will thrive, but someone like Avicii wouldn't have a chance at making it big.

You can't stop evolution, only adapt.

I know that the labour market in the States is probably somewhat skewed by sometimes overzealous efforts to undo discrimination, but that gay moment in the video just hit too close to home. I am not turning away from your content, which I find both really educational, entertaining and refreshingly down-to-earth. I just wish that the context of international audiences might be taken into account in the future. Sorry if I've been a nuisance.

If that music-generating AI is the one everyone has been talking about lately, it's notable that the training process was very careful about copyright - it's trained only from CC-licenced or otherwise public sources. Not because of any particular ethical concern - it's just that the music industry is notoriously sue-happy when it comes to copyright, and will unleash the lawyers at the slightest provocation. With the big money to back it up. Half a second of sound recognisable from a chart hit appears in the AI music, and it's an invitation for legal action. Artists though are both less likely to sue, and generally don't have millions of dollars to burn on a drawn-out court battle.

At this point, I'm only worried about being unable to sell my own art because the world basically becomes like AI TikTok; I make something good and then BILLIONS of mediocre teens steal it all and feed it into the machine for views and money, while I myself get no recognition.


Other than that, I'm still going to learn to draw and become an artist in my own way; for me, making the art myself is important, because I need that creative outlet. I think ultimately, to keep it broad and think about commission artists vs ai art, the market of people who are hopping on an instagram trend and posting their pictures on Instagram and the market of people who are going to seek out a commission artist in a style they like and pay them the appropriate rate for a commission drawing are two VERY DIFFERENT markets.

Lensa costs $4 for 50 images. For someone who doesn't actually care about art, and is just looking to do their cute insta post, which is the only instance I've seen this, that's an awesome one time purchase, maybe two. If you want to do more, the annual subscription is only $36.

You could pay for multiple years of lensa for less than the cost of the images of the quality that it produces, and if you're not trying to get commission art of an OC or something specific and just want to see cool pictures of yourself, I don't feel like you are the kind of person who would go and seek out a commission artist of their own volition anyways.

I do think that others have put very elegantly the issues of how AI generates these images, and the lack of consent from content creators is the primary issues in these instances. I've just seen some people say that it's driving business from actual artists, and while I think there might definitely be some cases of that, people scoffing at the prices of commission art has been a trend for centuries and will continue to.

There is a huge problem about the "prompting" part however. It seems prompting would/should/will replace programming. However prompting is very fragile and we actually already have well designed DSL "prompting" languages like SQL. Of course, you can generic-prompting and generate the specific prompt SQL (less learning) but probably your prompt will be much-much longer than the SQL variant (efficiency) and your prompt may or may not describe what you mean. You will never know (security, credibility). Contrary the database engineer who knows the DSL (more learning) will be much more productive and confident. (Of course an intelligent SQL syntax accelerator would be very welcome to the database engineer...).

The more I understand AI and how it works the more I wish it never happened in the first place within the humanities/art. you know whats really breaking my heart quite alot? the fact people think ''diversity'' is a good thing. well technically it is but not in the way people sell it to you. i am from germany for example, just because i prefer to live within other german people instead of lets say africans does not mean i m a racist or that i dislike africans (insert any other here). i just dont want to live with them because we are so different to one another, that we simply dont work together that well. IF i would want to live with africans.... i would live in africa instead and not germany, see where its going? i like african people and THEIR culture..but i also like my own. and i prefer to have people around me with similar values and mindsets and speaking the same language so you can actually talk to each other.

by making everything ''diverse'' you are making it less diverse.

as a kid, i was so thrilled every time we went on holiday somewhere to the world because every country was different, with different people and values, different music and food, different architecture and it was like you re visiting a whole different world.

now imagine you put diversity in there and every country is now the same. just a grey mudd instead of colors. france does not feel like france anymore, spain doesnt feel like spain anymore, germany doesnt feel like germany anymore and so on and so on. countries have no identity anymore, culture is slowly fading away. why would i want to visit x country if its the same stuff there as i have at home?

People are vastly different! and thats GOOD. it doesnt mean however that alot of vastly different people should live together 24/7.
imagine you re renting a small room. and you put in 30 different people from 30 different countries speaking 30 different languages with 30 different values and political views and alike together into that single room but you only have 20 chairs in there... WHAT THE ACTUAL F DO YOU THINK WILL HAPPEN???

it doesnt mean i dislike any of those 30 people in there or be racist against them... it just mean that i am the opinion, its a really bad idea to forcefully put them all into one room together. take some inspiration from animals. if you put a lion, a leopard, a grizzly bear, a tiger and some meat into one small room...do you really expect them to go along just fine? there is a reason different species take up different territories. and i know humans are no different species, however: different countries and ethnics are raised by such fundamentally different core values and such different ways for as long as humans are around that there is just a too big of a cultural difference for everyone to be compatible with everyone else. and today within just a few years you are like: ''nah you have to be compatible or else you re a racist'' its plain stupid.

I really can't stop laughing when I hear people say that there will be new jobs because of AI.
Think for a second, AI is literally doing the same mental work as a human, but faster and cheaper. ANY kind of new (required) job that will be created, the AI will be able to do it, and it will learn to do it faster than any human.

Why pay for a programmer to do the work of 10 with an AI assistant, when I can just ask my own AI assistant to do the same job cutting the middleman altogether?
Why go ask a designer that uses AI to make x10 more work for a design, when I can just ask my own AI assistant to do the entire design on its own.

AI is NOT the same as any other past technology, it will literally be able to do EVERYTHING a human can, but it will ALWAYS be cheaper, faster, and with more knowledge.
One example is prompt engineering. It will be the most short-lived profession in the history of humanity. For most new AI models (LLMs and image generation), there is already no need for prompt engineering, because the latest models can understand natural langue better than most humans at this point. And this will keep advancing.
In a couple of years at most, we will be able to ask an AI to generate a movie, software, or even an entire game, and it will be able to do it with no other input (except asking for preferences if it's not a personal assistant) and without any kind of prompt engineering.

The only types of jobs that I can see that are not going to be lost (at least for the next few decades), are related to live performances (sports, bands, etc.)
We just love to watch other humans do things that look hard or even impossible, and that require insane amounts of training and/or talent. We will continue to pay for tickets to watch them live.

I appreciate your perspective and taking the time to break down the arguments for both sides. I have to fully admit that I had a very difficult time watching through this video without getting frustrated, but a lot of the disagreements I had with you early on you managed to explain and ease the blow a little.

As an artist who has been developing my skills across various mediums for almost 20 years now - and who tries to just break even on the art I create - I understand that your video is simply about stating the facts, but it's a very - VERY - tough pill to swallow. Watching jobs that artists have spent decades working towards - illustration, graphic design, private commission work, etc. being replaced with AI practically overnight is ... horrifying, really. I understand that the average person doesn't mean any harm when using these programs, the average person is almost never willing to spend money on artists in the first place or pay them what they're worth - so of course the accessibility of AI art has huge appeal for people. (Even despite the glaring and often grotesque errors in what AI generates ... mangled hands and eyes, and proportions that don't make sense are all glossed over by most people it seems.)
I'm glad that you tied your argument back to a lot of creative fields evolving and adapting over time - the comparison between traditional and digital art is not entirely inaccurate but I do have to argue that there is still a creative skill that is honed and developed in the transition between traditional and digital. You still have to DRAW on a tablet - and in the case of electronic music, you still have to PLAY and CREATE the composition - unlike with AI where you simple hit a button and the computer spits out the work for you.
I don't like how a lot of artists are jumping down peoples throats over this technology - it paints artists in a bad light and I wish there was a better way to express how scary this is and for the average person to understand in a clearer and more sympathetic light - your video is a step towards that ... but emotions are really high right now. It doesn't help that most artists never consented to their work being fed into these programs, so when we see AI generate these images with mangled signatures from the artwork they're "inspired" by ... it's hard not to get upset hearing your argument, "It's creative freedom and it's the same as people using inspiration from other artists". It's not. Not yet, at least.

All of that said ... and as you conclude ... this is just something we need to live with now, unfortunately. We can't go back to the time before this as this was inevitable ... I just hope that moving forward artists won't be completely left behind. Without us, these programs wouldn't be able to exist in the first place.

In addition to all the new releases by dead artists, another thing to consider is the hybrid possibilities available to AI users that would, as far as I can see, circumvent any kind of copyright issues. Consider that a 50/50 blend of Steve Perry and Paul Rodgers might result in a wholly new vocalist with an outstanding voice, Jon Anderson and Rod Stewart? Not a copy of anyone, but a voice no-one has heard before. Paul McCartney and Robin Gibb? Adele, Edith Piaf and Taylor Swift? etc., etc. Who knows what would sound good? Could be a combination of any number of voices. And since the original voices used for the blend would not have to be disclosed - the labels would be none the wiser. We may end up with record setting song sales by artists who do not actually exist. The successful blending of two or more voices into a new amalgam may prove to be a new art form all on it's own in the near future. As it becomes more sophisticated, you may be able to select for specific attributes: the range of Jon Anderson, the vibrato of Robin Gibb, the timbre of Chris Cornell, the phrasing of Louis Armstrong...the possibilities are actually infinite.
And by that point, live performance won't be an issue. You'll just need a good looking, charismatic performer who can hold a tune to generate the base vocal from, which the real time AI would turn into whatever fictional hybrid vocalist(s) you've created.

While, admittedly, it would be less than ideal to be a singer under these circumstances, it should be considered that the amount of truly great singers in the world is quite small compared to the number of people trying to make music. For creators wanting to showcase their material in the best possible light, access to someone of the quality of a Stevie Wonder or a Pavarotti is pretty much a lost cause. As a songwriter myself, it would be pretty thrilling to have my work sung by world class vocalists.

One last point: for all of those people saying that this ends all human emotion in music, that it will become soulless, have you heard the top 10 from Spotify recently?

AI will never stop individuality or originality,  I never know what's going to come next from myself. I think this will influence artists become more diverse and try to push the boundaries even more.

In my 10+ years as an artist(3D Animator), all I've realized is that new technologies don't really make our lives easier. As soon as we are able to make things faster, companies just ask us to do more to make up for the time saved.

It would be great if AI could do the tedious parts I hate doing, but as things have progressed it's become clear that won't happen. Basically nobody in the AI/ML community has any clue about the intricacies of my work, and doesn't care to. It's easier and cheaper for them to just automate my job entirely and all that will be left is the tedium. Thankfully AI still isn't anywhere close to being powerful enough to meaningfully threaten my work yet, but I hope by that point I hope to be financially secure enough that it won't matter.

Also, one thing thing I feel should be pointed out(that other commenters haven't) is that AI/ML can only create something because humans did it first. Meaning that AI/ML "artwork" is inherently derivative in it's current function, therefore limiting the creative variability and leading everything to slowly become more and more homogenized. A problem that already exists, but I feel like AI/ML will make 1000x worse.

I am both of a more artistic and "programmer" like mindset, I absolutely agree with you, even human beings are as drone like as the AI if they are career artists. Living in the fast paced, work driven world like we do these days, most artists just don't have the privilege to create from their heart or soul, not as much at least. Most of us, if we want to keep spending our time working with art, we must conform to the desires of the many and client based "products", we create for the desire of others and what they want. In these cases, it's not always what we want to make naturally, or even like at all, but we do it because working all the time takes us away from being able to create for ourselves, to express ourselves. I don't know about everyone else and other artists, but I can definitely feel the difference between creating out of necessity for work related, product related purposes, vs creating out of passion, and necessity to express our self. I'm sure programmers must feel this way as well, for example, putting their hearts into creating ai, because they love it, because they are passionate to see where this technology goes, the progress.
Because I've felt this on a programmer like level, I understand why they want to defend AI so much, to them, this is a passion for them, their own art. I also really appreciate AI, because I know the self that can go into programming, and seeing the progress. I think this video helped me realize that more, too.

I love the idea you have for artists to have their own AI's. There is so much already out there right now artists are using as a tool that make the process so much faster and more efficient. Digital art; now you don't need to buy paints, you can send them quickly online over the internet, print them out. Using photography instead of life drawing to get the references your want or need for a piece. There's even great tools online, like picrew, where the artist can put parts of an artwork on different layers, using all the same poses, backgrounds, other assets, to create literally thousands of different possibilities very quickly, in their own art style. Dress up games in general. 3D art, you create something once, and can duplicate it easily for another project. Undo button, copy, flip, rotate, on digital canvases, all are just ways to make the process run easier and more smoothly. Some artists still insist on traditional art mediums, that's fine for them, but even they use tricks and other tools to make the process run quicker and smoother, stencils, sponges, stamps, printmaking. Traditional animation, cel animation, digital animation, 3D animation...

Right now using AI is seen as wrong because ease always seems wrong to those who have had to work harder in the past, and think that working harder is a more valuable asset, but the fact is, when you streamline the extra legwork from the past, you have more time and energy to think of something new and novel that could bring even more amazing results as time runs on.

Along with your idea, I really think it might be possible to at least do licensing, or even royalties, if an AI company wants to use a gallery of an artist's work. If they are grabbing galleries from others, they can put the bit of extra effort in getting the artist on board with the project. Not all artists will be able to understand how to use ai to be self reliant for that business, but they entities that do know AI should still ethically get the proper permissions from the artists before entering it as part of the AI.. Of course, I don't know enough about how the AIs are programmed to know if that's possible, but if it is, it should be possible for artists to take legal action if they find their work being so easily replicated just by a user inputting their name and style attached.

I think it can be done, but the legal system is so slow...
At least word of mouth and people respecting individual rights is something until it gets to people that don't care and will do it anyway.. ^^'' But that happens every day right now. I remember not that long ago hearing about sites like Redbubble once had the issues where art was being stolen and used to sell print merchandise, the Hot Topic scandals, etc.

I can picture a world where artists will have more time to create what they are passionate about, and then use those works to create AI generated works for those they do not want to do. Hopefully it can perhaps create a new artistic renaissance. Who knows?

AI generative art is a tool, like a paintbrush or any other tool. If you paint or trace an exact copy of any art, you will be guilty of plagiarism. If you use ai tools to build custom models and transform a piece of art within a greater workflow, and the result is ultimately unique and original, even with a few notes sampled from another artist, that is still art. Each individual work needs to be judged on its own merits, not by how similar the styles may be. Personality and individual expression will always need to be a primary factor, but every artist is free to use any tool they wish, and this will be true forever. The best and most influential AI artists of the future will be those that are most original, and do the work to build their own unique models that express their own unique styles. AI artists will benefit most from sharing their influences and workflows openly with their community and other artists to collaborate to build tools that make it easier to build custom styles.

One thing that worries me about AI art is that a lot of people who wanna be artists are just. not gonna learn how to draw. Not gonna bother with learning anatomy and geometry and color and light and line weight and creature design and character design and symbolism etc etc etc, not gonna try out different materials and techniques and doodle endlessly until they get where they wanna be, and just trust the program to build something that matches their prompt.

'Cause a lot of your personal style won't just come from what you imagine in your head, it'll come from the very process of getting your idea onto the paper or canvas or wall or what have you, what you choose to focus on as you learn; maybe you don't want to learn anatomy, so instead you figure out how to make characters out of geometric shapes (like with Genndy Tartkovsky), or maybe anatomy fascinates you so much you include it where it doesn't even belong (like H. R. Giger). Or stuff like what materials you can afford or like the feel of, what parts of the picture you do first and last, the shortcuts you take, the colors you like, your unique style will evolve as you learn and struggle and practice.

And it's just a scary idea to me that a lot of beginner artists will just not do any of that, and just practice what words the computer likes.

In my many years as a software engineer (I'm now 77, retired) - The biggest obstacle in delivering bulletproof applications was the push to get it done by the using community/customer to the point where we were forced to begin development before the problem was adequately defined and understood. Often, we were financially incentivized to start early or threatened with a financial penalty if we did not begin before ready. These important first step require humans that understand the business on both sides of the aisle (user/IT). We were often paid extra to deliver something with holes in it and then paid once again to patch those holes post deployment. While I believe that today AI can assist in accomplishing these important first steps it cannot do it alone. Maybe someday, just not yet.

I‚Äôm an amateur artist and in my career, I‚Äôve found that there‚Äôs an unspoken etiquette among artists. Tracing is fine but you don‚Äôt post it. You trace to learn. If you‚Äôre struggling with a pose or perspective, you can trace something to figure out how to do it yourself, but you don‚Äôt claim it‚Äôs yours. If you do post it, you cite your source, just like a bibliography for a book report. AI has learned from artists and is now profiting from other people‚Äôs art, claiming it to be original. It specifically erases the watermarks of the art it has stolen. The problem is that AI is only good at reference. It can‚Äôt think critically. If you give it an abstract concept like ‚Äúreally scary thing‚Äù it can‚Äôt invent something new, it can only reference other scary things. The same thing would happen if an alien race landed on Earth and you asked AI to draw it. It couldn‚Äôt because it doesn‚Äôt have that alien in its database to reference. AI art is basically just a personalized google images. It‚Äôs fine if you want to goof around with it, but I don‚Äôt think you should give it any more credit than it deserves. It‚Äôs not amazing art, it‚Äôs referencing amazing art and mashing it all together. Stop and think, ‚Äúhow much would it cost to pay an artist to do this for me with much more tact and specificity?‚Äù I dunno, just some things to keep in mind. It‚Äôs not just ‚Äúartists are butthurt about losing jobs‚Äù, it‚Äôs the ethics of literally stealing intellectual property for profit. It‚Äôs no better than NFT bros stealing art and claiming it‚Äôs going to the moon. Don‚Äôt be an NFT bro.

I totally disagree with that comparison that you do between how an AI "learns" to draw and how a human artist gets inspired. That comparison is incomplete, misleading and totally dishonest. Please stop propagating that fake metaphor.

You said a human artist can get inspired by the work of others and give hir own touch. You then say that this "should not be considered stealing". OK I agree, but the reasons why most of the people would not consider that this is stealing are two:

1 - The human artist would be adding HIS OWN TOUCH. (unlike an AI).

2 - That process would require a significant amount of human effort and certain innate talent that not everyboady is capable of. That skill and has merit. If an artist is capable of painting by hand a copy of the mona lisa that an art expert considers almost identical from the original, that artist would be praised for his insane skill. No one would say that his work is "unoriginal" and nobody would say that what he has done is similar to taking a picture of the original painting. Reproducing art requires skill, and what artist do when they replicate art from others is practicing to gain skill.

3 - That process require time. Human time is limited, if someone decides to go to art school and learn art, that person is investing a significant amount our his life in gaining that skill that allows him to output from his imagination beautiful creations. The goal of the artist is to invest a portion of his life to leave in the world something unique.

4 - Also a human artist can learn from the work of others, but he can learn without seeing someone else's work, just by getting inspired by his life experience or his imagination. Human art geniuses have jumped from their mundane life experience to wonderful creations new to the world.


But an AI image generator.

1 - Can not add its own touch, because it has no own touch, it has no life experience, no conciousness, no thougts or feelings. All it has is a huge dataset of work from human artists. That dataset is all it knows, every single relationship "word -- configuration of shapes" comes from that dataset, without that dataset (someone else's work) the AI would not even draw a stickman.

2 - Unlike the human artist, for the AI, there is no skill requirement. Because the AI goes from pixels to pixels, copy-paste. I know its not exactly copy-paste, but if a human had to imitate what an AI image generator does, processing thousands of images at a pixel level, we won't be saying "its getting inspired", we would be saying "its doing a photocopy". From day 0 the AI can copy-paste perfectly.


3 - For an AI, the time required to learn is several orders of magnitude smaller. The amount of images that the AI can process is several orders of magnitude above what a human person can experience in his life. What if AI image generators were limited to a human scale the output would not be that good. This is important, because this huge amount of images processed is what turns this process of enhaced copy-pasting at a pixel level, into something that some people consider "original creations". Those are not "original" and those are not "creations", everything was previously in the dataset.

4 - How would be an AI that learns to draw without the dataset? The day that this happens, this would deserve to be called AI Art. But today there is no such a thing.

Please stop doing the comparison "the AI is doing" what a human does: getting inspired by the work of others. Reverse the reasoning: imagine a human processing pixels by hand and inserting them in identical patterns.

Or just do an AI, that looks to the world, and learns how to move its mechanical arm, and to use a pencil, and to use a brush and paint. Go this way.

Why go through all that when you can program the car from the very beginning.. Make sure the car doesn‚Äôt drive to close, that it reacts quickly to accidents or falling objects like with the truck and that it sends alert messages to other vehicles to slow down and so on to stop / take distance, no need to hit or crash to whatever..

I'm not the biggest champion of self-driving cars, but I think way too much of the conversation is sensational rather than inquisitive and informative. It's easy enough to find a few silly situations to ridicule, but I don't think the news reporting we are getting will age very well. At the rate things are developing, it seems likely that self-driving cars will be safer than the average human driver relatively soon. Now that they are considered safe enough to operate and learn in a live environment, they will evolve even faster. We shouldn't let these companies get away with murder, but it doesn't seem like they are trying to. Seems to me like they are just trying to do their best in a somewhat dismissive (and sometimes outright hostile) media environment. Progress is inevitable, and in the case of self-driving cars, perhaps mostly for the better. At least if we take it seriously enough to prepare for it. There will probably not be much need for human drivers in the future, and it's important no to stick our heads in the sand and pretend that isn't going to happen.

If we look at the history of automation though, the most likely way this will play out is something like this:

Yesterday: What do you mean self-driving cars? Don't be silly! That is total science fiction and will never actually happen.
Today: Look at all those silly autonomous cars! They can only drive as well as a human 99% of the time, and sometimes they stop for no apparent reason. How hilarious.
Tomorrow: We have to stop all these self-driving cars that are so massively outperforming human drivers! We can't compete and are losing our jobs! This isn't fair!

Thanks for this balanced video that expands on the valid points of the artists as well as the developers.

6:18 is a nice summary of the whole situation!

I've actually seen both sides of the arguments within the artist community. Paradoxically, it's usually the product-driven artists that were the most upset. The value of art as a process is a also an emotional one, and ultimately what drives an artist forward. The product is the destination and does also have layers of value and meaning beyond just its monetary aspect. But that actually goes for AI-generated art and the atmosphere it creates by capturing the unique nature of a particular style. There are few words that have such a contested definition as the word "art". ("Love", perhaps) I can see why there is such a huge debate about whether "AI Art" meets some of these definitions, like an author's self-expression that's not given by something that's generated by an algorithm. Yet there is also a common notion that there is no actually original art, and what differentiates plagiarism from professional art is knowing how to steal from many different sources. In fact, some of the same artists that now talk about AI just stealing art argued about precisely that. (As the book titled "Steal Like an Artist" suggests, which I actually found through a YouTube artist recommendation)



And as you mentioned at 10:15, plagiarism is about the person falsely claiming work as their own. Whether that be an actual artist, or - In the case of AI art - the owners behind the technology. Don't demonize the tool - blame the user.

In that regard, AI basically taps into more sources of artworks as reference to create an images than any real person ever could. Of course there is a more unique conversion and perception when an actual person converts their reference material. But the technology is not actually taking any one artwork and selling it as theirs.



That said, using the images without consent is an issue, as you pointed out at 9:05.

Thankfully, opt-out options are at least popping up that allow artists from excluding their art. But while Opt-out could still be considered a crummy approach (and laws in the future might even make this outright illegal) that ultimately won't prevent AI art to reach a level where it can meet the vast majority of art commissions.



I think the real issue is the underlying fear through the sudden shift in the art market, as noted by you at 11:03. Suddenly, technology made it possible to create art styles that previously required hours of work - let alone years of practice to hone that skill. So I can see why full-time artists are so upset right now. Particularly the less professional ones (as there is no target group left for them, losing to both cheap and clean-looking AI art that the average joe is content with, and not being able to keep up with the pros providing refined and expensive hand-crafted art for the connoisseurs.)



They now meet the fate that many jobs were previously done manually and lost to automation. Art was considered this bastion that computers and automation were for the longest time impossible to touch, but now suddenly reached a dumbfounding level of proficiency in the blink of an eye. Making a living as an artist now definitely got harder. But in magical wonderland where money is not a issue and merely becoming a good artist and enjoying the process is the goal, the situation actually got a lot better.

Because ironically, It's never been easier to create reference material to practice drawing specific objects, compositions, drawing styles or color palettes than before.
But as you implied at 11:16, this is a blessing for the society at large by making art products far more accessible than ever before.

For the consumer.
For the hobbyist painter.
And even for the nonvisual artist that previously had no budget for enhancing their work of writing or music with pictures, this is a win/win situation.

It's where someone who has made something, even if it's just assembling a piece of otherwise ready-made furniture, will value the thing they made more than if they were to compare it to a store-bought or otherwise available resource.

Yes you Assembled the Ikea furniture, but you didn't really Make it--all the pieces and instructions were there. Similar to a lego set--would you pay more for a lego set you get to build, or one already assembled for you?

To me the problem is that technology is always designed to replace human labour, so now it assumes the drawing art is "labour" that you need to be freed from so you have more time to do something else. This appears to be the first time that we directly replacing something emotional as opposed to hard physical labour.
I don't think anyone complained we invented the wheelbarrow and this freed us from the labour of carrying things with your hands... We don't assign much spiritual meaning to carrying rocks around, however we do to drawing art. It is part of our expression and thus it allows the propagation of some meaning from me to you. AI won't replace that, because you still want to express yourself in a way. However, you will lose jobs where you are drawing with the aim of advertising coz they are not created to propagate some meaning across but created to extract money from you.

AI programmer here (and I've worked with both image and audio generation).

AI music atm sucks. But not because we don't have the technology. If a big company like OpenAI wanted to dump a few million into training AI models (like we see for image and text generation), we could actually produce something VERY good. For comparison, the tool you looked at (jukebox) was made basically as an junior project in 2020 with probably under a week training time. There is no serious corporate attempt to tackle AI composition.

The reason for this is simply that there isn't much demand for generated music compared to audio.

If you want generic music to fit a specific vibe, we already have a mountain of license free music. And licensing even big name music isn't particularly expensive on a corporate level. The only 'real' market is indie video games that want to have their own melody to use as a leitmotif but are too poor to hire a starving music school grad composer for potentially a few pizzas. And honestly, you can probably get them for free if they use it as their graduating project.

Outside of that, people want to hear music written by humans because music is often about either making an emotional connection, or being wowed by the human mastery of the instrument. Music composed by a robot feels fake. I mean, the public hates learning that their favourite songs are written by song writers rather than the singer since it feels fake. This would be even worse if it is written by a robot.

Realistically, music is already mined out in terms of automation. Probably 99.9% of music heard is created by a robot already... your speakers. And even within that original recording, we have synth bass, drums, keys that are commonly used, simply because in many musical genres, listeners only really identify with the singer, and maybe the lead guitar.... the rest is just faceless beat machines anyways (sorry Adam).

Everyone loves to trash it, but the Spanish Inquisition was the first tribunal that institutionalized legal representation. The process REQUIRED the defendant to have an attorney and was assigned one if he couldn't find one himself. It was the process with more safeguarding for the defendant at that point in history.

The Inquisition was also part of the efforts to unify Spain, a newly formed kingdom at the time, that was trying to bring under one King and Queen one of the territories most prone to civil war in history. I think the USA is now realizing what the Egyptians clearly saw: single faith empires are the ones that last. Like it or not, that's been proven many times.

As famous as the Inquisition is for its death penalty sentences, it only applied "torment" to 2% of the defendants in 3 and a half centuries of trials (around 3000 dead in 340 years, "torment" was the term for any type of torture). Death penalty was frequently avoided by just repenting. Between the XVI and XVIII centuries, more than 50000 "witches" were killed in other parts of Europe by the Calvinist (I don't have the tortured numbers, but they frequently went together), most of them in Germany, while only 59 women were burned by the Inquisition. And you can read more about some of the Spanish cases because they are well recorded, some might not have been "witches", but were accused of atrocities that might have no better name.

These are not just history facts I like to write to show off. I'm not even very well educated on them. These are FACTS that have been hidden and rewritten by the English speaking world and repeated by other Spanish enemies because at one point in history, Spain was the largest empire the world has seen. Being born in a country that has perpetrated these lies and still insists on desecrating any Spanish legacy in your continent, you should know very well how the tactics worked and understand that they are now being used against your empire.

Just like Elton John was saying in an interview a couple years back on what advice he had for the new generation of artists and the whole streaming thing and how to make money and live off from your music, he said ''It's really becoming insane and a lot of young emerging artists go viral or get on billboard charts with only one song and they get high on that but it's so fleeting. If you want to last in this business especially now, do live concerts and keep on doing it more than ever before. You can't copy a concert ticket or download a live gig experience.''

To me, the one fundamental thing about this whole AI Sh** is that it cannot reproduce in any way shape or form the ''human connection''. We long for human connection naturally in every aspect of life. With the help of humans programming AI, it could maybe get to a certain level of ''understanding'' and display a sort of ''Autotuned Empathy''. Nowadays, the concept of empathy is so popular with growing narcissistic societies. But the concept of sympathy is fading out or isn't the trend right now and this IS the ultimate level, let's say, where AI could not reach cause if you ask your friends or anybody around you what is the difference between empathy and sympathy, don't be surprised of the answers you hear.

Lyrics in a song can bring you to a place of understanding or getting the big picture behind the meaning of the song. A sort of empathy arises, a comprehension of the storytelling. But music on the other hand, will ''enhance'' or color and bring the lyrics, the story to that level of beauty like sugar-coating and make you discover flavours you had not expected or experienced before.

Only this song has that taste let‚Äôs say. It's a sad song because of the lyrics obviously but the music shows you the degree of sadness of that song. Music is on the level of sympathy while lyrics sides more with empathy.

Empathy is like putting yourself in the shoes of someone and getting a certain idea or concept of what that person is going through. Just like in the medicine field, they teach doctors about empathy instead of sympathy with their patients because they say it could be harmful for the doctor if he bonded and had this friendly or human connection and transfer with a patient dying of cancer for example.

AI would be the best ones to prevent sympathy and really stick to empathy. But a doctor, an artist, a music fan, all of them are human beings with emotions first. We can't separate that from us.

Sympathy is not trying to understand what this person is going through right now and trying to help or find solutions for the person's burden. Sympathy is sharing that burden, taking half of it let's say so that the person can have a better chance at getting back up on its feet. Sympathy is suffering with the person and doing something about it. Empathy is easier or less demanding because it's more on a level of understanding how big the burden is and sending flowers and prayers for a quick recovery!

Lyrics can bring you to tears or make you feel any types of emotions but music is that extended part where you will reach another level of a song. Sometimes we experience music and cry, or we feel something so strong inside of us and if a person asks you why this song has that effect on you, you can't give a precise answer as to why that particular song strikes a cord in you and you'll end up saying well maybe it's the chord progression or the sounding of a certain instrument, a melody beautifully intertwined with the harmony and lyrics on top of it or it reminds me of a certain period of my life even though the lyrics are not related to that period...
It's just the music...they're landmarks.

Also, about the quality of the code itself, it's more likely that the AI will understand how coding works from the source dataset rather than replicate portions of code depending on the intent. So there shouldn't be problems on that side in the long run. And that also makes it safe from any licensing problem, as it literally copies nothing. Of course, I said in the long run. In the short run it will probably continue copying code until it understands it enough to actually dissect it and make its own.

I think there may be more nuance to this. I had a long conversation with ChatGPT with OpenAI bias about this, and it doesn't seem to think that it will ever be fully autonomous or able to write code completely independently. I'm not sure what model has the largest token output, but we would need very large token input and output to generate assembly codebases. I think we need a specifically trained hierarchy of models that perform all the steps of the development chain and send instructions to improve upon the development cycle, with human influence. I think it will be: humans creating ecosystems, and those ecosystems interacting with other ecosystems of software stacks and LLM models maintaining them. Humans will be assigned to validation of theory, because we are the original source of creativity. The seed of random for the LLMs would come from the /dev/urandom of the universe. Brute force trial and error with LLMs, but humans would become knowledge workers of another kind, heading towards biologically invasive integration. The LLMs will converse with each other to brute force the problems we come up with. But, humans are impatient, and we won't stop modifying our own LLM systems, so then it will not become autonomous but rather just the most useful tool in our repertoire.

I'm glad to finally watch a video from a creative person that can appreciate the creative ways these tools can help everyone alive in the industry today.

Remember when DreamWeaver came out and people were like "there wont be any more developers! ooh nooo!! we're gonna lose our jobs!!"
Remember when Motion Capture came out and people were like "they wont need 3D animators anymore!!! OOH NOOO!!! We're gonna lose our jobs!!!"
Remember when CMS websites and App Builders started popping up and people were like "Oh No!! They wont need app and web developers any more!! We're gonna lose our jobs!!!"

Heck... remember when PHOTOSHOP came out, and people were like "that's not real art.... we're gonna lose our jobs!!"

Humans have such short memories...

Guys, all these things did was create a different way of doing the same job.
Just like Mocaps created a new TYPE of job, AI Art will create a new type of job for artists being born today. In 20 years "AI art cleanup" will be a job, just like "Mocap cleanup" is a job today.

"But ChatGPT is writing code now!"... yea, it's writing spaghetti code. Which is fine for quick tools, prototypes, indie games and small projects.
But you don't build your house on a pile of mud. Professional industry standard video games, websites, applications and software still need engineers and architects.
All those little script kiddies will be able to freelance simple projects; and companies will learn really quick that "cheap labor" isn't sustainable when they have an entire staff of entry devs and bots that can't fix anything when it's broken.

"But it creates 3D now!!!" ... again, this is fine for small projects. But if you don't have actual 3D artist who know how to optimize the 3D and separate it into pieces that can be animated... then all you have is a static blob.

"But people won't hire me because they can just use AI art!" .. then adapt! Offer your skills to clean up AI art or improve on it's generated concepts. AI usually only draws a portrait from the shoulders up. What about the torso? Is the person wearing pants or a skirt? What shoes are they wearing? If they're even wearing shoes. These are all pieces of the picture that don't exist. Your creativity isn't at jeopardy, it's just shifted.

Imagine how much more productive you can be if you're a freelancer. A customer gives you a concept. You can sit with them and generate AI art so they can visibly see their concept. Then you spend a day or two recreating the pieces of the puzzle they wanted in your own art style. This is an hour with the bot and a few days of art. Whereas before it might have taken you 2-3 days to come up with a concept only for the customer to say "nah.. I don't like that".. and the freelance work takes weeks. So you only have 3 customers a month. Well now you can potentially have 20 customers a month.

"But they're stealing our art!!!!" - Yea this is the only one I actually agree with is pretty shitty. But steps are being taken right now to prevent this kind of stuff.

Matthew - I have enjoyed your AI insights and completely agree with your review.  The AI trends you discuss put specific focus on a couple of levels I'd like to share from my experience with English language no-code tools from the late1970's to the present day.  Entry level skills that need to be built from elementary school levels are critical thinking, and operational system analysis ( use case domain driven ) .  Then learning to build prompt syntax excellence within the boundaries of specific LMs  that are trained on data aligned with specific use cases.  Example - we are experts in the SME manufacturing space.  The manufacturing domain results in manufacturing an English language domain variant that can be easily used to train an LM.  Today - this challenge is the easy part.  The hard part today is getting code delivered with UI-UX that is more sophisticated delivering what you need to see and do "in 3 clicks or less" on multiple devices.  And yes even that standard of UI-UX design can be taught as patterns to an LM.  Rock on!

computer scientist here, you are misunderstanding a bit what coding means in the context of machine learning. The code of gemini does not contain any bias, the data set that was used does.  That is what machine learning means, the coding happens first and does not lead to any kind of behaviour, just an abstract neural network. The next step of training that network with data leads to the final behavior. So you cannot blame google for "coding" anything wrong, the IT guys did their job very well here, the people who assembled the dataset on the other hand seemingly made some weird choices.

I have a friend who works in the tech industry and is HEAVILY into AI stuff, specifically "large language models." They told me that it was perfect for search engines, I told them that it was terrible for it, as it often provides false information. They did a random search just to prove me wrong. The answer was false. "But you see, now you can correct it, and that's why it's so awesome!" I flat-out told them that that's what makes it horrible. Any regular person, practically everyone on the internet, will do a search and take the result for granted. People with strong biases, people who want to deliberately spread misinformation or people who want to "troll" are the ones most likely to "correct" said AI, making the AI search engine absolutely useless as over time, it will only contain biased data and misinformation.

so the word chat in the traditional sense is a misnomer in relation to you
ChatGPT
Yes, you could say that the term "chat" is a bit of a misnomer when applied to interactions with me. In human-to-human interactions, chatting typically involves not only the exchange of information but also personal connection, understanding, emotion, and often some shared context or experience.

With me, while I can generate text that may seem conversational, there's no personal connection, emotion, or understanding behind it. I don't have personal experiences or feelings to share, and I don't perceive or understand the conversation in the way humans do. So while we can have a back-and-forth exchange of text, calling it a "chat" in the traditional sense might not fully capture the nature of our interaction.

You don't need to know the arcane syntax for code as much with AI, but it still helps to think like a programmer so you know what to tell the AI to do. I find that due to prompting challenges and limited context, it helps a lot to structure projects for AI using a component architecture. AI is much better at writing small to medium sized functions with explicit inputs and outputs where it doesn't have to understand the scope of the entire project all at once.

What I personally like about AI is that it forces global government from municipal to federal and international, to stare directly at the fact that our current way of distributing income is not working. These job shortages will force people out of jobs, and as a necessity for their livelihood, it will be vital to provide a basic income for them that is not based on how much they work, but based on their essential needs.
If we fail to do this, we will fail at being basic human beings, and we will fail at making the most out of AI. Because AI does not need to be a power over tool, but rather a shared power tool, and society as a whole can benefit from a tool that allows people to live without working. Pairing AI and social policies that provide people with direct income is the best way to maximize well-being, freedoms and economic development.

Warning: pointless epistemological debate incoming.

(0:10) "... all a large language model does is predict what's the most likely next word that you're going to use and then it extrapolates from there. So not really very intelligent."
(3:14) "... how most people work is, we all are autocorrect on steroids to some degree."

Prediction and extrapolation, those sound to me like characteristics of the kinds of things that swirl about the notion of intelligence. Of course, rarely does anyone ever define or pin down the term "intelligence", so, in long anguished or rapturous hot takes online, the word means whatever the person with an opinion about it wants it to mean. (And to follow the rule, I won't bother trying to define it here either.) But I would like to point out an analogy I often use to try to understand the "intelligence" of machine-learning systems: whenever I come across an LLM program, I generally think of it as being simultanously brilliant and impaired, as having capabilities I don't understand and obvious limitations. This contrast reminds me of what on wikipedia is called "savant syndrome". Because I'm not inclined to think of people with that kind of condition as "unintelligent" -- at least, as in "entirely lacking human faculties of intelligence" or, more to the point, "subhuman" --, I'm also not inclined to think of LLMs as "unintelligent". Limited or thwarted or ineffective in some way, yes. And less useful so far than their engineers and salespeople would prefer. But not unintelligent.

I feel like the big difference is effort. When an artist draws inspiration from another artist and tries to replicate their style, that artist will actually take the time to sit down and really study the person they've been inspired by. They have to practice, work hours and hours every day in order to capture the skills that the other artist had. In a way, there's a lot of respect being shown to that other artist. But with this, there's literally not a single ounce of respect or effort. There's no thought being put into what made the art style so unique, what makes it so memorable, how much work it takes to replicate it. It sees the artwork as nothing more than another picture you can find in a magazine and, in a few seconds, pops out a copy. It lacks the most important aspect of what makes art art, the soul. Unfortunately though, there's too many people that either can't see that or just don't care. Why pay an artist and wait for them to create something when I can have a machine do it in like 5 seconds? To me, it's the digital equivalent of that one ignorant person back in your youth  who would call your art just a bunch of doodles.

I will say that I think the sampling argument is actually a good one to make, only, it happens at a level that's much more granular than music sampling is so we don't recognize it as such. Like, for example, if I took an entire picture, put tracing paper over it, and traced it, and called it my picture, we'd obviously cry foul at that. What if, instead, I took someone's picture of a face, and then traced the outline of their head. Then I took someone else's picture of a face, and traced the eyes from that. Then someone else for ears, someone else for a nose, so on and so on. At that level, the "sampling" argument is super easy to see, right? Like if you knew the source images, you'd see the eyes and be like, "no way, you didn't draw this, this is from dippopoccomucus's anime girl drawing."

I could repeat that process, but trace a little less. One picture I only trace the outline of a jaw, then another picture I trace the cheeks, and on and on again. Surely I'm creating something that borders on being a cryptid, but, we'd still recognize it as being sampling. What AI like stable diffusion are doing is essentially this practice, but in much smaller chunks. Sometimes single line strokes, maybe just a splash of color, even if it's just a little gradient. It's capable of adjustments to copy-pasted stuff, that makes it less copy-pastey. It can internally categorize things enough to have certain lines be categorized almost like different brush strokes, and so maybe one of the things it does is trace a line using a different type of stroke. Both the line and the stroke themselves were sampled, too, it just categorizes things well enough that it is able to pattern-match and interchange things that are compatible.

A simple example is like, if you used the prompt, "Yoda, but he's purple", it would be fairly easy for it to see the keyword of "purple", have it categorized as a color, know which pictures were categorized with Yoda, be able to tell that the primary color in those pictures was green, which is also a color, and then do a swap. Probably end up with a purple tree in the background too. If you were to take a random picture of Yoda, photoshop him purple, and sell it as your OC Groda (do not steal), again, we'd call foul. But take that exact process and distill it into tinier chunks, and that's what the AI is doing.

It's easy to anthropomorphize AI, especially since we call the training process "learning", saying things like, "it knows what Yoda looks like", "It knows what purple is", stuff like that, but it's important to remember that it doesn't KNOW shit. It doesn't understand the concept of Yoda (not that any of us do, really), it just knows that that word seems to be related to a ton of pictures that have a lot of similar imagery, and it can then categorize those all together, and heck, once it's got the criteria for what "Yoda" maps to, it can even pick out other pictures in the set that are also likely pictures of "Yoda" even if they're not tagged as such. A troll doll or two might sneak in there, so it wouldn't be unthinkable to see an AI give you a purple Yoda with super tall hair, but at the end of the day it's just making millions of these categorizations and, even if only on a tiny level, is just putting stuff together in a way that it roughly matches the categorizations you specified.

This is mostly a simplified version of any AI process, rather than just Stable Diffusion itself. I'm less familiar with what exactly stable diffusion is doing, but from what I can gather, it takes existing images, flattens them into what it's able to understand as basic/similar components (the computer version of us saying "oh this is a picture with a house and some trees), adds a bit of staticy randomness to it called noise, then does a similar process in reverse with a little more randomness to create a new image. The reversing process can be adjusted on the fly with whatever text prompts you added (ie., it's reversing this process on a picture of yoda, but this is the stage where it takes all the "green data" and makes it purple instead). The pictures and properties of pictures that it takes all follow the logic I was talking about for all AI, and then to actually make the picture itself, it's just this collapsey-staticy-destaticy-decollapsey process. If that's so, then it explains why sometimes evidence of signatures pop up in the ai-generated images - it's taking an existing image, and just applying the world's most high-tech blur tool to it.

This comment got way bigger than I expected and at this point I'm making it mostly for me, but, the tl;dr is that I don't think the sampling argument should be dismissed out of hand, just because it's only sampling at a computer-obvious level rather than at a human-obvious one. I can't make any moral judgements on the AI itself, all work is derivative and even my youtube comment is somehow derived from the Epic of Gilgamesh. But I think that there's a little more merit to the theft argument than may be immediately apparent, and that the process could be considered much closer to copy-pasting with the blur tool on than just "taking inspiration from" existing work.

Hi :) these questions are interesting to ask ourselves.

I want to add a distinction between the law of copyrights and ethical dilemmas as two separate entities (even if closely interlinked).

Copyrights differ from country to country and most people aren't knowledgeable about them. By law - at least in the UK and most European countries - you cannot sell fanart legally. You would have to pay a license to use or buy the copyrights. Many people who sell fanart either do so because they are unaware of the copyright laws and therefore unaware of the risk they are taking (of being found and asked to pay royalties) or they are aware and are choosing to behave against the law (i.e. theft). A style doesn't fall under copyright laws, same for stick figure type of creations. Collages are difficult under copyright laws and quite complex.
Copyrights also apply to pictures taken of art. For instance, you technically cannot post a picture you have taken of a painting still protected by copyright without obtaining the rights of the painting's copyright owners first. It may be okay only if it's part of the background: let's say you were taking a photo of your friend at the pub and there happens to be a painting in the decor.
Furthermore, copyright also applies to alteration made to the artwork without consent which challenges the right to integrity of the work. This is important because it can protect the artist from derogartory misuse, e.g., you could create a portrait and that image could be used by someone who then adds offensive symbols to it, denaturing the artwork's original intent.

Most people also think, because of social media, that they can post pictures and videos freely without concerns about copyrights. In reality, you should obtain the consent of the people present in the images. If a person sees themselves in a video or photo you have posted, they have every right to ask you to remove it under copyright laws.

(Memes are an interesting copyright debate by the way).

Hence, with AI, under copyright law (and not ethical questioning), if the app uses images in its database to create something new without prior consent, it is theft as it is using artwork without the creator's consent and potentially affecting the right to integrity of the artist and its work.
From an ethical point of view though, there lies the debate. That debate is therefore not necessarily on AI but on copyrights in general. Such as, when should copyright applies? When do we believe we cross a line? How do we judge intent? How do we protect creators without limiting the community from getting inspired by one another? Etc.

However, people who share their photos to use the app, may not have read the terms and conditions and/or may have given full royalty of their own copyright (photography copyrights are automatically assigned to the person who took the picture) or accepted a license to use (most likely) without being properly informed of what it means. That is an other important ethical dilemna. Agreeing to a license to use without being informed about how copyright works and what it entails, could mean that people may have given consent for their image to be used by the app by other users. It could result in people having no protection and no support from the app if their image ends up being used for propaganda work that goes against their values, illegal pornographic images or any sorts of images the person may not want to be linked to.

Among visual artists, the common practice that we have judged ethical is to credit the artist when sharing their work, when doing fan art or when creating something heavily influenced by them. Maybe AI apps could include that in their coding somehow. Who knows?

I'm a software developer/DevOps professional turned software architect. I've been in the industry since 1999 and have adapted constantly. I agree with you ‚Äì AI will eventually replace classic software development, but I'm cautious about predicting when. People often underestimate the trade-off between abstraction and efficiency; coding won't disappear entirely because of this. Additionally, AI is incredibly energy-intensive. I'm unable to make the maths on my own, but the amount of energy it would take to replace all the traditional software in use today with AI systems should not be overlooked. Unless there are major technological breakthroughs, it'll take longer than many think for AI to become truly accessible for everyone. You can add to that that social transformation is always slower than technological advancement. I'm sure I will need to start reinventing myself again soon and it won't be easy, but that is how this industry has always been.

I see arguments a lot that still ‚Äî in this era ‚Äî dismiss art as a nothing hobby, much less any kind of lucrative or meaningful career. People who are not artists tend to picture only traditional familiar forms of art, such as oil paintings or charcoal-on-newsprint figure drawings... basically the stuff that earns the creative kid in the family that Rose Art beginner set for the holidays every year, or gets a nod from someone looking thru a gallery... while these are valid and strong visual art methods, art is EVERYWHERE. The chair you sit in, the car you drive, the speakers on your desk, plastic sports trophies and the ugly concrete state buildings downtown ‚Äî everything boring and tremendous in the world has a designer, and that's a LOT of artists at work.
I feel AI largely removes not only soul or passion individually from the artist, but from those who would buy their art or lend any audience to it. It must be realized and appreciated that the real world puts us all in the day-to-day situation of wanting purpose, and an artist feels no differently. A bare fraction of us get to work on the art that drives us or feeds our souls on a constant basis, and often we need to just do what we must to survive. AI doesn't just threaten to interrupt a hobby, it potentially takes jobs and livelihoods away, and no matter what you do for a living it wears at the spirit when you feel you might have lost your place.
In the meantime I hope we all keep working on what we want to, as much as we can, in spite of things feeling watered down

My two cents on AI and art is that I think we should be a bit careful with sayings like "The AI will never as creative as humans or AI can never match a human's creative process".
There are strong indications that humans' learning processes are exactly same as AIs at the base level. The current difference is that the AIs that we are seing around is "Narrow AIs" which are trained to do one certain task and deliver one single objective.
We possess "General Intelligence" similar to "General AI", .we learn from information and experiences we have and convert them into art we create. Compared to the Narrow AI which doesn't have the broad range of experiences and information that we have.
Now the dilemma starts when we have a general or near general AI and it is able to create "better than human" art from its own experiences. Which is quite likely as AI can literally experience hundreds or thousands of year of information and live through it.
If we define our art being superior to and more creative than AI, I am afraid this would lead to disappointment when the general AI arrives.
I think beauty of Art is in its indivuduality. The certain experiences and certain emotions that we have lead to a certain reflection of an art, which is truly unique to its creator. And this is what makes each art piece unique and valuable. A resonance off an indivudual that will never repeat again.
"AI will democratize art" In a world where art is far, far, far more accessible than ever.
