As an artist, I think I've identified why AI art specifically hits this horrible, gut-wrenching dread button for almost every artist I've talked to:
It jams its finger right onto every artist's first and worst insecurity - "Why should I make this if someone else can make it better?"
And the answer, of course, is that we love to create, and we love making art, and our unique personhood and experience means that the art we create will not be quite like anyone else's. We eventually learn to trust our audience when they say "holy shit! Two cakes!"
But the existential dread doesn't ever fully neutralize. It scabs over and eventually scars, but it's still a sore spot. We pour years of our life into improving our craft, cursed with the artist's perspective of fixating on the flaws in our own work. We eventually accept that constant improvement means we'll lose the ability to enjoy our older work. We have to learn not to self-deprecate and to trust our audience to draw their own conclusions.
So when someone takes their thumb, jams it right into that old wound and proudly crows that their Anime Waifu Generator can do exactly what you do but better and cheaper, it hurts like hell, no matter how untrue or irrelevant it is. It's pain on pain, exacerbated by the gleeful dickishness of the people being most aggressive about it.

It's an old, solved problem. We've all already learned how to create despite feeling outclassed. We know how to practice focusing on the merit of our own, unique work instead of constantly comparing ourself to others.
That doesn't mean it doesn't hurt. It just means the pain will pass.

AI / ML algorithms require training to become proficient at solving problems. They do this largely through training cycles where candidate networks are given a dataset to categorize (Recognition), or an input set (a query) meant to be used to generate a result set (ChatGPT). It can take hundreds of thousands, or often more cycles to fully train a network. And creating that training data is the key here.

With either approach, there has to be a target solution set for each test. What is the optimal output for the given input?

For music, it's not just "what is musically correct in terms of phrasing, theory, and key" that determines a hit.

It's the subjective state of a statistically large enough subset of our population to hear the track and like it for what ever reason. That subjectivity means that it will be nearly impossible to develop the training regimen for a generative network for music to teach it to create new hits.

Certainly, it will be able to mimic existing structures and sounds. But it will never be able to really innovate in the way that humans do. Because true artists in the field aren't making music to sound like anything else. They're crafting their own sound.

So, perhaps the copy-cat musicians and producers will have a harder time, as generative networks will focus on the latest trends looking backward. But the true innovators will always be essential to moving humanity forward, progressing in the art and science of making music.

Nobody outside of artists and people wasting more time than they should on analyzing somebody else art cares about an art piece's journey. Nobody that watched Endgame cared about all the VFX artists that were overworked making it. Nobody who can't afford a 3 million dollar paining is going to care about it. Nobody cares about how overworked animators are in Asia - hell, most people in the west don't even know most of the cartoons they watch are storyboarded in the west but animated in the east.

As for artists, they need to realize something very important, your painting isn't worth what you say it's worth. It's worth what people are willing to pay for it. If people aren't willing to pay you enough for your work for you to make a living that's not their problem, that's your problem. There's a reason most historical art was either made in service of something or someone else. A monk that illuminated a manuscript had a monastery to support him. A knife maker that carved an intricate handle was selling the blade first and foremost. Michelangelo did no paint the Sistine chapel, the papacy hired him to paint it. And things were not much different in the east. Most art produces in the east came from those rich enough to have the time to waste on making art and writing poems. Most people in the past, just like know, don't really care about art. Art is something we consume, not something we analyze. I remember in school, we used to analyze poems and I always hated it. Not because I wasn't good at it but because it felt like we were putting words in the mouths of mostly dead people. The poet already wrote what the wanted to. Trying to find meaning, especially when your a century or more removed from his death is pointless. It's an exercise in futility. An extremely political poem satirizing someone might be read completely differently without the historical context it was written in, and for most people, they will never be exposed to that historical context. The work must stand on it's own. And that right there is the problem with your argument. For most people, how a work was composed and made matter not. For the artists, the art historian, the art critic,? Yes, for those categories it matter. But for Joe average who's just looking at a nice painting and who will forget 90% of it the moment he walked/clicked away? No. And it's the same for corporations. Any studio exec that cares about the artists under his employ will probably not get very far. A POS like Weinstein on the other hand? he's made more successful movies than most Hollywood producers put together. Why? Because they were just products he was good finding a clientele for and advertising to said clientele.

Art is a product. Not because I say so but because everybody outside artists treats it as such, and because artists treat it as such whenever they want to eat. These AIs do nothing different that what an artists might do. All this flowery talk about emotions and feelings is all nice and good, until you realize the whole point of an animation departmental is for each and every artist working there is to draw just like the person next to them. Once the character sheet is complete, you don't get to deviate from it, not if you want to still be able to afford rent and food at the end of the month. Most artists get payed to not be original. To not draw what they want or how they feel. They get payed to slowly go insane drawing imperceptibly small variants of the same character or scene over and over again. AI is going to put all those people out of work. It's also going to put story bord and concept artists out of work. It's basically going to put anyone and everyone that's making products that falls under the art category out of work. If your art isn't a product then you have nothing to worry about since the AI won't be able to replace everything you bring to every individual work of art. The fact that artists all over are going insane over AI art and accusing it of doing exactly what they did, learn from previous artists, seems to indicate most artists are fully aware they're making products and al this over-analyzing crap is nothing but nice packaging.

And to any artists still reading, please remember that most successful authors aren't successful because they're good, they successful because they never gave up where more talented people did. In the world of AI art it will be up to you to convince people your "subpar" human art is worth their time. There will probably be people willing to do it for you, for a fee, but you need to realize, you're still selling a product at the end of the day and if people aren't willing to pay you for it, then it's not worth what you think it is. Also, maybe, just maybe, don't give your art away for free on DeviantArt. It's hard to make people pay for what they can get for free. Not to mention that giving your art away for free is how the AI models got fed. You might have had to visit museums to learn from previous generations, Midjourney just needed to go to DeviantART. If an AI is trained on your art the problem isn't that you didn't give permission - your permission is as irelevant as that of the masters you saw in the museum - it's that your art was easily available for the AI researchers to feed into the machine. And no, copyright won't help you with this one.

Even the best case scenario for AI you gave still feels very sad to me. There's something very solipsistic about taking these fundamentally collaborative mediums and putting the whole workflow into the hands of a single person by just automating the parts they're not professional at. That doesn't sound utopian to me, utopia would be the power to meet new artists to create together without the constant dread of wondering how you'll pay the bills or whether the next project will be profitable enough.

If I have an idea for a game I want to create, I don't want it to just spring forth fully formed from my mind, I want to spend time with people who'll be just as passionate about it as I am. I want to meet the animators, composers, concept artists, programmers, game designers and more who'll want to work on the project with me. I want to talk with them and share ideas about it, I want to create alongside them, I want to hang out with them when we're not creating and when the project is done I want to talk to them about what ideas they might have that we can create together. The core of collaborative art isn't that you get a higher quality product, it's the act of collaborating and making connections with other people. I hope the future of AI doesn't make people forget that.

I've worked in various creative, copyright-aware fields since the early 80s. Depending on my age, I might have different opinions about this, but as of now, I view it as another tool and, potentially a collaborator in the future. Think back to the classical scribes -- how would they view a word processor or text generator? A tool to relieve their calligraphic burden or as a usurper taking their creative and financial raison d'art from them? Humans are adaptable. Change is rarely undone and reset, we just change ourselves...or our children and grandchildren do. Music, writing, art, language, technology...it's really all part of the same conveyor of building on what came before to leave our legacy lest we stagnate into robotic mediocrity.

I think this is a similar disruption to what record players were to musicians around the 30s. It doesn't fully replace live performance, but there are kinds of demand that can be satisfied with this mass produced art-like thing. Of course, for someone who values the process will not be satisfied with an AI-generated picture. For the rest, AI will outcompete artists by being cheaper.
I don't believe it's plagiarizing to AI generate "art" in the style of a human artist. You could just as well pay an artist to copy the style of another artist, and it's still a separate creation. The only difference is that now it's cheaper. Of course it's nice to specify if one takes a lot of inspiration from someone else, but it's not mandatory, because it's a new creation. Whether it's for profit or not shouldn't matter. Copyright protects the concrete, materialized creation, not the style.

I agree with almost everything you said, but I do think that the onus should be on these companies to track the images they use. The datasets should all be publicly available, the artists should be able to find their artworks in these sets, and they should be able to opt-in/out. There needs to be more responsibility on the part not only of the companies providing the AI art producers, but the people who put together these datasets. Right now, it's all "I don't know, I just used it, I just found the image and included it" etc. But that's really not good enough for something that will cause such a profound change in society, in people's individual lives and livelihoods, in the accessibility/valuation of art. These people and companies need to get themselves in gear - they are mostly individuals or groups of computer nerds, not ready to deal with these kinds of changes that they have brought about. I respect that, and I also respect that it will take a lot of time and money to implement my idea. But I think that's more important. AI is supposed to be efficient, but it should ultimately be a *choice*. I should be able to choose whether I go to a human artist or computer. I should be able to choose whether I want my art/photo/likeness included in a dataset. I should not be told that it's too much time and money and, therefore, that that choice is a waste of time and money. These are things that should've been thought about long before this point, ideally. But they weren't. So we need to do it now, while it's happening. And if it messes up the AI revolution for a few years, I think that's acceptable for humans to be properly respected AND responsible.

On the one hand, I can see trillionaires being minted as the cost of labour dramatically decreases and smaller groups of individuals are able to create conglomerates and multinational companies.

But on the other hand, if millions are displaced and lack employment, who will be purchasing the goods and services that these companies produce? Where will governments get the tax revenue to function? How will they prevent social strife, insurrection, and conflict?

Maybe it will be like the dystopian movies where the trillionaires and their families flee the earth and take up residence on luxury space habitats while hordes of autonomous machines police the earth, dig for resources, and enslave the rest of the population.

There's a fatal flaw in AI generated code that makes it hard to get around a human supervisor. Even simple code in a major language from a perfect prompt has a few percent error rate, but as the AI builds on top of its own errors, the error rate compounds until the whole class comes apart from duct-tape upon duct-tape. I think the accuracy problem is an Achille's heel, just like it is for self-driving cars. Those last 2% are really hard to get to. But when you have a human supervisor continuously keeping the code on track, AI can help one programmer work for two or three people.

The simple answer is yes, if the code improves on the current work, it will likely be accepted, but even if they didn't accept A.I. code, how would they know if it's human or A.I. code?

Valve just recently got into a huff with A.I. on its store front, at first banning it, but I knew they would have to back track because it's going to be almost impossible to prove if work is done by humans or A.I. and considering that A.I. is going to be used everywhere, it would be crazy to not accept that work if it's better than what's already there.

For the time being, A.I. code is likely to be worse than human code, especially from a pro, but that is likely to change overtime where A.I. code becomes better than most human code, if not better than the best, so for now, it's handy for people that are not good coders or are just learning, but eventually, I suspect it's going to code better then even the best.

what he said about coding not being the source of value is kinda what i have been trying to get across with art, the value is in the creativity not the technical proficiency. i think this is something Hollywood has lost track of, they are so dedicated to making their movies more flashy, showing of their cinematography and cgi and ignoring the creative element of movie making. bringing it back to ai art, ai art is very proficient in the process of creating visuals, but it's not creative, it doesn't have the human creative drive, left to its own devices the AI will not create anything, it will just sit there forever.

same with programming, software is a means to an end not an end unto itself. when i write software i'm not writing it to be some cool bit of software, i'm writing it to solve a problem, to empower users or companies to do things they couldn't do on their own. most of my job is talking to the users, figuring out what they want and finding out how i can help them. a lot of times they have an idea of what they want done but when you drill down to WHY you find what they want done won't solve their problem and you can propose solutions that will not only solve that problem but a number of other related problems...THAT is the value of a programmer, not our ability to write code, but our ability to look at and design systems.

There is a critical misconception in people‚Äôs concerns. The advancement of AI/LLM in coding surpassing human capabilities is an inevitable evolution. In Larry Niven's "Known Space" future history, the people of Earth eventually reached a homogenous race of tanned people, not white, black, yellow, or red. To distinguish this generic melting-pot race "Flatlanders" became their nickname. This is meant in the same vein as "Hoosiers", but natives of a planet rather than a continent, country, or state.

Other such names denoted different planetary populations, such as the "Crashlanders" of the planet We Made It, who literally crash-landed, and "Mountaineers" from Plateau, for the immense mountain mesa poking out of a hot, hellish environment reminiscent of Venus. The mountain sticks up high enough that the top plateau is habitable by humans. It's said that the pilot of the first colony ship saw the plateau sticking up out of the boiling fog below and said "will ya lookitthat" giving Mount Lookitthat its name.

There are probably others, but the homogenously-raced Flatlanders was what I specifically wanted to mention.

Painting and poetry gave way to other art forms a long time ago, new forms were created such as cinema. They are still used of course, but are not mainstream (partly a good thing maybe?) and being able to create something truly new with those forms is extremely difficult without changing the form itself. The medium is the message and all that jazz...

The near future is VR, computer games and cinema merge, VR and social media spaces will merge. AI will create new forms of art where the actual 'art' I.e. Technical skill, thought and process lies in other areas.

Concepts like Tilt Brush by Google show a possible future for painting and sculpture, where once the detail and resultion, as well as haptic feedback are realistic enough you could imagine it as a totally valid evolution of painting. Painting in 3dimensions, painting environments, even collaboration in real time around the globe in a shared virtual space. Text to video promises the possibilities of movies only Jodorowsky could have dreamed of, and access to the common man/woman, much as the digital camera opened up photography to your average person in a far more profound way than Polaroids or getting your photos developed at the store. With access that makes these art forms more available to others, comes the loss of privilege. In some areas it will eventually make real hand created paintings more expensive, but less people will buy them in general.

It is one of those situations where you have to learn to transfer your skills and evolve, or find a way your artwork still stands out as unique. Personally I believe that the vast majority of artwork these days is simply merchandise, painted with the intention to sell right from it's inception, these AI images are just making this more obvious. Real art is process, the finished artwork is an artifact. So then you have to ask, what is the process of AI art, well there's the coding and development (you'll say that's technical not art, however the way you use and develop your tools for any physical artwork is still considered art if also technical) and then there's how you decide to use it, jerry rig it, how well you're able to make it bend to your imagination and what you do in order to make that happen, how you use it in ways no one has thought of.

I think reproducing other forms of art is a pretty boring thing for this new technology, trying to use it to create new forms of art will be what really stands out in the next ten years.

Overall we're all gonna die, even Shakespeare is dead, and one day he'll be forgotten and all his works. Art's in the moment, it's process, it's becoming... an alchemical process that works back on the artist as much as the artist works on it and if you're lucky it changes others too, if not what's the point? You'll just be creating future landfill, maybe beautiful, intricate landfill, but landfill just the same.

Artists should just make a Syndicate, even if it's just online to post their artwork, it will prevent not only stealing from techbros and such to use their work to feed an algorithm, but also avoid other problems as people in ebay using their artworks to sell shirts and a big etcetera.

Heck, even an art page with a protection clause will work, or even forcing people who make ai "art" to put watermarks on the works generated via AI

Edit: seeing how the trend has made "progress" i will risk to say, it maybye will not be necessary, this fashion about "art tech" probably already has a timer on his head.

Its already like that with other mediums, as things become more easily accessible they lose value. Thinking of books, photographs, visual art and music. I agree that self driving cars are a bad idea, and awesome video. I liked the addition of the "one more lane" montage. I do have two things to add which are about the comment at 3:42 that tesla autopilot turns off 1 second before a crash. This may be true, but Tesla actually counts any crash within 5 seconds after autopilot disengagement as a crash while on autopilot in their statistics. This is in the fine print on their stats in their reports and I think mentioned during a CVPR conference talk. I would have instead mentioned also more about how Waymo, Cruise, etc actually have human drivers that perform the high level planning for their autonomous cars, so they are really not as autonomous as you would expect. When they see eg. a delivery truck blocking the road, the car calls for help from the human and then the human creates a route around the truck. I have a friend who works on the software for this system at one of the major autonomous companies I mentioned.

The Luddites weren't just monkeys that thought we should all return to living in trees, they were a revolutionary political movement. One specifically opposed to the way in which industrial weaving machines were being used as an excuse to lower human wages and decimate the lives of the working class. They didn't succeed partly because capitalist factory owners decided that the blood spilled by the twelve thousand British soldiers used to exterminate dissenters was worth less than the money being generated by their factories. Now over one hundred years later, their ancestors have invented a tool able to take human culture itself and produce a cheaper, lower quality imitation. How could anyone resist?

Abigail Thorn (philosophytube) once did a video trying to define creativity. She landed on the crucial aspect of anticipation. Basically what you make exists first in your mind, and then enters the canvas, or yoy play it on your instrument. A photographer sees the picture and it's composition before they take it, and a writer anticipates the text they write before they write it. On some level weather it feels mysterious or like the result of technical skill, art is first shown to you, then you put it into the world in a tangible or sharable form. If you generate an immage using AI, and you are stunned at it's beauty, you are one step away from making art, but if you just show people the thing, you aren't a painter, you are a tourguide (not to diss tourguides, they're awesome, and there is room for artistic expression in the field, it just isn't essential)

One thing to your point about human artists drawing pretty people or predominantly white people, etc. You have to consider that, especially for someone who's style is that kinda-anime-meets-pixar cartoon style, drawing people of races other than your own CAN open you up to accusations of caricature. I personally don't feel those accusations would hold much merit 99% of the time, but on the internet that doesn't matter - the accusation alone, regardless of merit, will ruin reputations and careers.

It's a lot like being a writer accused of not writing more female characters - as a writer you are told over and over to "write what you know", and if you're a self aware guy who thinks well I'm not a woman, I don't know what it's like to be a woman, so I'm gonna tell very male-centric stories because that's what I know! Then you get accused of being sexist for telling male-oriented stories focused on male characters. But if that same writer had tried to branch out, and write more women into his stories, he might not do a great job of it, then he gets accused of sexism for trying to break out of his comfort zone and stumbling a bit.

In short, creative people - artists, musicians, writers, etc - are constantly being told "STAY IN YOUR LANE" but the minute the listen to this advice they get told they're bigots for not including women, POCs, etc. So, internet, which is it?

It seems short sighted and disastrous in the long term. How is anyone supposed to become a an expert level worker that AI can't replace if there are no entry level jobs anymore? And if a large portion of your population is no longer employed due to AI, the who'll be able to afford all the automated corporations' products?

As someone who works in tech for a small startup, I can tell you right now that AI will not replace any serious or meaningful jobs any time soon. At least not within the next 5 years.

The reason being is that while ChatGPT and other LLM models are good as a quick lookup or fine tuning certain smaller details, it's still very far from any skillful decision making.

It is akin to a really smart 10 yr old. While it may know more than you in specific things, it still does not understand how different topics or bits of information interact with each other or effect each other. Now knowing that, what serious company do you think would replace their workforce with a smart 10 yr old?

AI is definitely the future, but as riding shotgun. The driver will still be human for the next few years.

Something to also remember with all these big companies announcing AI stuff is that they are publicly traded companies: they will do and say anything to get share price higher. There is a reason that the real leaders in the AI have not mentioned anything about replacing jobs, and that's because they understand that it's too early to make that conclusion just yet.

I think the problems here are overstated, at least for the time being. I haven't been approved for CoPilot yet but having heard from many others about it, it's really limited in its capabilities and languages supported and cannot read from a large amount of context in your current codebase. It's basically a quality of life time-saving tool that saves you from a bit of Googling now and then. Basically a smart snippet generator. What's problematic is that it's only really competent at creating small functions. What that might do is force you to use functional programming with many small functions that carry out simple tasks. What it seems great for is for helping save time starting up with a new framework that you're unfamiliar with, which is great because there are so many new frameworks cropping up left right and centre. I don't think it's good enough to worry about, and I doubt teachers will have any problem testing students with access to this VS Code plugin, if it gets so good that it becomes a problem, students should just be tested in a controlled environment like an exam, or be asked to explain what the code does and why they chose to build it in such a way. Furthermore, if it becomes such a prevalent tool, good use of the tool will become desirable, and thus we may not actually want to discourage students from using it, we may even want to encourage it or train them to use it efficiently.

I come from the beat production and sound design world where sampling ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù works or the world outside via field recordings, within respective terms, are utilized to create new sounds and music. I see the same thing happening with ai art. There are 2 things I am taking away from my experience.

By nature, I am a creative type. I enjoy creating new things by taking from the old. I guess you could say that I enjoy making old things new again by modifying what came before. With ai art I attempt to utilize multiple applications and photoshopping/photobashing techniques to further dilute the art styles that are contained within the checkpoint models. I enjoy experimenting with different models by mixing them together to create new styles, which is a similar approach to sample music production. Taking what already exists and creating something completely new is always the goal in this type of workflow. My interest isn‚Äôt in replication (creating something that already exists). I look for ways to push diffusions into territories the ai was not trained on. I like to break the ‚Äúgrid‚Äù so to say. Again, this is an approach that is very similar to beat production techniques. However, I do have the full understanding in how the ai was trained on copy protected work. Even custom checkpoint models today are trained on specific art styles from well known artists. Dead or alive. Because of this, I cannot accept full credit for the initial work that was utilized to cook a model. Credit might come from the practice in how one manages to manipulate a sample of an original piece, in such a way that the original intend and styling becomes unrecognizable. That is how I like approach my creative endeavors. This practice can be found in many forms of considerable art. Some are more masterful in their approach and thus are more recognized for it as well. However, with that being said, the art community should at the very least have control over checkpoint models or their own models they can create, which then in turn could be sold for profit. I‚Äôm also thinking in terms of licensing there could be deals made with artists who would allow certain pieces of art to be utilized commercially via a licensing fee. Otherwise, we should only have the ability to train the ai with our own artwork and style. Established artists should continue to maintain copyright of their own works, similar to to the practices we have in the music industry. Lastly, because of the recent ai art boom, I have developed an interest in pursuing digital painting/illustration because I would love to create my own art. I would love to train the ai on my own art style. My workflow would consist of illustrating a piece in photoshop and then running it through the ai engine to add or change details. Again, while I do truthfully enjoy ai art as much as I enjoy original works, I wouldn‚Äôt dare to disrespect an artistic professional. The time dedicated to developing masterpieces is invaluable. Everyone should respect that.

While I agree with the major points of this video (and congrats for pushing out of your comfort zone on this one, Benn!), the problem with advocating for a shift towards purpose-built autonomous vehicles based on distributed intelligence is that there are so many uncertain and unpredictable factors that can happen in the real world compared to a nice closed-world and fully-observable environment like the Boids simulation you were running on. Things break down in the real world, infrastructure, connectivity, sensors are noisy & unreliable, and what's to stop Timmy Trump from running into the autonomous vehicle-only lanes? By the time you've fully accomodated for all these factors, I'd argue that you're already more than halfway to solving the general self driving problem. I note that these aren't mutually exclusive solutions, though, so it may still be viable to pursue.

However, investing in public transport instead still makes so much more sense üôÇ

I think the key point is not that we should be alarmed at an a.i.'s ability to produce code, but that it could produce code we didn't ASK it to produce.  Maybe self-produced code is the result of an interpretation.  The a.i. developer instructs the a.i. to make reducing the time it takes to complete a task a goal.  Do your task as fast as you can.  Create code to shave off a few nanoseconds.  Then, the a.i. dev says to combine the functionality of contemporary computer languages.  With enough time and proper analysis of the a.i.'s activity, maybe a new language will be generated.  Parts would be recognizable, but it would be a mish-mash.  Then, the dev asks the a.i. to generate code for front end software, u.i., sound effects, a pleasing color palette.  Prompt it.  Encourage it.  Eventually, I think, a.i. would satisfy an ever-increasing number of demands.  I believe the biggest obstacle for truly impressive a.i. (as we are already losing interest in its ability to churn out essays and qualify its medical advice with "check with your physician, but....") will be merging the specialized a.i. into one.  Perhaps Dalle 2 and Chat GPT, an a.i. used to extrapolate effective proteins, and another to predict the spread of forest fires are incompatible.  But a.i. learning code will see things we may not.   Humans have often noted that a genius sees the connections between seemingly unrelated things.  And a universal a.i. will operate at a superhuman level, maybe they will provide insight into making more things into a single thing.  Coding will gallop right along with counting cattle from a drone, organizing voting districts, measuring happiness by facial recognition, inserting higher quality information into news broadcasts, or gaining an edge in the stock market.  The crack in the dam may release a deluge we cannot yet comprehend.

I'm a computer scientist, and it saddens me to see the toxicity from users toward artists, derived from the existence of these AI models. There's no justification for that, and there will never be.
The way current AIs work is definitely too close to the source and that needs to be taken into account for evaluating the ethics of those models, before we go out of our ways to monetize and capitalize on these models. I do hope that the laws will catch up quickly with this, and people will be prevented from continuing to capitalize on models trained using copyrighted data obtained without a license. As you mentioned the models could be trained exclusively on open-source and public domain images (I don't like the term copyright-free, because in most cases, it's not true -- having a permissive license doesn't cancel out copyright, only public domain does, and public domain doesn't exist in all countries), although this will very definitely result in much lower quality models with lower quality output -- not because permissive licensed art is inferior, but because there's less quantity of it.


That said, I do believe that with enough evolution of the technologies used for AI art, in the future we could get to a point where the process used by AI will be unique and original.
But this will require that the models learn about shapes and colors, instead of learning how to predict what an image looks like based on a prompt and random noise. I do not believe that creativity is a special thing that only fleshy brains can have, but rather an emergent property of the complex abstraction that our brain does, which is orders of magnitude more nuanced than current AI models (regardless of their size) can hope for.

At least the workers replaced by the industrial revolution were cleanly replaced by machines- they did not have their limbs wrenched off and used as components of those same machines- in the case of creative people we are seeing a process where Artists are being replaced by machines built out of the very things those artists created- it's a morally bankrupt act of cultural vandalism that will in the end leave us nothing but a culture saturated by derivitive clones of those original works.

Ai Art is a solution to problem that did not exist- there was no shortage of humans who wanted to make art. The saddest thing of all is that AI art will not replace artists in the legitimate sense that it will add the same value that human artists did to our culture- what it will do however is drown out those human creations in a tsunami of inferior deriviative garbage that will, by sheer volume alone, ensure that in the end humans will simply no longer feel able to contribute and many will give up on art entirely. On the upside a handful of people will have made themselves very rich in the process.

We are moving towards two possible scenarios (provided that AI is legit and not some elaborate version of a credit default swap). 1. Convoluted neo-feudalism. 2. Mass extinction though major economy collapse. Most likely it's going to be #2 followed by #1. Capitalist economy, and most of civilized world have exactly that, heavily reliant on consumer. If AI replaces 70% of workforce, it also displaces 70% of consumption of its product.
On the other note. I am not a developer, but I work very closely with a large group of developers in fintech. I honestly don't see how AI could write a clean code without somebody who knows what he/she is doing spends considerable amount of time "prompting". We tried. And unlike human developer, AI doesn't care about readability much. Even if you explicitly ask. So debugging that code is a major chore. Maybe in a future (although I don't see how. Maybe due to my low IQ) it'll be able to do better job more efficiently. It's not there yet by a wide margin.

Human PM will be replaced by AI too. We will simply get to where LLM interrogates the stakeholder(s) and works with the AI Agent Team to iterate rapidly on thin vertical slices to minimize the risk of inaccurate deliverables. Human QA will go away too. And at some point you would need only to map KPIs to a fully AI agent team and make the KPI their loss function. But also that might be how we all get paperclipped so maybe treat the AI team as a contractor team without access to your prod infra where their deliverable is a PR a human needs to merge into the prod codebase.
Finally, someone who doesn't fear monger. I've had enough of all these videos predicting the singularity event in the next 50 years, when we can't even prove that our AI technology works.

My problem with ai art aside from 'Its unethical to use unconsenting/unaware artist's art for ai learning' is that ai isn't human. And here me out, I know a lot of people think I'm going into the 'robot bad' side of things when that's definitely not the case.

While AI art is not inherently theft because it's not copying, it's still using all those art pieces for its own purpose and ONLY those art pieces. Humans always use other art for inspiration and nothing is original - I agree with those statements. But we also use our own emotions, experiences, opinions, and memories to create our art. Art ( whether it's music, visual art, dance, etc ) is all about expressing yourself and the way you view the world. Because of this, no art is the same, even if we're always taking each other's ideas.

AI can't do this. It can't add its own self into the art to make it its own. It only has other people's art to go off of. That's why I personally don't like it, because it's not original in even the barest sense of the word.

( Anyone feel free to add on whether you agree or not, I would love to hear everyone else's opinions :) )

There are two possible scenarios for a solution:

¬†1) In a self-driving car city, there are no humans involved, meaning there is no human error (there wouldn't be motorcycles). All the cars will be connected to a network where the cars can communicate with each other. In that way, it can be created an instantaneous response to minimize harm in all humans around,¬†for example with the car on the left manoeuvring as well, to create a controlled accident with less trauma. These are some basic limitations I've found.

¬†1. AI needs such detailed guidance that it takes longer to write the prompt than to code it yourself for anything real world.

2. You have to manually design the solution and break it down to very small steps to stand the remotest chance AI can code it. Even when you do, it really isn't worth it. The prompt does serve as useful documentation though.

3. Almost any real world problem is too complex for AI to design, code and test.

I‚Äôm not an artist but a lawyer and someone who sees the labour and copyright problems with this but also the paradigm shifting value in people being able to, with a bit of effort and time visualise their wildest dreams and nightmares through verbal commands.

I think the most practical legal solution in the future would be that AI companies would be forced to submit any work done on their servers to the public domain.

Let us for a second, make the huge assumption that the AI companies will also use only other public domain work in their database.

My question for you guys is that wouldn‚Äôt it still fuck over the art industry greatly even if the AI art product of the future is not copyrighted and users are not artists because people/entities can just create/use public domain visuals for their commercial purposes especially as a result of ever improving technology and specialisation of prompting down to a code?

If I am a small video game developer or comic book author, not being able to copyright specific art is not great but 1. I can still copyright everything else about the art including the dialogue, the name etc and 2. It comes with the benefit of much cheaper and less time consuming work hours. It would be a deal worth taking unless I‚Äôm a giant corporation where copyrighting specific icons is very important. For instance, even in a relatively ‚Äòbig‚Äô game like DS1, the visuals of the artorias or gwynn is far less valuable copyright property in the long run than the title itself and to a much lesser extent lore etc.

Overall, the commercial situation still seems to be difficult for those in a lot of similar visual/graphic art industries and I sympathise with them but don‚Äôt see any solution which would preserve the professional status quo from say, 3 years ago in the industry or better.

I can't speak to AI mimicking production/mixing/mastering, but so far, AI-composed music is nowhere near even writing an adequate melody or composition. I'm sure in the next 10 years it'll be a different story, but showing AI subtlety, nuance, and the ever-elusive taste, it's just not there yet.

Love your channel, love your work. Have to agree to disagree on this one. Not everyone, even in the art community, is all torches and pitchforks. Countless respectable, responsible professional artists and creators use AI as the tool it's intended to be. I suspect your experiences with "everyone says they hate it" are suffering from a bit of confirmation bias, especially considering how well the Terraforming Mars kickstarter seems to have gone.

I agree that most junior level programming will disappear in the next 5-10 years, specially in business specific applications (aka "VBA crimes"). However, as you can learn from the adoption rate of no-code/low-code, the industry is very slow to change and adopt. The main point is: it is very uncertain if AI can anytime soon can create higher level functions. What you can see today is replicating some "hello world" stuff, very unspecific, generic copy&paste from the net. It is amazing and will change how code is written - however, i am uncertain it can replace a senior developer who works on a production system with sometimes hundreds of complicated business rules on a single function. As IA does not understand anything, i am afraid it might get stuck at the 70% line - it can produce something that is almost good enough, but getting the next 10-15% to make it useable for production might take an insane amount of effort. I am also unsure if AI generated code will every be good enough for critical functionality, as LLMs just replicate what they have as in input.

We use LLMs a lot every day, and we have a term for the typical LLM results: "word vomit". As you get more experiences with generated content, you can spot "word vomit" or "pixel vomit" very quickly: AI generated images are off in many ways and so is much of the code it generates today.

To be clear: it will become much better and an below average developer will be in deep trouble - as the job will become much harder for a developer in the future. I also assume that developers will get paid MORE and will be in much higher demand. Why? When i created my first applications in 1995 most developers where fullstack - and the stack was very thin. I remember when PHP was introduced and the Java Server Pages guys made fun of it. Java Server Pages died out soon after, and the PHP ecosystem exploded. Then no-code showed up 20 years later and people predicted the death of all programming languages. Look inside a typical company, you might still find JSP applications and even worse: some niche programming language that was all the rage 20 years ago and is long forgotten - but still used by this one business app, that is kind of critical - not critical enough to be rewritten in an current language, of course.

My prediction is therefore:

#1 some teams will go full AI and will experience crazy productivity gains - and most of the developers will continue doing what they do today for the next 10-15 years.

#2 Yes, some copilot based technology will be used and we will see a big increase in productivity. Some companies already scale down teams by 2-3 developers (from 8-11) - and this seems to be highly effective for multiple reasons.

#3 It will take a VERY long time until LLMs will be adopted for on-premise production solutions. I would not be surprised if this is 10+ years

#4 we might soon enter a "AI cold winter" due to legal issues - blocking any investments for years to come. Expect companies to ban google copilot and similar tools due to legal concerns

#5 i am uncertain if there is a big first mover advantage in the application of AI at this point - companies seemed to rather wait for somebody else to take the risk and then move in quickly as soon as regulations and technology has become production ready.

#6 There are still a significant number of development teams who have not adopted even the basic practices: some teams even work without version control, no standard build pipelines or any testing. You can find projects that got started in 2023 with ZERO automated testing, no QM in the team, no coding guidelines etc. - in companies with 1K developers.

#7 decision makers do not like to take risks. Generative AI is currently the biggest liability and risk for a company. Yes, it is an amazing opportunity for a startup and a few early adopters - but most people have way to much to loose and nothing to gain from investing into it. So why should it take off quickly?

Just because we know how to build professional software does not mean that people actually do it.
Just because we have the power of generative AI for development does not mean that it will be adopted anytime soon - even IF it works "good enough".

I'd honestly love a self-driving car as a disability aid, speaking as someone who will never, for safety's sake, be permitted the freedom of travel that car owners enjoy. In an ideal world, that's what these things would be, not starry-eyed techno-dreamer "traffic fixes".

It's gonna take a workforce revolution to fix traffic. You need to require companies to transport their own employees, not employees to transport themselves. It would be efficient use of vehicles (cutting down on spare seats), and crucially, it would incentivise them to employ people more locally. You take the millions and millions of problems of, say, two people both doing inessential anywhere-jobs (which most jobs definitely are) just to have excuses to be allowed to keep surviving, both having to travel to each other's very far-apart city daily, when easily, they could just swap jobs... but they'd never know it. But you create a situation that discourages that sort of outsourcing in the first place and you don't even end up in that jam. And sure you could always point out a few anomalies but that'd be the point - they'd be anomalies, rounding errors - they wouldn't just be part of the normal mix.

Profit motive, it's all profit motive. Anyone serious about making society function properly needs to get rid of profit motive and work from that starting point. It's no good pretending it works. There's way too much evidence that it doesn't. It's bad systems design. Companies will still care about efficiency. The problem right now is they care more about enrichment than efficiency. You have to remove that overriding factor that keeps systems awful. You have to never have the excuse that I've got enough to fall back on to make as many mistakes as I want (which is disproportionately filtered-for among those in charge of things), and you have to never have the reason that it's better for me to let a thousand people suffer more so long as I suffer less because I'm "worth" several magnitudes of them.

That's how you transform the incentive to "go green" or "build smart" from vanity projects, optics massages, headline grabs, political flavour distinction, role justification busywork, and optional pride-of-work-face ego boosts... all motivations which will unsustain themselves at a whim... into actual honest-to-goodness what somebody in charge always wants to do for the sake of doing a good job of it. Remove the graemlin, let the cogs turn.

I think the problem is more how AI is used and less how and with what data AI is trained or even the whole concept of AI.

Copyright, law and ethics, tells us we can't just use other people's art in our own art without permission. But what does "using" actually mean? In music, it could mean, I use a sample from some band and build a new song around it. Perhaps even a sample everyone would immediately recognize. What using other people's art does not mean, is when you go to a museum, an Instagram page, or wherever you consume other people's art, then go home and make your own art which is inspired by all the art you've seen before. That's something no artist would have a problem with and that's how all artists in the history of art did it except for the first artists ever.
What happens with AI is much more like the latter one, not like the former one. The training data is NOT part of the model. It's only used to create the model. But not the training data but the model is what's being used to create AI art. Just like other people's art is used to create a new artist's skills by learning from it. Because AI learns, AI doesn't just copy.
Just ask yourself the following question: Would you tell new artists that they are not allowed to get inspired by or learn from your art or do you think other artists should be able to do that?

The best example for the difference between copying and learning is when I gave Dall‚Ä¢E the prompt to give me a man with a mohawk in a leather jacket on a Harley Davidson in the style of Vincent van Gogh. And that was exactly what I got. There aren't any originals from van Gogh where the AI could have copied the individual elements from. The AI actually had to learn how to do this.

I also heard about cases where people were able to reproduce virtually exact copies of original artworks with AI. However, in the studie I heard about (for transparency, I think it was done or financed by Google) they only managed to do this A in really rare cases and B only with the knowledge of the training data and C by purposely pushing the AI to produce a copy. That is NOT a realistic scenario.
Leaving that studie aside, it is just plausible, that the creators and users of AI are not even interested in that happening. They actually want to create something new, so they will actively try to avoid something which is already unlikely to happen in the first place.

However, there's one thing where the problem already CAN (doesn't have to) start with the training of the AI. Artworks of a certain artist can be part of training data, but training a model with the sole purpose of copying the artists style, is something only the artists themselves should be allowed to do. At least as long as the results get published. But when artists do that, AI could change from being a threat to being an artistic tool.
I think it's already a little bit lazy, not necessarily problematic, when you copy a certain artist's style by hand. But that at least is good for practicing. With AI, that doesn't give you the same benefit at all.

I also think there should be transparency about AI art. Just as with so much else, there's a competition in art. Even when it's not about money but "just" about the limited attention of your Instagram followers. Recognition is a totally legit currency for artists. You might win their attention by them having respect for you because you actually created this artwork. But they probably wouldn't give you the same respect when they know that you used AI to make it. So not being transparent about it, brings a bias into that comoetition.
However, you should also not overshoot it with your honesty and also loose the respect you might actually deserve. Because AI art does not equal AI art. You can type a prompt into a web based AI, generate 50 versions and then just take the best one, without having more influence than the prompt and the selection. Or you can use a local install of Stable Diffusion, where you can use several plug-ins like ControlNet which give you back some of the creative control, you load some of your own sketches which the result will be based on, perhaps you also create a completely original artwork which will be used as a style reference, you also don't just select the final result out of 50 versions but refine the result over and over again by slightly changing the prompt and doing some inpainting with new prompts and perhaps also new sketches for ControlNet, ...
Those are two completely different things which deserve a different level of respect. So yes, be transparent and mark your AI art as AI art, but in your own interest, just like at school in math, show your work. That way, you don't create any unfair bias to other "manual" artists, but you also regain the respect you actually deserve.

I personally believe, much like many others, that AI/ML will only speedup the rate at which bad programmers become even worse programmers. Part of the art of writing software is writing it efficiently, and you can't do that if you always use tools to solve your problems for you. You need to experience the failures and downsides in order to fully understand how it works. There is a line when it turns from an efficient tool to a tool used to avoid actually thinking about solutions. I fully believe that there is a place for AI/ML in making software, but if people blindly use them to write software for them it'll just lead to hard-to-find bugs and code that nobody knows how it works because nobody actually wrote it.

Even though in the future the action of writing code might not be necessary. All the concepts and theories from CS, Software Engeniting, Data Science, Math, etc. Would still be required.
The hardest thing about prompting is knowing what you actually want and how you want it. And to know that you need to know the theory and concepts.
In the open source community, we are always building on top of other people's code so programming has been getting more and more high level for a long time, like you showed in the video.
In the Social Media example, the orchestrator still needs to know that the application needs a database and that the database has tables tables schema, and so on (Concepts). But what is the best database to use for scaling? In a real-life project, there are thousands of similar questions, even though there may be a way out of coding there is no way out from studying the theory and concepts.

My prediction is that AI would lower the barrier to programming. But would also make dedicated programmers a lot more productive: the only requirements would be to know the concepts and theory. No specific syntax no programming languages. So any programmer would by default be able to write code in any language. Because we don't need to know syntax, it would be common to have Full-Full Stack programmers: who would be capable on FrontEnd, BackEnd, Data Science, Dev-Ops, Cypher Security and so on. A one-man startup. And you can be sure that the number of startups will skyrocket.

Finally, a person who prompts an LLM for code and runs it, is indeed a programmer (it is creating commands for a computer to execute). It might not be a coder but it is still a programmer.

Absolutely, you're completely right. I apologize for oversimplifying the complexities involved in the situation of Weimar Germany and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. 0:36 Slight correction: The people who make the AI don't write the code for it, they simply create the rules by which the AI learns. The AI learns itself when it is being fed the entire internet of text and images during the training process. What I'm trying to say is, the reason it is having this problem is because whoever is feeding the model the data is feeding it "Politically correct" and biased data or punishing it when it makes a politically incorrect statement or image (left wants diversity in their images of groups of people, so "whitewashed images" are not what google would go for). Also, it's likely that the foundation model isn't biased, it's the REFINED models using RLHF (Reinforcement Learning by Human Feedback) that creates biases afterwards. There's a possibility that the raw foundation model of Google's Gemini is extremely unbiased.

But yeah, key point is that the people who write the code only right the rules, they don't program in the bias. A great analogy would be writing the rules of evolution and letting the complexity of nature emerge over millions of years, which is exactly like the programmers writing the rules of how the AI learns and letting it learn by itself (Humans then go in and corrupt it with bias after the initial training process).

I think there will always be a market for human made art especially since AI lacks any sort of vision or intent behind it. You already see it in people's reactions to anything AI. AI at best imitates what humans do but for humans who wish to spend money on some music they'd rather settle for the real thing every time.

That being said, you are right about companies and big clients being unwilling to spend thousands in order to hire a composer to make music for them when they can just get an AI to do it. Unfortunately I think that that just represents the problem with our modern day creative economy: on top of consumers and producers, we have middlemen who have no respect for art or particular love for artists in most cases, but are the ones who are essentially financially supporting their careers. To them, artists are nothing more than employees who produce products for them to sell, and when they can cut costs by hiring a robot to do it, they'll likely settle for that.

As much as people say that this will lead to greater creativity, my worry is that it will likely lead to a bunch of layoffs in the professional space, and since corporations don't care at all about being creative, the music they settle on will end up becoming generic to the displeasure of the average consumer (who like I said finds AI soulless compared to human made art). Just look at how the video game industry works with big game companies jumping at live service games and monetization schemes. The one good thing that I see is that we may see music careers shift to the independent space instead of relying on corporations to hire them. A company may not want to spend thousands on hiring a particular artist they don't really care about, but I can see regular people giving small dollars to support a particular musician they personally like continuing to make music the way they can.

Of course that assumes that we as a society decide that all art should just be automated and somehow see no value in human made art at all. I mean, art as an industry always depends on us supporting it, but yeah we would be entering a dystopian future in that case. Let's just all hope that that doesn't come to pass.

The funny part is when Adam brought up the generative Ai features, as someone who actively uses it for fun and sometimes modify art pieces I work with, it just reminded me how empty their claims are.

How they train, and use this machine isn't even autonomous intelligence. It just breaks down images into pixels, remembers the details and static patterns of key features, the places them into logs which they call tags.

Meaning it's not intelligent. It's just an analog storage bank that will throw a bunch of static at the wall and mish-mash equations and pixel patterns together to make an image, and by no means can function or do anything without human input and management.

Exactly like the "self driving car"... Which cannot actually drive the car.

Although I agree overal, I think the timeline is way too optimistic. We need much bigger contexts and much smarter models, the best current models can do is very simplistic programming tasks. Sure it can throw out some simple website, or a snake game, but we already have tools that can do that without programming, with enterprise software or when developing on the edge, the best it can do at the moment is help you fill in some boiler plate code. Don't get me wrong, this still gives a huge advantage to programmers who use it, but it's far from being fully automated.

I think the biggest issue for now is hardware, as long as we need complete server rooms to run these LLM's it's not going to progress fast enough. And designing newer, faster, smaller, more energy efficient hardware just takes time...

So although probably technically possible in a few years, I don't think it will be scalable enough at that time untill much later.

Simple concept since I can tell you we are a little ways away from putting a system on a car that can determine head gear. My thought brings it back to a more simplistic approach based on instinctual nature, just now programmed. I'm going to give my thoughts in a stepped up version starting with basic and simple up to higher complexities. My view is that of someone going into electrical engineering, as well as a fireman on a department that services two of the most heavily used, midwest interstates. I have also added at the end of each order paragraph a summary of what devices and/or systems will be needed to include that order in a vehicle.

First order: All else fails, vier right, slow down. In countries where you drive on the wrong side of the road, vier left. This is simple as it would cause you to push you or the others into the shoulder away from oncoming traffic. This minimizes the chances that someone will be pushed into an oncoming lane and, assuming everyone is paying attention, will allow the person on that side to divert to the shoulder. This requires no input device other than danger detection.

Second order: Vier toward noted/mapped shoulder including grass areas w/o steep drop. No shoulder, Stop. This will be used in places where there may be a closer shoulder on the opposite side or in the case of construction where the shoulder was moved or on a bridge with no shoulder. This can be maintained by adding a single bit of information to all routed roads accessible to the car and updated based on reads by it or other cars. The basic system requires only a stored map of safe shoulders.

Third order: If all local lanes are moving in the same direction, and there is a large gap, vier towards it, including the inside shoulder of a highway. This is the first step in complexities relying on simple wide angle cameras or any form of distance and object detection already used. In this case, the motorcyclist/scooterist could potentially take the penalty; however, they also have the smallest footprint in a lane and the highest capability of accelerating out of the way. This method will only be used if their presence is not detected, either based on them being a distance from the sensor or any other occurrences that throw off the detection. This requires only local awareness technology already in use.

Fourth order: Large gaps detected nearby by others, vier in direction. This begins a much more complex area whereby the cars start communicating with each other. This networking is already being put in place by modern self driving cars or assisted driving cars. This order relies on the other vehicles informing your car of potential avoidances and where it can vier with the same idea as moving toward the right for the shoulder, only this time its a moving shoulder/gap. This requires sensor' information to be broadcastable locally, possibly over a decided wifi channel.

Fifth order: Communicate to other smart cars to make a necessary gap to allow yours to divert. This is merely an increase from the previous order adding the complexity of all the local cars determining the optimal direction of movement. This requires the computers to link and process all information quickly and accurately, then send out instructions.

Sixth order: No detectable oncoming traffic, move to oncoming lane, then back immediately. This is put farther down the complexity tree as it would require a good bit more in communicating systems before relying on a car to determine an oncoming lane to be the correct choice right away. Even if it is observably empty. This requires sensors either on the road or for every vehicle to be required to broadcast position reliably to a system immediately accessible to the vehicle.

Through these six orders you might note that I haven't actually addressed the given matter directly. This is because that would rely on deliberately deciding to hurt someone. I indirectly stated my decision in the second order though by saying that if the car can determine no shoulder, it is to simply stop. This decision is due to my experience from recorded crashes and participating at accident scenes as a fireman. If there is a shoulder and people can move to it, damage and harm will be minimized by diverting in that direction. However, if there is a barricade on both sides, such as is often the case with a bridge, then diverting will cause more damage and all involved passengers will end up hurt. If there is a guarantee that everyone will be hurt extensively, then minimizing the number hurt becomes priority to improve the ability to save those hurt.

Graphic artist turned copyright lawyer/professor weighing in here. I‚Äôve spent the better part of past two decades teaching copyright and contract law at law schools, art schools, ComicCon‚Äôs, etc. A huge part of the problem is the art school model here in the US. Rare is the art school that puts serious effort behind teaching its students copyright and contract issues that are at the heart of every artist‚Äôs career.
Quite literally every time I teach at a new school or guest lecture for an art teacher I spend the majority of the time undoing the misinformation passed on to the students by professors who think that creativity is the only thing that matters in an artist‚Äôs career.
But here‚Äôs the funny thing: it‚Äôs not the art students to feel that way. I‚Äôm a product of art school myself and can tell you that the students who have taught for the past 10 years have been increasingly hungry for information on how to turn their art into a sustainable career. But if the school administration is not prioritizing the protection of art or the licensing of an artist's work product, they are failing their graduates.
You may be wondering why this is at all relevant to the issue of AI?
Simple: copyright law is complex and often counterintuitive. However, virtually everybody in the tech space knew this was coming for years now. Ask yourself ‚Äî how many of you in art school learned about the encroaching copyright issues of AI-generated art? What would‚Äôve happened if the art community had been informed before everything hits the fan this year was AI art? As both a practicing attorney and an academic I think it likely that you would have well-researched position papers and nonprofit arts groups seeking to bring cases to court to challenge the AI encroachment BEFORE this ‚ÄúAI-Artmageddon.‚Äù

AI is different than the breakthrough technologies of the past. The past technologies opened up new areas of work and people to figure things out, but now you have a AI "Brain" that is already figuring things out and robotics to replace human labor. AI's growth and evolution is on trace to reduce the need for human labor, not increase it.
Take your mom and pop pizza shop example. AI will be able to make pizza all automatically, which will eliminate the need for a mom and pop pizza place. This favors corporations automating more and hiring less.

I agree to a certain extend with Gabbie‚Äòs argument that the money the artist would get then simply gets to the person who programmed the AI. It always has been a natural aspect of a developing society that certain jobs will get redundant and eventually die out. This can be negative and positive, of course. A lot of tradition and culture gets lost, but a lot of unfortunate work environments will also die out (e.g. making mochi by hand is dying out in Japan, but also painting watches with radium paint isn‚Äôt a thing anymore).

However, I see a problem with the training required for the new jobs. Not everybody who is artistic can become a programmer, but a programmer can become an artist with ease through these AI programs. Furthermore, one programmer can make art for, let‚Äôs say, 50 artists with one program. Sure, the jobs would ‚Äúsimply shift‚Äù from artists to programmers. But not everybody can afford the training required to become a programmer, or has the understanding to become one. There‚Äôs a problem already with jobs requiring degrees despite not really needing one. Being an artist is one of those jobs that don‚Äôt require degrees, but if this job now shifts to programmers, it will be.

I‚Äôm on the fence with AI art. I think it can be useful as a tool for inspiration, but I find it unethical to publicise and make money off of it.
Unless the cloaking distorts an artist‚Äôs style in a consistent way, just a handful of cloaked images will be enough to rip out any noise and distortion like that.
I think AI in programming will peek in next two years, but then as new stuff comes out, it wont have data to feed itself, we will have to resort to good old stackoverflow again.

I tend to use public transportation as much as possible when it is convenient, for example when I lived in Los Angeles, I would ride the metro every time I went downtown with people. (If I was going by myself, I would just ride my motorcycle.)
I found that riding the metro was not only cheaper, but made the whole experience more relaxing!
Also when going to visit my cousin in Tijuana, I would ride the train to the border instead of driving from Los Angeles.
Here in Nashville, tho, public transportation is a joke.
Everyone drives everywhere! (my brother drives to my house instead of walking even though it is only a block away... (only 1500 meters....))

I think it boils down to what's being represented. Let's say artist X has a distinct art style and artist Y was inspired by them and uses some of their techniques and does something similar. There's still something inherent to an artist Y painting, it could be something new or other influences also sinking in, and while people will see the inspiration it's still artist Y's painting made by them. Where as with AI art it's usually "I fed this AI all of artist X's paintings and told them to paint G in that style" or to make more paintings like them. The inspiration is only them, and it's supposed to be by them no matter how poorly it's down it in some way's represents them not the person who had the AI do it or the AI itself. I think personally this is a legal battle ground that is rather iffy and needs to be figured out quickly, similarly to the deepfake sort of thing where technology is progressing to interesting and cool spaces that if not checked could end up being really bad.

So, I'm an artist, and my works are in the dataset that these AI are trained on (as well as many if not all of my artist friends works as well). I didn't consent to a robot using my art to generate new images, and neither did any of my friends. The people who run these AI image generators are making a profit on them, they charge fees for generating images with these bots they "made". By myself, and everyone else who's art is being used in them get nothing. If they had gotten permission, and the artists were getting a percentage or some sort of royalties, or anything really, i'd be totally fine with it!

(I'm self employed, if i don't sell my art, i don't make any income. I can't have a normal job due to health issues, same with many artists i know who have also had their work taken and used in the datasets)

The other thing i want to say is that without the images they are using without consent, without the millions of hours of hard work us artists have put into our craft, their AI image generators would be nothing. They wouldn't work. Their entire setup relies on the things we've made, and its insulting and disrespectful to just scrape all of that hard work into a little bot that can just spit out images faster than us artists could ever hope to. The more it improves and the better it gets, the more its going to put actual artists at risk.


I don't do fanart, but i feel like thats not comparable to what is being done here. Fanart is most often made by individual artists, but the owners of said characters (like pokemon, or anime, or videogames) are usually large corporations that aren't going to notice a dip in profits at all whatsoever if some kid at anime expo is selling pikachu keychains that they made at home. If people start using an AI to generate images in my style, I am going to notice that financially. If the value of art falls because of these image generators, big corporations will most likely profit off of it (because they can pay less to artists for their art), and actual artists will suffer. Also, if a big corporation really had a problem with fanart (which sometimes they do!) they have the full ability to go after artists and send them cease and desist letters. Comparing self employed individual artists to corporations in the context of fanart is not a fair comparison.

I get what people are saying when they compare the AI programs to people getting inspiration from art around them. Its inevitable to be inspired and influenced by the art you see and learn from as an artist, but, these AI image generators aren't real people. Its a program that an individual or team worked on and made. That team had full power over getting consent from artists for use of their images, and they didn't. Thats a conscious decision. Also, people getting inspired are able to understand nuance and what is and isn't appropriate when being inspired. AI cannot make this distinction, what is generates has no basis on what would or wouldn't be considered ok in art communities.

(this isn't related to anything you've said in the video but people are already posting AI images under the guise of them being the artists who "painted" them, as well as using this to scam people into "commissioning them" for images they use and AI to generate. Also pretty much everywhere images are posted or shared are being flooded with AI stuff. Not sure where this fits into any of the arguments but I wanted to mention it.)

To be clear, i don't dislike AI, I honestly think its great and it can be such a powerful tool for artists of any type to be inspired and build off of, but with how its being done now, it takes agency away from the artists its building off of. If the people making the datasets had gotten consent, and the artists being profited off of were getting at lease some sort of kick back, I'd be 100% fine with it. (and at least as far as i know, many other artists would be ok with this as well if this is how it was being done)

It is essential to understand that the elimination of jobs is not directly caused by artificial intelligence itself, but rather by the decisions of corporations driven by profit motives. These entities, controlled by a wealthy elite, prioritize financial gains over the welfare of their employees. Historically, advancements in automation, fueled by human creativity, have often led to reduced workforce requirements, enabling companies to increase profitability. This trend has contributed to the concentration of wealth among a small percentage of individuals at the top, who benefit at the expense of the broader workforce. The deployment of AI in various sectors is a continuation of this pattern. It's crucial to recognize that the root cause of job displacement is not the technology, but the unchecked capitalist system and the greed that drives it. Addressing the power and influence of this oligarchy is a critical challenge facing humanity, rather than attributing the issue to the technology itself. #EndTheOligarchy

I think self driving cars can become a complement to public transport. I think public transport is the way, but becaus eof it's costliness we need some sort of flexible transit.

The structure would be:
walk > 2-wheeler > 4-wheeler > bus/tram > trains/other major transport

Self driving cars help with this because they can be assigned as public transport. If integrated into the public transit system (via APIs and integration systems) you can plan a trip on your phone, hop on a robo-taxi, switch to light rail, hop onto a robo-taxi again, then scooter your way to your building before walking to the lift.

App > taxi > LRT > taxi > scooter(town center > walk
