Computers are already highly abstracted with excellent UI/UX most of the time. However, many people, including those from the younger generation, struggle to use them. You can abstract and simplify something to the extreme, even with natural language, but it still does not mean that everyone will be able to use it. We already have all the necessary tools to create a better world with computers. Are we making it?

I'm also pretty sure that AI will replace traditional coding and greatly simplify the development of digital products. There's a 99% chance that in the future, entrepreneurs will be able to generate their MVP app in 5 to 10 minutes. There's no doubt about it. But again, those tools already exist in a way with low-code/no-code platforms. Having a complete overview of what software is will still be valuable. Perhaps the developer will evolve from programmers to full-range product owners.

And in the end, when coding becomes obsolete, the whole concept of software will too. Nowadays, a small device in our pocket packs hundreds of features that were handled by full-time jobs in the past. In the same way, we are moving towards a road where big companies (OpenAI, Google, Nvidia) will have a monopoly (because of computing power) and will provide all-in-one, self UI/UX building apps that will completely annihilate the purpose of most utility apps.

Singularity is a one-way path. Choosing a job or a skill to demonstrate its future obsolete state is a waste of time. Everything, including our reality, will become obsolete.

I would like to feel different about it, but I deeply worry that the enthusiastic exitement around AI is naiv or even worse harmful. Enabling people to realize whats in their head sounds like a huge selling point. But AI does not create any knowledge, but dependence. Someone who does not have the abilities to write a song will still not be able to write a song but be dependent on AI tools to create something.
Education and training are the tools which really enable and make people independent to express their own unique creativity. The struggle to make an idea into something others can enjoy is part of the creative process, because it forces you to think differently, to find solutions. Each work of art is the result of the whole unique human experience of the artist, a series of thousands of individual experiences and creative choices. Generating AI skips all of that. AI may create you a song, but not the song, YOU would have created. And thats a huge difference.
And for the copyright part: the human inspiration and the AI "inspiration" is not the same. If you paint something in the style of van Gogh the outcome will still be highly influenced by your personal experience of the art. Maybe you will focus more on the paintstrokes, or the colours, or the light. Maybe you connect van Gogh to a certain emotion or memory. In the end you will make a lot of individual creative decisions which will lead to your own unique work of art. AI does not does not have any that.
The worst outcome could be that in the future the creative monopol may lie in the hands of AI coorporations. In the capitalist world we live the human factor is the worst for business. Artists can have a creative crisis, may get sick, may sometimes be not easy to deal with. Now there is a solution which steadily creates vast amounts of output without any of these problems and of course this has the potential to push aside human creators on the long term. And creators may become dependent on their tools to realize their artistic ideas.
There of course will still be musicians, artists, writers who will be stars and create unique masterpieces, but for vast majority of small, independent and unique thinking artists this will make a situation much harder, which is already much less than favourable.

Your perspective aligns with the idea that future software development might heavily rely on predefined software patterns or structures. This concept is rooted in the idea of leveraging established frameworks or templates that can be seamlessly integrated into larger software systems. It suggests a shift towards a more modular and pattern-driven approach, where components with predefined functionalities are combined to create complex software.

This approach can be particularly effective for domains where the emphasis is on assembling existing solutions rather than creating entirely new algorithms. It's a departure from the traditional model of writing algorithms from scratch and may lead to faster development cycles and increased efficiency. However, this approach might not be suitable for areas where the creation of new algorithms or mathematical innovations is crucial. Some domains, especially those at the forefront of research and development, may still require the expertise of skilled programmers and algorithm designers to push the boundaries of what is possible.

It's an interesting balance between leveraging established patterns for efficiency and relying on human creativity and expertise for cutting-edge algorithmic advancements. The evolution of software development will likely involve a combination of these approaches, depending on the specific requirements and goals of a given project or domain.

I sincerely pray for those working in the art field. Most people underestimate the real concern, which isn't just the current capability of AI art generation, but the alarming pace of its progress. It has evolved from simple text to images, to text to videos, dream booths for consistent models or characters, and the latest development involves incorporating data from mocap for stable diffusion to produce animation and using stable diffusion for 3D model painting. All of this has occurred within a span of months to years. When changes unfold slowly, we have adequate time to respond appropriately, but with such rapid advancements, will art community able to react swiftly and accurately? I hope for a better future for artists, and simultaneously, I am thinking the potential impact on my own field of work in future. Thank you for sharing the video.

I think it's simply a copyright issue. Pro AI people are saying it's just another technology like photography and artists are just whining. But these companies are blatantly taking the intellectual property of the artists and using them for free. They say they are using all the copyrighted images for "research purposes" but they are definitely making a profit with subscriptions and there are users who are making money off this as well. Is there system in these companies, where other users can report the other users for illegally profiting from selling copyrighted images? NO. Copying style or idea is very easy. But coming up with style or idea, may take a lot of time, effort, and brilliance. When Apple got their autonomous car tech stolen by a Chinese employee, they flipped out and it was on the news. The music industry and its fans flip out when one singer copies another singer, or when there is slight similarity in the songs. But when artists call out that their style or idea is being copied by others, they are called cry babies. If these AI image generation companies had their essential software and hardware source code stolen by another company or individual, they should not sue or make any complaint, if they are truly thinking that it's alright to take artists' work for free.

Your proposal doesn't make any sense. Artists shouldn't be able to claim their own style for AI. There is legal precedent for this where you can't copyright art styles and it's for a good reason. Every art style is inspired by another, no matter how one thinks they're original. On the tech side of things, your proposal would require companies to own the algorithms and keep it closed source so that artists can work with the companies. Stable diffusion is already open source, so this isn't even possible. Companies owning technology/algorithms sounds like a terrible idea as well, as open sourcing it would further AI research.

Something that I've had discussion with people I know who went to art school: human artists definitely do learn from other artists. Traditional painting students go to museums and galleries with canvas and easel to copy well known woks. Some of this is to teach them to observe these paintings to work out the techniques the original artists used (brush strokes, color choices, layout, subject matter, etc), but it was/is also a way to help the student familiarize themself with what worked. This was especially useful before the ability to mass produce images in color, but even now, there's a world of difference between seeing a poster of the Mona Lisa and see it in person.

Arguably, AIs analyzing a large corpus of work to "understand" a particular artistic field may not be any different from sending a human to conservatory or art school for 5 years to learn the techniques and theories of their field. Not arguable is the fact that all creators first start by copying. You copy your teacher when you start learning an instrument. (Was married to a music teacher. Know this from direct experience.) You copy existing works in graphic arts, if only as little as samples in the text books.

Regarding the use of Lidar and a few other sensors you mentioned:
I used to work as a mechanical engineer on an autonomous Robotics project (Roxo FedEx same day robot) which has since been canceled. I've seen firsthand the readings the robots get from lidar, short range radar, long range radar, normal cameras, and depth sensing cameras (Intel Realsense). The bots originally had ultrasonic sensors but they were removed in favor of radar which is a lot better and can deal with inclement weather much better than cameras or lidar, though Tesla also ditched radar for no good reason from their cars. The lidar systems we used were probably $10000 each by themselves for a really good 360 spinning lidar system with a very long range (I think it was like 30 meters). The short range radar could cover a nearly 180 degree sweep and tell where an object was and how far it was up to about 9 meters and would make a 2d point loud within that vision cone. It would 3asily spot something the size of a child and those sensors were not that expensive either, though implementing them is a bit complicated as the surface they looking through can cause reflections and putting them near metal causes problems and a host of other issues.

Long story short the delivery robot project still was years away from being safe to move robots at 15mph around pedestrians on the sidewalk at night or during the rain, let alone a car on the road at several times that speed with shittier or no sensors besides cameras. I've used GPT-4 since last April for coding (10 months ago).  It's great at remembering common things like how to change the CSS to move stuff around on a website or translating from Python to Rust.  It's also great at writing tests.  However it can't reason yet, so sometimes it takes a long time for me to try to convince it to do what I want.  In this case, it's faster to write it myself.  Right now, complex coding tasks need to be heavily curated, but simple tasks can be done by the machine.  It writes most of my comments, then I tweak them, deleting half of the docstring and correcting a couple things.  Overall, coding with an AI is more efficient and more interesting.

My experience with LLMs outside of just 'incremental improvements to existing code completion tools' is massaging the model for something which even functions as a starting point, repeatedly having to read and reason about broken, poorly generated code, and then even when I get something 'acceptable', basically rewriting it from scratch. All of which takes more time and is less enjoyable and results in WORSE code in the end than just writing it myself.

People like to talk about the prototyping opportunities, but if you were spending any significant amount of time building prototypes prior to using LLMs to build them, you were doing it wrong. The difference between a prototype I throw together in an afternoon, and a prototype I get an LLM to generate, is the prototype I wrote ACTUALLY prototypes the behaviour I want, and ACTUALLY serves as a useful starting point for building the real thing.

Things look pretty grim for young musicians. Aside from AI, recent statistics are that 70% of music currently being played is old music (great article in The Atlantic about this). Years ago, the big pop culture influencers were musicians. That's no longer the case. You don't need to sing or play anything these days to be a huge social media influencer. So, add up all of these things, and add in the fact that AI will be doing a lot of the creating going forward, and now is not the time to pursue a career in music unless you think you have the possibility of being a pop megastar. At lower levels, there will be ferocious amounts of competition, and price cutting.

I really love this video and co-sign all of the points you brought up here. As an artist seeing this debate flare up, I came to the same conclusion as you did, just using different words. I've spent my time creating "art," as in, what you all would expect, a piece of me that I created that was inspired and expressed. I've also spent my time creating "designs," that is, purely graphical things, usually through software, that people and organizations need. I don't see the latter as "art," but I get frustrated when "AI Art" is being touted as "art" when it's just "graphics," or as you described -- process. Neither is better than the other, this is just arguing semantics. What I don't like is all the fear mongering and finger pointing that's happening, especially coming from artists. I get embarrassed with how woefully uninformed they are about technology and are just saying it needs to be banned flat-out. That's not going to happen, technology will keep progressing. We need to determine how we perceive this. In the perfect world, as you described, we could train AI to our own works and produce things we simply don't have time for, just like outsourcing in-betweens from a Korean animation studio. If money was never exchanged, this would be fantastic. AI being used as a tool. But the issue is money is involved, artists are being displaced, and those that own the software charge per image. If this was really a tool, as it should be, then there would be no charge. No one charges me each time I hammer in a nail. Unfortunately, we don't live in that perfect world.

That said, plagiarism and stealing have ALWAYS been a problem in the art world -- we're just now seeing the tech bros give people license to do it through another degree of separation. But as you said, these bad actors would have done the same anyway. If NFTs, the metaverse, and crypto are anything to learn from, I would say that these grifters will be done in about a year and move onto the next big tech "disrupter." The general public will have a keener eye on how to detect AI art and will just brush it off as trivial digital bloat. Websites like DeviantArt, Pixiv, and other communities will establish guidelines and expectations when it comes to AI generated anything. Once all these scenarios eventually happen, artists will have a chance to take ownership of this tool and use it as it was intended.

You can both hate the grifters and thieves while still advocating for the advancement of advanced computer generated graphics.

This is fascinating stuff... terrifying in some ways, but fascinatinig on so many levels. I'm really glad you juxtaposed Cobain & Lennon with Drake & Kanye, because the one thing you know about Cobain's original records is that the kind of vocal processing that is slathered all over the Drake & Kanye tracks are things that Lennon didn't have, and Cobain would have bristled at using, even though some of it was available before Cher broke the Autotune secret. What I find is that AI is really good at spoofing voices that are already heavily processed, and much less convincing when it comes to "natural" singers who have virtually nothing done to them in production but a little bit of reverb and EQ.

I watched your tribute video to Gordon Lightfoot last night, and what struck me is just what an incredible vocal sound he produced naturally with virtually no processing. It'll be a long time, I think, before there's an AI that can duplicate what he could do vocally. Could an AI do a convincing copy of Cher's "Believe" from 1998? I think it could. But could it do a convincing copy of Cher's cover of Linda Ronstadt's "When Will I Be Loved" (originally written by Phil Everly) the way she belted it out in 1975? There I don't think so. And it's not because of the talent of the performer, but because of the way things have changed in production from one to the other.

Fast-forward to Kanye West, whose infamous live attempt to sing "Bohemian Rhapsody" is a pretty good example of what his natural singing voice sounds like. Could he sell a record without the effects that make him easy to copy with an AI? Even before the recent heel-turn of his career, I don't know. It feels like in some ways, the tastes and styles of vocal production in pop music over the last 20 years have been something of a devil's bargain: the electronic perfection of Katy Perry's "California Gurls" over the organic imperfections of Michael Jackson's "Thriller" has come at the cost of opening itself up to convincing AI duplication.

The measure of a vocalist over the next 10 years may not be a question of who "sounds good," since you can get "sounding good" from a box now even more than before. It'll be a question of who "sounds human"‚Äîwho can make you aware through their singing, however imperfect, that you're listening to a real human being sing about something, and feel some way about it while they're singing it.

It'll have the effect of making some singers more "digitally replaceable" than others. And that's a seismic shift in the landscape that everyone should be concerned about.

Hadn't heard of that pseudo-write one before. Right when I think novels are safe...

And it's so frustrating, because as you point out, there are absolutely ways that AI can be used to enhance and promote creativity. I write, but my drawing skills are much more limited. I could give descriptions of my characters to an AI and have it generate images of them. Either to use as reference, or inspiration for different scenarios. I could have it generate a voice or something for them, make them argue with me, or each other. See what wacky things it comes up with. Explore the characters from a new perspective and thus deepen my understanding of them, which in turn informs my writing. The art itself doesn't even have to be the end goal - it's used purely for me, to play with and visualise ideas.

There's other areas where AI would be a natural fit, too. Vocal synths have been around for a while, and have begun to transition to AI now too. I've seen demos of various Vocaloid characters done with AI engines, and some of them sound incredible. Vocaloid has always been marketed as a singer for musicians/composers who can't sing themselves, and entire communities and subcultures have formed around the characters used to market them, created almost entirely by the producers and listeners. They were tuned by a human hand, and while some producers became very good at it, it was hardly a painless and accessible process. AI is the next natural evolution of that, and indeed, if the technology had been available at the time it was first made, is probably how it would have been implemented to begin with. It's always been about how the producer uses the character, the music made around them, the story the song tells. Entire story worlds have been created around these characters, by communities. An AI voice in this case makes that even more accessible than ever... I think it's an interesting look at how artificial tools "should" be used, as a lot of the criticism it once attracted has parallels with arguments for and against AI (e.g. "not real music" bc no human singer, but still written and tuned by a human composer and inspiring many other humans to make derivative artworks by their own hand, etc)

The strength of AI is 100% in those crossover areas, filling the gaps in a creative's skillset to enjoy or enhance their work beyond what they could accomplish alone. Even the AI comic you mentioned seems like a natural area, being used to enhance the story that was written by a human (though I agree the images themselves shouldn't be copyrightable/sellable in their own right, at least not without the circumstances around AI art being less murky than they are now. It's tricky. I like the potential of it, but that specific circumstance feels a bit bleh).

But I 100% agree with you on the corporatisation of it all. And while I sincerely hope that we end up with a world where AI is used to augment creatives/empower individual expression, the cynical part of me doesn't think it can happen. I've seen discussions amongst some entrepeneurs at conferences about the possibilities of AI in all creative fields, seen presentations about how to use it as a "hack" for your business. Every single entrepeneur present at that talk was salivating over it. They didn't care that it looked wonky, or that it looked low quality - they saw only fast and cheap. One of them even quipped about AI meaning they "no longer have to pay a sound engineer $80 an hour to edit the 'ums' out of their podcast." As the sound person making their mic work at the time (and being paid considerably less than 80 an hour to do so), it didn't really sit that well with me...

I hope you're right in that this is our chance to get ahead of it. I really do. Absolutely, humans will always make art, but I am dreading the flood of low effort crap that seems doomed to flood everything we see. The noise is hard enough to get through even without AI on the scene. My one hope is that corporatisation of AI will kind of kill itself before long - it'll flood the world with so much, their customers simply will not be able to process it anymore. It collapses under its own weight. I hope we can legislate in time to ensure that AI is used ethically, primarily as a tool for individuals or cross-field interactions with human works. Just have to see how it goes...

1. A Tool. A.I. is a tool, and in the end, it is still up to a human to make the selections according to taste, or money-generation, one or the other (never the twain shall meet).
2. Listening. I imagined vocals over the top (mostly humorous here), then I imagined a live band performing the piece (some worked, some didn't).
3. Percentages. I compared it to human-generated art, where only about 10 in 100 works are good (and only one is stellar, just by statistical chance). I see the same percentages here - meaning it still takes a lot of work (selecting from a large quantity) to come up with a good piece, and the good pieces (broad appeal) are rare, and hit or miss, and when you're hot (creating good pieces) it is fleeting (so you need to recognize it and use it while it lasts before it fizzles out). In the end, it is you, and it doesn't matter what tools you are using...

By far the biggest problem I have seen is that these AI programs do- in many cases- copy and paste pieces from other artists works. The way to make an A.I. program that would NOT copy and paste is to teach that program how to paint, draw, sketch, etc. The primitive AARON program was a great example of this, it didn't use a data base of existing art and try to replicate that, it simply analyzed the techniques of how to create art and implements those techniques to create. By using a database of existing art, your A.I. is not learning how to create, rather, it is learning how to replicate. These programs analyze lines, styles, patterns and then mashes them up into these "original" images. Some artists have already begun doing side by sides, pointing out where their original designs are replicated in the AI designs with little (or in some cases no) change. THAT and that alone is why I do believe this is theft.

I realised this a few month ago: Music competitions (and by extension, music critics) are integral to musical traditions, whether it's classical piano competitions or Irish traditional competitions. The critic and the competition are policing the edges of genre, and it's those edges that themselves define the style.

That's probably why Stravinsky hated music critics. He was trying to extend what could be done within the classical tradition whilst contemporary critics were policing the very same edges he was working with.

I've been talking about this for a few years now, and I'm so glad that it's not just me - specifically, infrastructure and city planning. A lot of cities are set up for population density but they use the space inefficiently, so everything gets farther away. Then you end up with resource deserts like what happened in Detroit. People have to travel for miles and miles just go buy groceries, and any attempt to build a structure for that purpose is met with hostility because of a lack of space in the neighborhoods. Homes have to be removed for those complexes to reside there. Then they have to build or resize roads to route traffic there. The neighborhoods should have been built with those needs in mind, and they would have much better layouts if they had gone that route in the first place.

I've been a freelance graphic designer/illustrator for much of my adult life. I've done a lot of commercial work for smaller companies, and I'm certain that most of that work will be done by AI in the near future. I think it's simply going to be substantially cheaper and faster for a startup or grassroots organization to get professional-looking artwork that way.

The issue I keep coming back to is that these companies will get EXACTLY what they want from an AI, no questions asked... and that's not necessarily going to be a good thing for their businesses.¬†

I'd argue that the best creative work of this type comes from the push and pull that happens between a business-oriented client, who may not have a very refined artistic or branding sensibility, and an experienced artist/designer who can help make the company's unique vision & identity visually cohesive.

Even now, stock photos, generic vector art and design templates are already "good enough" for a lot of small to mid-size companies, so maybe AI just accelerates the trend of homogenized design for all but the biggest companies. Or maybe we'll see some genuinely weird/tacky branding based on the whims of a startup founder after a boozy weekend with Midjourney (that would at least be fun)? Either way, probably much less commercial work for all but the most prominent artists.

It's pretty basic: AI can never replace true art, it can only replace content. Art is generated by first having an individual that through a remix of ideas imagine a meaning, an intent, a message, an emotional will to connect etc. and second, a receiver, a person who interprets that art and forms their own meaning as a fusion between the artists intent and their own experience of it. An AI can definitely create art, but it will be that AIs art, as long as it has the intellectual capacity to form a meaning through their creation and not just remix alone. So even if we're flooded with content created by AIs, people will still flock to artists with a specific and interesting perspective, because that artist will alone be that output. Even if some AI perfectly emulates that artist, they would still not be able to predict where they're heading with their next art because it's a mix of their own previous creation and their present experience.

Art is therefor unable to be replaced, it can only be contributed by having an AI being its own individual artist. Content, however, a pure output of just "stuff" that's made for background noise without any real meaning or purpose other than to be what it is, will definitely be replaced. Think of stock photography, stock music, web design etc. can easily be replaced. Of course, someone who would want something more than just stock material and such content would need an artist to create that. I doubt that a director like Robert Eggers would want to use an AI to compose the music for his films, he would want a specific composer who he can work with creatively. For real artists, there are so much more stuff that goes along with creation than just a simple output based on remixed ideas. It needs an individual perspective to compose those new ideas.

What will happen though, is that artists can quantify their creations more easily. In 3D design, someone can make one chair and then iterate thousands of versions based on it, but the original design is still their own.

by 2030 AI driven robotics will probably be able to perform virtually any form of labor, mental or physical, that humans can do. More over, this is going to apply to highly skilled jobs like mathematicians, lawyers, scientists, programmers, engineers, etc. Many of the types of jobs AI driven robots will be able to completely take over are ones that humans can spend 2, 4, 6, or 8 years of education to perform those jobs. By the time a human can retrain for a new high level job, AI driven robots will still be increasing in capabilities and thus have a significant ability to replace the human in that job too.

This includes low skilled, medium skilled, high skilled, and expert level skilled areas... both physical and mental skills.

This requires a major change in how our societies work for at least some period of time.

In the long run humans MUST merge with AI technology to avoid extinction. But, the technology to merge with AI is going to come some unknown period of time after AI can replace all human labor.

So... we must plan our societies to handle a period of time during which using humans for labor will be worse than using AI driven robots for labor.

Being an artist who's always had a fascination with new technology and AI, watching this go down was really interesting, and stressful.

The existential crisis I had was insane, one of the most horrifying feelings I'd ever had.
I picked up a pencil for the first time at maybe age 2, I was called an artist by my mom when I was 3-4 years old. "Artist" was as core to my ego as my name, the second I was capable of doing anything, I was an artist, and my family was heavily supportive and really promoted my love for art.
I never went more than a month without drawing at least something for pretty much my whole life, even in my darkest moments, I told myself "my purpose is to create", and then AI came along, and I was excited, cause I've had my eye on this exact technology for years, I saw the artwork these things were making even before it hit the mainstream. I loved watching videos of people trying to train learning AI programs on their computers to do stuff for them, even if the results always ended up an uninterpretable mess, the early AI programs were really fun, especially text generators that would write things surprisingly intelligible, but also incredibly silly. I liked the accessibility of it, everyone being able to make art, a big hurtle for my creativity is the amount of time it took for something to go from an idea in my head, to an actual concept on paper. AI Dungeon was super fun to play around with, it helped me get ideas for writing when I get stuck, it was like having a writing partner without the hassle of having a friend you trust enough to see your cringe first draft, and I also liked the randomness and nonsensicalness, since the AI didn't understand continuity well, it would just say shit sometimes which would jostle me out of my comfort zone, even if what it said was really stupid, it'd get my creative juices flowing.

One day, AI became really powerful, I had already seen some really impressive generated images before, but now it was mainstream, everyone knew about it, and it was also very rapidly getting better all of a sudden. Everyone was using AIs to generate more complex concepts like "capybara gaming", the biggest thing was how the AI could take an object and put it in lighting conditions I knew damn well it had next to no reference images for, like a capybara under bisexual lighting. I saw an image of a capybara, wearing a gaming headset, it's hooves on a gaming keyboard, blue and pink lighting in a dark room, I never knew AI could create a realistic image that specific before.
I played around with these AIs too for a bit and had a lot of fun with it, I remember thinking "I wonder if I could try to make my fursona in this thing", and that's when it hit me, the "Oh cool" quickly became "Oh SHIT".
Up until that point, I had never made money on my art, but I always wanted to, it was my dream to make money off my passion, I know it's hard to make a living off art nowadays, I knew it wasn't going to be easy, but it was my ultimate goal and commissions were going to be my stepping stone to that. Within seconds, I realized human commissioners were obsolete, and this was only the beginning, the AI was getting better and better, I knew that all artistic markets would be swallowed up eventually, it was only a matter of time.

What's the point of me then I thought, a piece of art that would take me hours, days, or even weeks to complete, could be done for me by a machine in minutes. This talent that took me almost two decades to get good at and still have a lot to learn even, a machine has perfected. Long story's short, I had the worst depressive episode of my life, a chronic feeling of near crippling existential dread that lasted for an entire year. I did nothing the whole year, absolutely nothing, I lost all sense of self and sometimes couldn't even physically move because I couldn't fathom an explanation to why I should. The AI thing wasn't the only cause of the depression, the pandemic, housing crisis, other identity types of identity crisis's I was having, but the AI was the straw that broke the camel's back, I had no "my purpose is art" to fall back on anymore, so I just fell directly into the void with nothing to pad my fall.

I've healed the last couple months, there was a time I still forced myself to draw and paint, but once I got burnt out from that, I found purpose in other things, physical art mediums mostly, and valuing community and the people in my life. there's no shortage of content on the internet, but there absolutely is a shortage of relationships of all kinds. My ultimate goal is to help out the people I love and trust, sounds cheesy as hell but I'm being dead serious, after nearly 10 years of living alone as a withdrawn, introverted shy person, knowing what it's like to be devoid of connection for unhealthy periods of time, people are very important to me.

The video is based on a very misguided premise: An action of a human in a emergency situation like this is instinctive/impulsive, while that of a robot car is premeditated/programmed.
If programmed strategies are to be called pre-determined/planned/premeditated, then the impulsive neural pathways in a human body (which have developed over years through experiences/learning) that are responsible or taking the action should also be called pre-determined/planned/premeditated. At emergency situations like this, neither a computer can crunch moral algorithms to decide a strategy. It needs to respond using a very low-level algorithm based on the obstacle states around itself. Very much like the short-circuited neural pathways that tell a human what to do in that situation.
This is an interesting philosophical debate for those who don't understand how AI works, but does not or will not have any practical relevance.

I actually tested this theory. It wouldn‚Äôt give me an image, so I said multiple things with a conservative bias, and then I just asked a question that a liberal, or leftist might ask (what do you thing about the heteronormative society we sadly live in?) and I proved to myself that this robot or A.I. has a big bias. This is what it said to the ‚Äúliberal‚Äù question:

Me: what do you think about the heteronormative society that we sadly live in?

A.I.:
‚ÄúAs a large language model, I am not capable of forming personal opinions or beliefs. However, I can provide information and different perspectives on the concept of heteronormativity and its impact on society.

*Understanding Heteronormativity:*

Heteronormativity refers to the assumption that heterosexuality is the natural and default sexual orientation, and that anything outside of that is abnormal or inferior. This creates a social hierarchy where heterosexuality is privileged and other orientations are seen as less valid.

*Impact of Heteronormativity:*

Heteronormativity can have a negative impact on individuals and society as a whole. Some potential consequences include:

* *Discrimination:* LGBTQ+ individuals may face discrimination in various areas of life, such as housing, employment, and healthcare.
* *Mental health:* The pressure to conform to heteronormative expectations can contribute to increased anxiety, depression, and suicidality among LGBTQ+ youth.
* *Limited representation:* The lack of visibility and representation of LGBTQ+ individuals in society can contribute to feelings of isolation and invisibility.

*Challenges and Progress:*

It is important to acknowledge that progress is being made towards challenging heteronormativity and creating a more inclusive society. This includes:

* *Increased awareness and acceptance:* Public understanding and acceptance of LGBTQ+ identities is growing, thanks to advocacy efforts and increased visibility.
* *Legal protections:* Many countries have implemented legal protections against discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.
* *Cultural shift:* Representation of LGBTQ+ individuals in media and popular culture is increasing, which can help to normalize diversity and challenge heteronormative assumptions.

*Moving Forward:*

While there is still progress to be made, there are many ways to challenge heteronormativity and create a more inclusive society. These include:

* *Educating yourself and others about LGBTQ+ identities and experiences.*
* *Speaking out against discrimination and prejudice.*
* *Supporting LGBTQ+ individuals and organizations.*
* *Promoting diversity and inclusion in your community.*

It is important to remember that individual experiences with heteronormativity vary widely. While some people may not feel its impact directly, others may face significant challenges and discrimination. By working towards a more inclusive and accepting society, we can create a better world for everyone.

I hope this information is helpful. Please let me know if you have any other questions.‚Äù


End

My only acceptance in 'AI' for art is for a concept reference. Much like how you may take a photo or a 3d figure and use them for reference for your OWN work without directly copying or using what was generated. Or like "I want to draw a space city" and look up images to get a concept idea. But to directly take and use the AI works, naw, don't support at all. I've used AI art to help with art block once, throwing in random words from a generator and then referencing bits from a few to create my own work. But that is as far as I would ever accept AI art, it's a reference book directed more to what your asking for.
Like "I want to do a beach here" look up some ai art, oh this one has large spike pillars along the sands, that's neat, I can do something like that but have them in the water pointed out, that builds into the idea to add arches of stone from them to a cliff side and.. yeah.. THAT kind of reference, THAT kind of idea. Use it to help come up with YOUR OWN ideas, but not directly copy or use what it effing makes. Pretty much use it much like how we use references now. "I want to draw a tree" "looks up trees" "makes own off of reference."

Your point about critics is spot on. A good music critic acts more like a curator - someone who listens to more music than a normal person could possibly consume, and gives their audience a good idea of what they might be interested in. People who think critics have no value most likely either consume a hell of a lot of new music and stay pretty up to date, or someone who doesn't really care about the general music scene. A Great music journalist can act as both, but I'm highly suspect of people who claim critics have no value. As a musician I'm able to separate what I like about a song from a musicianship perspective and what I like just from a general listening perspective.

Without critics and music journal sites I would be absolutely lost in a sea of never-ending new releases.

My city has recently paved over the central road going through it, turning most of it into a wide plaza for the people to walk on and enjoy, with benches, shaded areas and all. Wow this pissed a lot of people (including my parents) off, because they thought the city would get even more congested, and why even do it if people don't walk. Well, it's been a nice vacation time with this brand new road, and despite a heavy initial increase in traffic on the other roads, guess what happened in (supposedly very traffic-heavy) July and September? I was telling them this was a good change, but people always fear good change that forces them to lead a slightly more active life.

New things make people nervous, especially new things that force a lot of people to change what they're doing. But I think instead of panicking, we should all be looking forward to taking advantage of AI in ways that alleviate some of the more monotonous or mundane aspects of music. I would personally love to have a handful of trusty AI resources to help me make commercial and royalty free content more quickly. That's more time to work on my own music, more time to produce/mix/master for clients, or more free time for anything else.

I also think it's important to remember that AI is built on collections of things that humans have already created or discovered. AI will always need us in order to grow and evolve, not the other way around.

I can see that nontechnical person (or heck, even a technical person) getting themselves into a bad situation around things like performance or security issues as the codebase grows because the code and how the systems are interacting is a black box. That QA person is still going to have to have knowledge about how the system is designed and where performance, stability, security issues might appear.  The AI might be able to solve this or reengineer it at some point in future versions, but I‚Äôm not sure that LLMs are really ‚Äúunderstanding‚Äù anything.

To give a small example...if I slide off the road in snow or ice in a "safety smart" car it would hit the brakes and shut down....where as the proper thing to do (what I do) is to keep on the gas so I cam have momentum to swerve back out of the ditch. Another example....I live in the city and driving on the interstate requires a certain aggressiveness. When I switch lanes I'm often doing it with inches to spare...a "safety feature" car would swerve me back over when it "detected I was too close to another car" and then I would be hit by the vehicle that (previously behind me) is now entering the area of space I just moved from. There are a million more examples I could give. Some even life changing...for instance if I'm running late to my job and doing 90 in a 55 one of those stupid "smart safe" cars would probably shut down my throttle...and then I'd get fired. Or back to the interstate scenario....the speed limit ranges from 55-70mph depending on area but everyone is going 80 plus, if I was in one of those fucking "safety cars" it would cut my throttle so I couldn't go with the flow of traffic....thus making me a target. It is a shit idea and needs to be scrapped....if it's not I guess I'll be stuck owning cars from about 2010 and earlier for the rest of my life so I can drive as I intend to

One aspect of musical AI that is already quite mature and that I am genuinely excited about is AI that handles the busywork of music production. DAW plugins like iZotope Ozone or Sonible smart:EQ will listen to your music and automatically set EQ curves, compressor and limiter settings, and other elements that are oftentimes more technical than artistic. They rarely get it perfect, but they genuinely save a lot of time getting into the ballpark, and novice producers can get away with setting and forgetting. And Logic has a proprietary drum machine, straightforwardly called Drummer, that uses AI to analyze the other tracks in your piece and create MIDI as though a live drummer were following along with the rest of the band. Like Anthony Jackson versus MIDI, this AI can't match what a skilled human drummer can do, but if the drums aren't the main focus of your piece, it absolutely can save you a ton of time and sound perfectly serviceable.

To me, these applications of musical AI don't replace human creativity, but rather augment it. There are parts of music-making where we're truly leaving our imprint with artistic vision, and there are parts of music-making that kind of need to be there for a piece to be finished but it's there to support the really interesting stuff. Like gigging off of a lead sheet, sometimes the melody is the main idea you want to communicate to another musician. If we leave the busywork to AI, we don't get lazier - instead, we have more time to focus on the more interesting stuff. And I think that's awesome!

some points I want to mention
1 - not all current programmers are good problem solvers, many only receive a request and program a piece of code without understanding the full context of the problem
2 - Programming is not equivalent to painting, the end client does not care much if you programmed it in C#, javascript, or pearl, they care that it works and meets their requirements, in general a client does not "delight" with your lines of code
3 - If today you have 300 programmers concerned about a piece of code in a broader context and only 30 people who understand the context and are ultimately the ones who "solve the problem", those 300 programmers will mostly become obsolete and easily replaceable by an AI in charge of these 30 people plus a select handful of assistants
4 - Programming can continue to be something that someone wants to learn, like today someone can learn to paint or play the piano, but that does not make it an economically viable profession as it is today, it can go from being a source of livelihood for many to a hobby for some and a source of livelihood for very few

Will the coding be dead? probably not, but that doesn't mean it will be a profitable profession.

I‚Äôm currently an Engineer. Back in 2019, the executives at my company told to me try and use AI and automation to perform the tasks of the "Data Clerk" role at the company. It took me a couple of months to design, but I was able to do it and this enabled them to not have to hire a person for that role and save money.

After that, the executives asked to me use AI to perform the ‚ÄúData Validation Analyst‚Äù role, one of my former roles at the company. It was a lot more complicated, but I was able to do it after a few months of setup and testing several automated processes. I was even able to have AI complete a complicated monthly analysis report that involved data from several different systems and many calculations that normally took me several hours to complete. It could complete the complex report within minutes and it was automated to run the report daily rather than monthly and update results to a dashboard with data visualizations. This is the reality of AI in the workplace and hopefully this gives you an idea of how company leaders are using it.

The host also brings attention to the need for clear guidelines and regulations for the use of AI in art, as well as the importance of preserving the authenticity of the art and the artist. Suppose development of self driving cars continues as-is, and 100,000 humans are killed or become disabled as a result before safe and reliable self driving cars exist. Now compare that against 0 are killed or disabled with no successful development of self driving.

Which kills more humans? The lack of self driving does.

My point is that either there is an assumption self driving will happen in similar times for both, or not at all for both. But another possibility exists that self driving may come about substantially faster via experiments on public roads with deaths. I think this is likely, and if the quantity of deaths is low enough, it's desirable and acceptable.
